headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our fourth quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner; and John Reyes. I just wanted to remind everybody that all statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our fourth quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner; and John Reyes. I just wanted to remind everybody that all statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, February 17, 2016, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A reconciliation to GAAP and the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and the audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. We had a pretty good fourth quarter and 2015, so we're happy to open up for questions.
componenttext: Thank you, Clem. We had a pretty good fourth quarter and 2015, so we're happy to open up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Smedes Rose with Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Smedes Rose with Citigroup.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is just looking at your property manager payroll and supervisory payroll, those line items combined came in, it looks like, about 1% for the full year in terms of total increases. And you guys always do a good job of keeping those payroll numb
componenttext: My question is just looking at your property manager payroll and supervisory payroll, those line items combined came in, it looks like, about 1% for the full year in terms of total increases. And you guys always do a good job of keeping those payroll numbers fairly low in terms of percentage increases, but as you think about 2016, is that sustainable keeping it at that pace? Or what kind of increases would you expect maybe going forward?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Smedes, I would say you should probably expect between 2% and 3%.
componenttext: Smedes, I would say you should probably expect between 2% and 3%.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That high?
componenttext: That high?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I mean, you got supervisory payroll for the year for 1.9%. We were light a few district managers in 2016 -- or '15, so we'll fill in the bench there. On-site property manager payroll, I'm looking 0.6%. That will probably be up 1% to 1.5%, would
componenttext: Yes. Well, I mean, you got supervisory payroll for the year for 1.9%. We were light a few district managers in 2016 -- or '15, so we'll fill in the bench there. On-site property manager payroll, I'm looking 0.6%. That will probably be up 1% to 1.5%, would be my guess.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can I just ask you on -- you did -- the acquisition activity thus far in the first quarter looks like almost as much as you did for the full year in '15. Can you share maybe what kind of yields you're buying at? Or maybe any thoughts on kin
componenttext: Okay. And then can I just ask you on -- you did -- the acquisition activity thus far in the first quarter looks like almost as much as you did for the full year in '15. Can you share maybe what kind of yields you're buying at? Or maybe any thoughts on kind of just pricing that you're seeing now versus what you were seeing last year or availability of product or -- it just seems like it accelerated quite a bit from what you had done last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't read too much into that. I think last year, we were a little light on volume pricing as, for the most part, gotten away from us. The transactions that we see, a lot of the transactions we see in the marketplace, we just -- it doesn't work
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't read too much into that. I think last year, we were a little light on volume pricing as, for the most part, gotten away from us. The transactions that we see, a lot of the transactions we see in the marketplace, we just -- it doesn't work in terms of what we're looking for in terms of returns or value per foot. And that was pretty much the case last year, and I'd say it's continued into this year. We get deals here and there. And so that's why the volume's $100 million, $150 million.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ron, as you look into next year -- or this year and next year, do you see anything on the horizon that you can point to that would suggest or make that 6% realized rent growth or contract rent growth number you posted this year to slow down at all?
componenttext: So Ron, as you look into next year -- or this year and next year, do you see anything on the horizon that you can point to that would suggest or make that 6% realized rent growth or contract rent growth number you posted this year to slow down at all?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Ki, I've been saying for the last couple of quarters, and I think it's true, eventually, the uptick in new supply, the number of properties being constructed, will have an impact on rental rates or realized rents per foot. When that takes place, I d
componenttext: Well, Ki, I've been saying for the last couple of quarters, and I think it's true, eventually, the uptick in new supply, the number of properties being constructed, will have an impact on rental rates or realized rents per foot. When that takes place, I don't know. Is it back half of this year? Is it 2017 or '18? I don't know. The new supply steps are kind of a best guess. My best guess is we probably got 1,000 to 1,200 properties under construction in the U.S. And that's probably 2%, 2.5%, which is close to 3x population growth. The flip side of that is that new supply is not coming in, in all markets. And so the markets with the greater-than-average supply growth, unless the population is flowing there, will have rental rates impacted sooner rather than later. But when that takes place, Ki, I don't know. It will happen, though. I mean, it's economics, supply and demand, and so as that supply comes on, it will impact our ability to price products.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you said 2.5% of stock coming online. How much of that is in your markets though when you look at it not from areas where you're not in but just where you're competing in?
componenttext: Okay. And you said 2.5% of stock coming online. How much of that is in your markets though when you look at it not from areas where you're not in but just where you're competing in?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the new supply usually comes in, in the markets where it's easier to build, so Texas and Florida. The boroughs of New York have had a number of projects under construction for a while, big projects. So I'd focus on those markets in terms of new supp
componenttext: Well, the new supply usually comes in, in the markets where it's easier to build, so Texas and Florida. The boroughs of New York have had a number of projects under construction for a while, big projects. So I'd focus on those markets in terms of new supply. The flip side of that is Florida and Texas have great population flows to them. So they can handle above-average supply growth. We're not seeing a lot of stuff here in California, really, on the West Coast, to speak of.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jana Galan with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jana Galan with Bank of America.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk to kind of just operations during the slower winter months, use of concessions and what you saw. And I think I was surprised the occupancy held up stronger than prior fourth quarters.
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk to kind of just operations during the slower winter months, use of concessions and what you saw. And I think I was surprised the occupancy held up stronger than prior fourth quarters.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Jana, this is John. The occupancy continued to hold up. We did some television advertising in Q4 as we did in Q4 last year. I don't think it was as effective though as we saw in prior years. But nonetheless, I think the demand was still there but not
componenttext: Hi, Jana, this is John. The occupancy continued to hold up. We did some television advertising in Q4 as we did in Q4 last year. I don't think it was as effective though as we saw in prior years. But nonetheless, I think the demand was still there but not as strong as we were hoping. Our move-in volumes were up about 0.9%, and people were moving in at rates that were approximately 4% higher. But overall, I was very pleased. I think the demand coming into our systems, either through the call center or the websites, continues to be strong. I think our biggest problem right now is really having the available space to rent and to satisfy that demand. So we'll keep working on that as we move forward. Demand continues to be strong year-to-date for the first 1.5 months of this year. So things still look pretty good right now.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just in terms of any geographic variance, are you still kind of experiencing stronger rent growth and occupancies on the West Coast markets?
componenttext: And just in terms of any geographic variance, are you still kind of experiencing stronger rent growth and occupancies on the West Coast markets?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: West Coast is definitely our strongest markets, regions. The Midwest, and I would say the Great Lakes markets, are probably the weakest right now, the Chicago market, Milwaukee market, Minneapolis, down into St. Louis. Florida is doing very well. Most of
componenttext: West Coast is definitely our strongest markets, regions. The Midwest, and I would say the Great Lakes markets, are probably the weakest right now, the Chicago market, Milwaukee market, Minneapolis, down into St. Louis. Florida is doing very well. Most of Texas is doing well. The Carolinas are also doing well. We're a little weak in the D.C. markets, the Baltimore market. But other than that, most of the other markets are doing pretty good.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just thinking about fundamentals in the current environment and your operating strategy here into -- in the new year, with the peak leasing season approaching, do you think that your customer acquisition cost will continue to improve in '16? I think last
componenttext: Just thinking about fundamentals in the current environment and your operating strategy here into -- in the new year, with the peak leasing season approaching, do you think that your customer acquisition cost will continue to improve in '16? I think last quarter, you said you profited $35 per move-in in the first month, that was net of marketing and discount. And that was a peak since you began tracking that metric. Do you think that you can improve upon that in '16?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, get the -- the short answer, Todd, is, yes, because I think Street rates will be higher in '16 than '15. We probably won't do as much advertising, and we'll be mindful of holding customer volumes. So net-net, if you reduce your marketing cost, rates
componenttext: Well, get the -- the short answer, Todd, is, yes, because I think Street rates will be higher in '16 than '15. We probably won't do as much advertising, and we'll be mindful of holding customer volumes. So net-net, if you reduce your marketing cost, rates go higher, and you hold volumes, then the customer profitability will go up. In Q4, our profit was about $27 per customer versus $19. So we were up 42% in terms of customer profitability in Q4. For the year, we were up about 33%.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just following up on, I think, the prior question, you just said that the TV advertising was not as effective in the fourth quarter. Any reason why that you can point to, to explain that?
componenttext: Okay. And then just following up on, I think, the prior question, you just said that the TV advertising was not as effective in the fourth quarter. Any reason why that you can point to, to explain that?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Todd, no. I can't explain it. It's just -- it's one of the things you just never really know how markets are going to be -- react. It could be weather, it could be people busy doing something else, not paying attention. Maybe -- we just don't know.
componenttext: Todd, no. I can't explain it. It's just -- it's one of the things you just never really know how markets are going to be -- react. It could be weather, it could be people busy doing something else, not paying attention. Maybe -- we just don't know.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, can you talk about how the fourth quarter played out to what your expectations were? And in particular, as you well know, the retailers had a tough calendar fourth quarter because of the warm winter weather, so people weren't buying jackets. But I'd
componenttext: Ron, can you talk about how the fourth quarter played out to what your expectations were? And in particular, as you well know, the retailers had a tough calendar fourth quarter because of the warm winter weather, so people weren't buying jackets. But I'd imagine, it probably meant that they might have been getting out of their houses more to do things like use self-storage. Do you think the winter weather played into your favor in the fourth quarter?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: From a revenue management standpoint, I think it came in where we thought, right?
componenttext: From a revenue management standpoint, I think it came in where we thought, right?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we were -- there was no surprises, Ross, in terms of demand into the system. The rental rates that we were getting, a lot of our properties aren't -- still at the West Coast is still doing very well, which is really driving a lot of this. And
componenttext: Yes, I think we were -- there was no surprises, Ross, in terms of demand into the system. The rental rates that we were getting, a lot of our properties aren't -- still at the West Coast is still doing very well, which is really driving a lot of this. And I don't think the West Coast was -- is as subject to weather changes as maybe the East Coast is.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ross, move-in volume in Q4 was up 0.9%. The move-out volume was up 1.7%. Recall, last year in the fourth quarter, pretty harsh winter, so my guess is people were -- maybe unable to get out of their storage facilities, so maybe that's why we had an uptick
componenttext: Ross, move-in volume in Q4 was up 0.9%. The move-out volume was up 1.7%. Recall, last year in the fourth quarter, pretty harsh winter, so my guess is people were -- maybe unable to get out of their storage facilities, so maybe that's why we had an uptick in volume. So -- but we still had positive flows on the inside.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question, can you talk a little bit about to what extent you're using targeted online advertising such as Facebook, and I think about when I travel to Los Angeles, right, Mark Zuckerberg somehow knows I'm in Los Angeles and starts sending me
componenttext: Okay. Second question, can you talk a little bit about to what extent you're using targeted online advertising such as Facebook, and I think about when I travel to Los Angeles, right, Mark Zuckerberg somehow knows I'm in Los Angeles and starts sending me L.A.-based business ads. Are you guys doing that in any fashion and thinking about shifting more of your spend away from TV towards targeted online and embracing that channel a little more?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say this, we do spend -- we actually spend more money on online advertising, either through keyword search bids or banner advertising, than we do on television advertising. Television has really come down in terms of our spend. So much of ou
componenttext: Well, I would say this, we do spend -- we actually spend more money on online advertising, either through keyword search bids or banner advertising, than we do on television advertising. Television has really come down in terms of our spend. So much of our dollars are now being spent online. In terms of what you're referring to in terms of using, I guess, social media to do things, we certainly are thinking about things like that. I don't want to tell you that we are doing things like that at the moment but certainly something that we -- we're constantly exploring thoughts on how we can attract the customer and a better customer actually, using the demographic information that we have or can get from some other source to try to attract the better customer. But I would tell you this, we're in the very beginning stages, so we've been thinking about doing stuff like that.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ross, to give you some color. On television last year, we spent about $4.5 million, and on the Internet, we spent about $13 million. So the Internet is by far our major marketing channel, and that's a combination of some of the marketing stuff John just t
componenttext: Ross, to give you some color. On television last year, we spent about $4.5 million, and on the Internet, we spent about $13 million. So the Internet is by far our major marketing channel, and that's a combination of some of the marketing stuff John just touched on, the website and then bidding on various terms and phrases across the country.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk a little bit about G&A cost for 2016, kind of what might be a good run rate? And how much of legal costs will be -- are you guys assuming for 2016?
componenttext: Can you just talk a little bit about G&A cost for 2016, kind of what might be a good run rate? And how much of legal costs will be -- are you guys assuming for 2016?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm looking at our GC here and she's smiling and shaking her head. She doesn't know what legal costs would be. But we're estimating a ballpark range of between, like for G&A, for the entire fiscal 2016, somewhere in the neighborhood of between $80 million
componenttext: I'm looking at our GC here and she's smiling and shaking her head. She doesn't know what legal costs would be. But we're estimating a ballpark range of between, like for G&A, for the entire fiscal 2016, somewhere in the neighborhood of between $80 million and $90 million.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one thing on Europe, can you just comment a little bit on Shurgard's performance? And then also how is development ramping up in Europe? Kind of last quarter, you guys had mentioned that they're starting to pick up.
componenttext: Okay. And then just one thing on Europe, can you just comment a little bit on Shurgard's performance? And then also how is development ramping up in Europe? Kind of last quarter, you guys had mentioned that they're starting to pick up.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, let me start with development. We opened -- last year, we opened 3 properties in London, and we've got 3 more at various stages of development as well, either we're taking on the land or about to take on the land. Or we're working through the
componenttext: Sure. Well, let me start with development. We opened -- last year, we opened 3 properties in London, and we've got 3 more at various stages of development as well, either we're taking on the land or about to take on the land. Or we're working through the zoning process. So all combined, that -- when that's done, we'll be at about 500,000 feet added, about $90 million invested there. And we're looking around the market to look to do some development, in East Berlin, but we don't have anything in the hopper in the moment. For Europe, Q4 revenues were up 4.7%. Income was up 1.3%. They had a fair number of R&M stuff and property tax credits last year that didn't flow through this year, so expenses were up a bit. So -- and then all the revenue growth didn't flow through to the bottom line. For the year, Europe revenues were up 4.5% and NOI was up 5.5%. So Europe had a very good year. Occupancies averaged for the year 89.8 versus 85.3 last year, and minor degradation of rents. So it was a very good year in Europe operationally.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Burke with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Burke with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, a gap in operating ability has always existed between PSA and your private competitors. In your view, has this gap widened or narrowed over the last 5 years and why?
componenttext: Ron, a gap in operating ability has always existed between PSA and your private competitors. In your view, has this gap widened or narrowed over the last 5 years and why?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, since I have no information on private competitors, I can't answer that question.
componenttext: Well, since I have no information on private competitors, I can't answer that question.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if we can look to a point beyond 2016, just speaking specifically towards PSA, in an environment where operating fundamentals have slowed meaningfully, what are the main weapons that you'll utilize to continue to capture outside share of de
componenttext: Okay. And then if we can look to a point beyond 2016, just speaking specifically towards PSA, in an environment where operating fundamentals have slowed meaningfully, what are the main weapons that you'll utilize to continue to capture outside share of demand? Is there anything in particular that you have left in the closet right now that hasn't been brought out yet?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the great thing about Public Storage is we have a thing called a brand, which no one else has. So that is the, by far, the biggest, so to speak, bazooka, which we're using all the time. Combine that with the operational skills of our field personnel
componenttext: Well, the great thing about Public Storage is we have a thing called a brand, which no one else has. So that is the, by far, the biggest, so to speak, bazooka, which we're using all the time. Combine that with the operational skills of our field personnel who are exceptional, the Internet marketing, the technology, all that, and a platform. If you look at how -- what market share we have in the major metro markets, I mean, for the most part, we're the dominant provider. And as I think I've said before, when things get tough, the big dog eats first. And we're the big dog. So...

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And you produced 22% NOI growth in your 2013 acquisition bucket during 2015. Can you provide just, in general, the early stage strategy of acquisitions? What are you focused on from a revenue and expense standpoint during year 1 versus year 2 versus
componenttext: Sure. And you produced 22% NOI growth in your 2013 acquisition bucket during 2015. Can you provide just, in general, the early stage strategy of acquisitions? What are you focused on from a revenue and expense standpoint during year 1 versus year 2 versus year 3?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, expenses, they fit into the platform, right? So if you have a property in Miami or Dallas or L.A., they just kind of fold into the district, and the operating platform and the expenses become very consistent very quickly with what other properties i
componenttext: Well, expenses, they fit into the platform, right? So if you have a property in Miami or Dallas or L.A., they just kind of fold into the district, and the operating platform and the expenses become very consistent very quickly with what other properties in that market are operating for, operating at in terms of an expense per foot other than property taxes, which is always kind of the swing item on the expense side. On the revenue side, it's fill them up as fast as possible. Generally, discount rates increase promotional discounts. Fill them up, get them stabilized and get that tenant base in there and then operate them consistent with the way we do the rest of the portfolio.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JP Morgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JP Morgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of things. First, I was wondering, can you give us the January 31 spot rates that you typically do the year-over-year rate increase for occupancies, et cetera?
componenttext: A couple of things. First, I was wondering, can you give us the January 31 spot rates that you typically do the year-over-year rate increase for occupancies, et cetera?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. At the end of January, occupancies were 93.2 versus 93.0. And our in-place rents were 15 50 versus 14 61. So occupancy is up 0.2%, in-place rents up 6%. Street rates were higher.
componenttext: Sure, Mike. At the end of January, occupancies were 93.2 versus 93.0. And our in-place rents were 15 50 versus 14 61. So occupancy is up 0.2%, in-place rents up 6%. Street rates were higher.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then for rate increases going out to tenants at this point, any color you can share with us?
componenttext: Okay. And then for rate increases going out to tenants at this point, any color you can share with us?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike. This is John. We really haven't started sending out increases. We'll be gearing up at the end of this month to really start sending the first wave out. I anticipate that it will be very similar to the past 2 years. People who have been here lon
componenttext: Yes, Mike. This is John. We really haven't started sending out increases. We'll be gearing up at the end of this month to really start sending the first wave out. I anticipate that it will be very similar to the past 2 years. People who have been here longer than a year will receive an increase, and the increases that we've been doing in terms of percentage, year-over-year percentage increases, have been in the neighborhood of 8% to 10%. So I expect that we'll continue that in 2016.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Stender with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Stender with Wells Fargo.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the full year acquisitions, it looks like occupancies were in the 85% range and rental rates were sub 13%. Can you give us a feel of what those numbers look like at the end of last year? And then I know you've made some acquisitions so far
componenttext: Just looking at the full year acquisitions, it looks like occupancies were in the 85% range and rental rates were sub 13%. Can you give us a feel of what those numbers look like at the end of last year? And then I know you've made some acquisitions so far this year, just where the fundamental trends are.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, Todd, what number are you referring to?
componenttext: I'm sorry, Todd, what number are you referring to?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: What are the occupancies -- what were the occupancies of the acquisitions you've made lately? And then rental rates, just seeing how far they can be pushed once you hold on them, that's where I'm going.
componenttext: What are the occupancies -- what were the occupancies of the acquisitions you've made lately? And then rental rates, just seeing how far they can be pushed once you hold on them, that's where I'm going.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, most of the acquisitions were, David, 80%, 85%, yes, 80%, 85%. We didn't -- I don't think we bought anything that's ground-up empty. We got one in Houston that was 0, Todd, that's a fill-up. But for the most part, they're somewhat stabilized pr
componenttext: Yes. Well, most of the acquisitions were, David, 80%, 85%, yes, 80%, 85%. We didn't -- I don't think we bought anything that's ground-up empty. We got one in Houston that was 0, Todd, that's a fill-up. But for the most part, they're somewhat stabilized properties, somewhere between 80%, 85%. Extrapolating what that's going to be versus what is in our press release, right, because the acquisitions, I'm looking at here, the annual contract rate of 15 06. That's probably not the way to go because the rate per foot is going to vary by market. So if you get a property in Ohio, you can have a very different rental rate than a property in New York. So you really can't take things and say, okay, everything is going to migrate to 15 06 a foot. Generally though, that once we get them stabilized and up into the platform, our ability to push rate is consistent with everything else we've said on the call, 6%, and then rental rate increases pretty much happens.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, Ron, and how long is that period for you to stabilize? According to your metrics, once you layer in tenant insurance and maybe too as concessions starts to slow down, what does that period look like?
componenttext: That's helpful, Ron, and how long is that period for you to stabilize? According to your metrics, once you layer in tenant insurance and maybe too as concessions starts to slow down, what does that period look like?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, operationally, in terms of fitting them into the system and operating them as a Public Storage property, that's usually 30 to 90 days. The real estate group is great at fixing the offices, rebranding the property. It goes into the system in terms of
componenttext: Well, operationally, in terms of fitting them into the system and operating them as a Public Storage property, that's usually 30 to 90 days. The real estate group is great at fixing the offices, rebranding the property. It goes into the system in terms of Internet marketing on the website, in the call center on day 1. So you can usually see quickly the impact on move-in volumes once it gets into our system. There's usually problems on delinquencies, so we have outflow. But generally, 6 months to a year, you get the thing stabilized, and then in the second year is when you start to see some meaningful growth. Recall, if you're going to lower rates and increase promotional discounts to fill it up, revenues generally going to not -- revenue growth is not going to be very strong in the first 6 months to a year.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of R.J. Milligan with Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of R.J. Milligan with Baird.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can give any color on the estimated development yields and redevelopment yields on the projects within your pipeline.
componenttext: I was wondering if you can give any color on the estimated development yields and redevelopment yields on the projects within your pipeline.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Development yields after an imputed absorption costs are going to be somewhere between 8% and 10%. On a cash-on-cash basis, no absorption, it's going to be 150 basis points higher than that. Developed -- redevelop -- so that's on the developments. The red
componenttext: Development yields after an imputed absorption costs are going to be somewhere between 8% and 10%. On a cash-on-cash basis, no absorption, it's going to be 150 basis points higher than that. Developed -- redevelop -- so that's on the developments. The redevelopments can go anywhere from 10% to 30%. And as I've said over and over again, redevelopments are great because it's low risk, you know the property, you're not paying for the land again. And I wish we could do $1 billion a year of those. But there's just not that much opportunity.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of those development yields, is there a difference between markets? Are there any markets where the development yields are much more attractive, and particularly at the high barrier-to-entry markets or what traditionally has been those high b
componenttext: And in terms of those development yields, is there a difference between markets? Are there any markets where the development yields are much more attractive, and particularly at the high barrier-to-entry markets or what traditionally has been those high barrier-to-entry markets? Are you seeing any difference in development yields regionally?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it -- yes, generally, the higher barrier-to-entry markets are where we're having greater competition for the land and we're having to pay up for the costs. So those yields tend to run a little lower than the lower barrier-to-entry markets. And the w
componenttext: Well, it -- yes, generally, the higher barrier-to-entry markets are where we're having greater competition for the land and we're having to pay up for the costs. So those yields tend to run a little lower than the lower barrier-to-entry markets. And the way we look at it is, okay, on a lower barrier-to-entry market, we need a higher yield because it probably won't grow as much as the high barrier-to-entry market.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the balance sheet, you guys have about $375 million of the Series Q preferred, so they're callable in April and almost $500 million of the Series R, they're callable in July. So I'm wondering what the plans are there?
componenttext: Just looking at the balance sheet, you guys have about $375 million of the Series Q preferred, so they're callable in April and almost $500 million of the Series R, they're callable in July. So I'm wondering what the plans are there?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, this is John. We have -- we don't have any definite plans at the moment, but I would say that it's pretty likely that we may call one or both of those series. But we haven't made that final decision yet on that, but I wouldn't put it past us from
componenttext: George, this is John. We have -- we don't have any definite plans at the moment, but I would say that it's pretty likely that we may call one or both of those series. But we haven't made that final decision yet on that, but I wouldn't put it past us from calling them.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And would you be more inclined to just refi it with more preferreds or would you include some unsecured debt?
componenttext: Okay. And would you be more inclined to just refi it with more preferreds or would you include some unsecured debt?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We could do both. We did a preferred in January, so we're sitting on cash which will cause a little dilution to our FFO in Q1. And that was a $300 million deal. I don't know whether the preferred market will be open throughout the remainder of 2016. We di
componenttext: We could do both. We did a preferred in January, so we're sitting on cash which will cause a little dilution to our FFO in Q1. And that was a $300 million deal. I don't know whether the preferred market will be open throughout the remainder of 2016. We did mention that we were looking at doing unsecured debt. That's still -- that is not off the table, it's still on the table. So we could do that also. So we'll wait and make the decision when we need to.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jordan Sadler here. Just a quick question regarding sort of appetite on the acquisition front. I know you've got some competition out there from some of the smaller competitors. But just curious, there were some that were -- seem like they'd be a lit
componenttext: It's Jordan Sadler here. Just a quick question regarding sort of appetite on the acquisition front. I know you've got some competition out there from some of the smaller competitors. But just curious, there were some that were -- seem like they'd be a little bit more in your wheelhouse geographically in L.A. that crossed recently. Curious if those were on your radar, if you had interest? And just maybe talk a little bit about your appetite?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jordan, good to hear from you. We have an appetite for acquisitions. We try to be disciplined in our approach. And the stuff in California, we looked at it. It's pretty good product. We just couldn't get our heads around, I think that went from about clos
componenttext: Jordan, good to hear from you. We have an appetite for acquisitions. We try to be disciplined in our approach. And the stuff in California, we looked at it. It's pretty good product. We just couldn't get our heads around, I think that went from about close to 300 a foot and we just couldn't get there in terms of that kind of pricing. So -- but it's good product, it's fine.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on a separate but similar note, when you guys make acquisitions, I know you give some pretty good disclosure on this, but I'm just curious in terms of breaking your acquisitions from prior years out separately rather than including them in
componenttext: Okay. And then on a separate but similar note, when you guys make acquisitions, I know you give some pretty good disclosure on this, but I'm just curious in terms of breaking your acquisitions from prior years out separately rather than including them in the -- in your same-store portfolio. But what do you view as sort of the potential uplift in terms of buying something from a private operator, you buy something that's maybe not fully stabilized but what maybe a private guy would call somewhat stabilized, what are you able to sort of pick up in incremental yield on those acquisitions over sort of a 1- to 2-year time frame?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jordan, that depends on a lot about of variable factors. Generally, we try to underwrite where we think there's -- I'd say, on average, where 150, 200 basis points uptick in terms of NOI over 12 to 18 months. One of the things that we overcome in ac
componenttext: Well, Jordan, that depends on a lot about of variable factors. Generally, we try to underwrite where we think there's -- I'd say, on average, where 150, 200 basis points uptick in terms of NOI over 12 to 18 months. One of the things that we overcome in acquisitions is property tax reassessments. So whereas an operator may have had the property for 20 years, he's got a low tax basis. We buy it, now we've got a big tax bill. So you got to kind of make that up in your NOI, in your growth rate. But generally, 150 to 200 basis points. The stuff we bought in '13 and prior and even '14 is performing better than we anticipated because the industry fundamentals are better than anticipated. We underwrite things on today's rents in that marketplace. We don't do a forward forecast of what we think rents might be 2 or 3 years out. And so the fact that the operating fundamentals in the marketplace across most of the U.S. have been very good in the last 24 months has helped us outperform our own expectations in terms of our last couple of years' acquisitions as well as our developments. Our developments are performing across the board better than we anticipated.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then Todd has one on demand. I know you know that business a little bit.
componenttext: That's helpful. And then Todd has one on demand. I know you know that business a little bit.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just quickly. A number of those on demand storage services that are operating in a few of the major metros, are you seeing any impact from them in some of your markets? Any competition or anything that you can comment on?
componenttext: Just quickly. A number of those on demand storage services that are operating in a few of the major metros, are you seeing any impact from them in some of your markets? Any competition or anything that you can comment on?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, at record occupancies, I would say, no. The Bay Area, where a lot of that tech stuff -- we know of a couple things up there that are going on, no impact. I mean, we are chock-full in the Bay Area.
componenttext: Well, at record occupancies, I would say, no. The Bay Area, where a lot of that tech stuff -- we know of a couple things up there that are going on, no impact. I mean, we are chock-full in the Bay Area.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.

componenttext: Can you provide an update on the development in Glendale? How's that leasing so far?

componenttext: 85% or 90%. It's full.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And what type of yield did you get on that? I guess it looks like it's vastly exceeding underwriting.
componenttext: Okay. And what type of yield did you get on that? I guess it looks like it's vastly exceeding underwriting.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It will. It has not been open a year. So taking the last 10 months of income is not indicative of what that income is going to be over the next 12 months. But I think we underwrote it with a 3-year fill-up. I think as a pretty good private property, even
componenttext: It will. It has not been open a year. So taking the last 10 months of income is not indicative of what that income is going to be over the next 12 months. But I think we underwrote it with a 3-year fill-up. I think as a pretty good private property, even a little bit longer than that. And so it's far exceeded our expectations. And the other thing about that fill-up on the property is we do not have to discount rates. It's heavily -- to get it filled up is what we normally do on a typical development. So it's a home run.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when you look at acquisitions, how far off are you on the final price for a deal? How clear is that? And then with the cost of preferred coming down and cost of that will be coming down, will more deals make sense now versus, I'd say, last
componenttext: Okay. And then when you look at acquisitions, how far off are you on the final price for a deal? How clear is that? And then with the cost of preferred coming down and cost of that will be coming down, will more deals make sense now versus, I'd say, last year?

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry. I didn't understand the first part of your question, Wes.
componenttext: I'm sorry. I didn't understand the first part of your question, Wes.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes. So how far off are you when you look at an acquisition you said you're missing on pricing? Are you like 5% away from the final price? Or is it like 10% to 15%? I'm just wondering if the improved cost of equity, cost of preferred equity, will he
componenttext: Okay. Yes. So how far off are you when you look at an acquisition you said you're missing on pricing? Are you like 5% away from the final price? Or is it like 10% to 15%? I'm just wondering if the improved cost of equity, cost of preferred equity, will help you pencil more deals in this year.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, yes, there's 2 things. It's both yield and then price per foot. Because we have a development platform, we know about what these things cost to build. And so even though the yield may kind of fit the current cost of capital, and you can get --
componenttext: Yes. Well, yes, there's 2 things. It's both yield and then price per foot. Because we have a development platform, we know about what these things cost to build. And so even though the yield may kind of fit the current cost of capital, and you can get -- in terms of cost of capital, you can get really creative and say, well, our line cost is less than 1%, so why don't we use that in terms of underwriting acquisitions, which we don't. But when we're looking at L.A. properties at 300 a foot and we're building in L.A. at 150, 160 a foot, we're just not going to pay 300 a foot.

headline: Public Storage, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
