headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Jackie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the confere
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Jackie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Clem Teng to begin.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes. Before we begin, I want to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of historical facts include
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes. 
Before we begin, I want to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, April 27, 2016, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A reconciliation to GAAP with the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC report and an audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
Now I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem, and welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter here in Q1, so I'd like to open it up for questions.
componenttext: Thank you, Clem, and welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter here in Q1, so I'd like to open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Glenn Clark with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Glenn Clark with Evercore ISI.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I realize this information will be available in the 10-Q but since that data won't be up for a few days, can you give us some color on the operating performance within your largest metros?
componenttext: So I realize this information will be available in the 10-Q but since that data won't be up for a few days, can you give us some color on the operating performance within your largest metros?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gwen, this is John. I can kind of run through some of those. So Los Angeles, which is, by far, our largest market, revenues were up about 8.2%. San Francisco, just a second, I'll just give you our top 10. San Francisco is up 7.8%; New York, 4.6%; Chi
componenttext: Yes, Gwen, this is John. I can kind of run through some of those. So Los Angeles, which is, by far, our largest market, revenues were up about 8.2%. San Francisco, just a second, I'll just give you our top 10. San Francisco is up 7.8%; New York, 4.6%; Chicago, 2.4%; Seattle, 8.4%; Washington D.C., 2.6%; Miami, 6%; Dallas-Fort Worth, 8.9%; Houston, 5.2%; and Atlanta is 7.8%.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And I guess on that note, seems like Chicago and DC were the definite underperformers. Can you just talk about what you think was driving that?
componenttext: Thank you. And I guess on that note, seems like Chicago and DC were the definite underperformers. Can you just talk about what you think was driving that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, DC has been an underperformer for us for several years actually. We've struggled with DC. I think that's mostly competition. With respect to Chicago, that's more of a recent phenomenon. Don't really know exactly what's going on in Chicago. It's been
componenttext: Well, DC has been an underperformer for us for several years actually. We've struggled with DC. I think that's mostly competition. With respect to Chicago, that's more of a recent phenomenon. Don't really know exactly what's going on in Chicago. It's been a struggle for us throughout the markets so it's not just any particular part of the market. So I really can't tell. I think we're keeping our occupancy there but we're lacking pricing power. So we'll just keep working on that and see if we could improve it soon.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you do get the Q, 10-Q, you will see that Chicago's NOI was up almost 11%, and that's not due to operating fundamentals, that's due to less snow than last year.
componenttext: When you do get the Q, 10-Q, you will see that Chicago's NOI was up almost 11%, and that's not due to operating fundamentals, that's due to less snow than last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose with Citigroup.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask your about your acquisition activity, which looks like it's picked up year-to-date, and I think is now in excess of what you did for the entire year in '15. And I just was curious, are you seeing more products come to market? Or are you ch
componenttext: I wanted to ask your about your acquisition activity, which looks like it's picked up year-to-date, and I think is now in excess of what you did for the entire year in '15. And I just was curious, are you seeing more products come to market? Or are you changing what you're looking for in some of the acquisitions you're making? Or is there any some of it that's driving that increased volume there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Smedes, it's Ron. We've not changed our criteria at all, but I would summarize the market for acquisitions has more product, lower quality, higher prices.
componenttext: Smedes, it's Ron. We've not changed our criteria at all, but I would summarize the market for acquisitions has more product, lower quality, higher prices.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. More products, higher prices and lower quality?
componenttext: Okay. More products, higher prices and lower quality?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But -- so within all of that, you're still able to find stuff that you like?
componenttext: Okay. But -- so within all of that, you're still able to find stuff that you like?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The broad market as a whole. Inside that are some good products, some reasonably priced so we're able to do some transactions here and there. But historically, we tend to do what makes sense for the franchise, what makes sense for the platform, what makes
componenttext: The broad market as a whole. Inside that are some good products, some reasonably priced so we're able to do some transactions here and there. But historically, we tend to do what makes sense for the franchise, what makes sense for the platform, what makes sense on a price per foot. It varies by market. And that strategy's not changed. It's consistent. We continue to build out the platform in the markets where we are, both submarkets as well as markets in general. So nothing has changed in terms of strategy, but we are seeing, given the robust pricing, more product coming to market and I would say overall, lower quality. David Doll is here, so David, would you have anything to add to that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think [indiscernible] what we're seeing a little more activity is we've got a team out looking for some of those one-off, off-marketed properties that can fill in some of our [indiscernible] as Ron suggested markets where we're trying to build out s
componenttext: No, I think [indiscernible] what we're seeing a little more activity is we've got a team out looking for some of those one-off, off-marketed properties that can fill in some of our [indiscernible] as Ron suggested markets where we're trying to build out scale.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. So I mean, so just Ron, when you say higher prices, I mean, can you maybe just generally just quantify like how much cap rates have declined in the last say year or quarter or however you're going to measure it just get a sense of the pace
componenttext: That's helpful. So I mean, so just Ron, when you say higher prices, I mean, can you maybe just generally just quantify like how much cap rates have declined in the last say year or quarter or however you're going to measure it just get a sense of the pace of price increases of what folks are asking?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: My guess would be everyone measures cap rates different, Smedes, right, they include tenant insurance our retail or don't include certain operating expenses. So it's a little hard to say in terms of the way we underwrite and what we're seeing out there, I
componenttext: My guess would be everyone measures cap rates different, Smedes, right, they include tenant insurance our retail or don't include certain operating expenses. So it's a little hard to say in terms of the way we underwrite and what we're seeing out there, I'd say 50 to 75 basis points at least, David, for...

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: 1.5x to 2x replacement cost.
componenttext: 1.5x to 2x replacement cost.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jana Galan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jana Galan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk to the decision to grow the development pipeline and maybe comment on land prices and construction costs.
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk to the decision to grow the development pipeline and maybe comment on land prices and construction costs.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the decision to grow the development pipeline or grow -- enter development started about 3 -- in earnest, about 3 years ago. And we started doing that in part because we couldn't find product in markets or submarkets where we wanted to build out our
componenttext: Well, the decision to grow the development pipeline or grow -- enter development started about 3 -- in earnest, about 3 years ago. And we started doing that in part because we couldn't find product in markets or submarkets where we wanted to build out our franchise, build out our platform. And two, we saw the continued escalation of prices of acquisitions, which previous question I just answered just kind of come to bear and has been for the last 12 to 18 months. So pricing when acquisitions was making and get a new product in markets where we didn't have existing product is the rationale for the development platform. And to the team's credit, this quarter, we ended with $600 million in the pipeline, which is a new record for us. And most of that, about 2/3 of that, $300 million, $350 million  will be delivered this year, which is also fantastic. In terms of construction costs, land cost, David?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So construction costs, across the country, there's different markets where we're seeing acceleration of costs mostly due to labor shortage or subcontractor coverage, markets like the Bay Area, Miami and smaller markets like Phoenix and Denver, we're start
componenttext: So construction costs, across the country, there's different markets where we're seeing acceleration of costs mostly due to labor shortage or subcontractor coverage, markets like the Bay Area, Miami and smaller markets like Phoenix and Denver, we're starting to see some pressure on construction cost. Land prices generally, I'd say a factor of availability. And so in those key markets where availability is becoming more and more difficult, then we begin to focus our efforts on redevelopment. And in most of those markets, we've got a great portfolio of assets that can be redeveloped on our existing real estate. So the team has to be nimble in terms of where those opportunities exist and how they could execute it.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I believe last quarter, you identified overall supply, maybe about 1,200 self-storage facilities in some stage of development. I was curious if you had an update on that number.
componenttext: And I believe last quarter, you identified overall supply, maybe about 1,200 self-storage facilities in some stage of development. I was curious if you had an update on that number.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I've been pretty close to -- between 800 and 1,000. And that -- nothing's really changed. My guess though is it's accelerating, so as we go through the year, that probably number will accelerate. The number of people entertaining development,
componenttext: Yes, I think I've been pretty close to -- between 800 and 1,000. And that -- nothing's really changed. My guess though is it's accelerating, so as we go through the year, that probably number will accelerate. The number of people entertaining development, trying to get their arms around it or undertaking it continues to grow.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeremy Metz on with Ross. John, I was just wondering if you could talk about what you're seeing on the rent front, given the maturity of the portfolio and close to max occupancy. It does seem like you guys are still able to get some good traction pushing
componenttext: Jeremy Metz on with Ross. John, I was just wondering if you could talk about what you're seeing on the rent front, given the maturity of the portfolio and close to max occupancy. It does seem like you guys are still able to get some good traction pushing rents in the market continues to bear. So any color on street rates, where they trended during the quarter and maybe that spread between move-in and move-outs.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that the street rates during the quarter were up about 5%. The take rate on our movements, which were movements were about up 1% during the quarter, and they were moving in at rates that were about 4% higher than last year. The move-out r
componenttext: Yes, I would say that the street rates during the quarter were up about 5%. The take rate on our movements, which were movements were about up 1% during the quarter, and they were moving in at rates that were about 4% higher than last year. The move-out rates, that were up 5.6% year-over-year. So just to give you a flavor of the take rate, the move-in rate was average on a per unit basis about $124 versus the move-out rate of about $135 was about probably about $11 difference there. And that compares to last year at about $119 move-in versus $128 move-out.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pretty similar. And then just one on you had a pretty good bump on the late charges and admin fees this quarter. Just wondering is that more late fee-driven and assuming you'd be willing to provide it or get able to say what can of percentage of the portf
componenttext: Pretty similar. And then just one on you had a pretty good bump on the late charges and admin fees this quarter. Just wondering is that more late fee-driven and assuming you'd be willing to provide it or get able to say what can of percentage of the portfolio is [indiscernible] at this point and has that increased at all really?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, with respect to delinquencies, we're close to we're at record low delinquencies. So the uptick, it's admin fees, the [indiscernible] these haven't changed it's all in admin fees. We bumped those little bit last year, and so on a year-over-year basis
componenttext: Well, with respect to delinquencies, we're close to we're at record low delinquencies. So the uptick, it's admin fees, the [indiscernible] these haven't changed it's all in admin fees. We bumped those little bit last year, and so on a year-over-year basis, they're higher. Plus as John noted, you've got about 1%, 1.5% increase in move-ins.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I think Ross has one quick one.
componenttext: Okay. And I think Ross has one quick one.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Your occupancy at the end of March was flat year-over-year. Do you have an update on where you are here at the end of April?
componenttext: Yes. Your occupancy at the end of March was flat year-over-year. Do you have an update on where you are here at the end of April?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have an update. As of yesterday, we were up about 11 basis points.
componenttext: I have an update. As of yesterday, we were up about 11 basis points.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Ron, given your comments on where the transaction market is with lower quality and higher pricing, have you thought about putting some of your "lower quality, noncore smaller market assets" up for sale and using that as a source of developm
componenttext: Okay. And then Ron, given your comments on where the transaction market is with lower quality and higher pricing, have you thought about putting some of your "lower quality, noncore smaller market assets" up for sale and using that as a source of development funding?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have thought about that, Ross. We continue to think about that. In terms of needing that as capital for development, we have plenty of firepower here on the balance sheet to undertake our development program. Keep in mind, $300 million to $400 mi
componenttext: Well, we have thought about that, Ross. We continue to think about that. In terms of needing that as capital for development, we have plenty of firepower here on the balance sheet to undertake our development program. Keep in mind, $300 million to $400 million, call it $350 million a year, of routine cash flow goes a long ways towards funding the development program. That's about what our spend will be this year. So it's -- this level of development we're basically taking retained cash flow and underwriting the development program. To your first question, yes, we are -- we continue to look at maybe peeling off some markets where we don't want to grow in and we don't have much of a presence.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, just following up on new supply. Curious to get your readover whether there are any markets where you think that there's some real overbuilding taking place that you're watching carefully or where you may be a little cautious over the next year or so
componenttext: Ron, just following up on new supply. Curious to get your readover whether there are any markets where you think that there's some real overbuilding taking place that you're watching carefully or where you may be a little cautious over the next year or so.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2 markets that come to mind, Todd. One is the in boroughs New York. We have -- we don't have anything in the boroughs per se, well, we got one on Long Island and we've got one over in Jersey City but that's it. But just looking at the deals of the other p
componenttext: 2 markets that come to mind, Todd. One is the in boroughs New York. We have -- we don't have anything in the boroughs per se, well, we got one on Long Island and we've got one over in Jersey City but that's it. But just looking at the deals of the other public competitors as well as what we know is going on, the boroughs seem to have materially above-average level of development and high proportion of existing supply coming in. The other is Denver where we've been told there's 40 to 50 properties on the board or about to be developed in that market, which is a big number for that size a market. We're developing quite a bit in Dallas. We -- where we are developing North Dallas, we're not seeing a lot of new competitors. Down in Houston, we've seen some uptick in Houston that nothing relative to the size -- in terms of size of market, nothing, from our perspective, to be concerned about at this juncture.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the lease-up cycles for new development, they were taking place at of much, much faster pace for quite some time. Has that changed at all with some of the new deliveries or is absorption taking place at pretty much the same pace?
componenttext: And then the lease-up cycles for new development, they were taking place at of much, much faster pace for quite some time. Has that changed at all with some of the new deliveries or is absorption taking place at pretty much the same pace?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're pretty much ahead across the board in terms of our filling up faster ahead of pro forma. So that process continues. The fundamentals of the business are great. Our customer acquisition costs were down again this quarter. We brought in more custo
componenttext: No, we're pretty much ahead across the board in terms of our filling up faster ahead of pro forma. So that process continues. The fundamentals of the business are great. Our customer acquisition costs were down again this quarter. We brought in more customers at lower cost and higher rates. So the fundamentals of the business continue to be just excellent. And that's playing into fortunately our development platform as well.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could talk about overall operating expenses. In 1Q, you guys benefited from lower snow renewable costs. But as far as trends going into the rest of the year, are there any areas where we could see some savings that would keep costs l
componenttext: Just wondering if you could talk about overall operating expenses. In 1Q, you guys benefited from lower snow renewable costs. But as far as trends going into the rest of the year, are there any areas where we could see some savings that would keep costs lower? I mean, I would assume you guys won't be expecting a negative -- another negative quarter of year-over-year costs. But what else could -- where could we see some savings in?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, I don't recall what Q2 snow removal costs were last year. I'm sure we had some. It was a pretty tough winter last year so there may be some minor positive expense snow R&M next year. Most of the other expenses, as I always say, I would count on 2%
componenttext: George, I don't recall what Q2 snow removal costs were last year. I'm sure we had some. It was a pretty tough winter last year so there may be some minor positive expense snow R&M next year. Most of the other expenses, as I always say, I would count on 2% to 3% property taxes. We've got them running at 4.5%. That's -- we don't see that changing much. So my -- if I were modeling, I'd model 2% to 3%.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a follow-up on a previous question. You guys gave April occupancy stats. I was wondering if you could provide contract rate, what that looks like in April or move-in rates, whichever you think is more useful.
componenttext: So just a follow-up on a previous question. You guys gave April occupancy stats. I was wondering if you could provide contract rate, what that looks like in April or move-in rates, whichever you think is more useful.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't usually provide that. I think -- but I don't think there's any trend different in April than what John mentioned in the first quarter in terms of move-in rates and move-out rates and street rates versus take rates.
componenttext: We don't usually provide that. I think -- but I don't think there's any trend different in April than what John mentioned in the first quarter in terms of move-in rates and move-out rates and street rates versus take rates.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess just broader, is this spring leasing season generally behaving the same way the previous couple of years spring leasing seasons have behaved in terms of you guys being able to push the take-in rate or contract rate year-over-year much harder in
componenttext: So I guess just broader, is this spring leasing season generally behaving the same way the previous couple of years spring leasing seasons have behaved in terms of you guys being able to push the take-in rate or contract rate year-over-year much harder in the springtime versus like the winter times?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ki, this is John. Yes, it is -- you've seen that sequential push. I think that the difficulty for us in Q2 is a comp compared to last year where we had an exceptional Q2 last year that was surprising to us about how much demand came in and our ability to
componenttext: Ki, this is John. Yes, it is -- you've seen that sequential push. I think that the difficulty for us in Q2 is a comp compared to last year where we had an exceptional Q2 last year that was surprising to us about how much demand came in and our ability to continue to push rates. So we're comping against that. But the trend lines are still the same, but it is a tougher comp for Q2 this year than we experienced historically.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, any color on Europe? Can you just give us a quick rundown of what you're seeing over there?
componenttext: I was wondering, any color on Europe? Can you just give us a quick rundown of what you're seeing over there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. Europe, let's see. Occupancies for the quarter were 89.8% versus 88.1% so up 1.9%. Realized rents were up 3.1% so overall REVPAF growth was 5.2% for the quarter. Expenses were only up 2.9% [ph] so we had 6.7% NOI growth across Europe. So the t
componenttext: Sure, Mike. Europe, let's see. Occupancies for the quarter were 89.8% versus 88.1% so up 1.9%. Realized rents were up 3.1% so overall REVPAF growth was 5.2% for the quarter. Expenses were only up 2.9% [ph] so we had 6.7% NOI growth across Europe. So the team is doing a great job over there. Every market was up in terms of NOI being led by Sweden at 16.2%. The laggard was Germany at 0.8%.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just in terms of investment activity over there, what's going on in terms of development or anything on the acquisition side?
componenttext: Got it. And just in terms of investment activity over there, what's going on in terms of development or anything on the acquisition side?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We opened up 3 new properties in London in the back half of last year. We've got a couple more that we're undertaking this year. We're trying to get things started in Berlin. So that's on the development side. Nothing at this juncture in terms of acquisit
componenttext: We opened up 3 new properties in London in the back half of last year. We've got a couple more that we're undertaking this year. We're trying to get things started in Berlin. So that's on the development side. Nothing at this juncture in terms of acquisitions.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Belcher with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Belcher with Wells Fargo.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Wondering if you can give us some of the operating metrics for the assets that you acquired in the quarter as well as those already acquired so far in Q2. Will be particularly interested in any color you can share on the occupancy rates in place versus market rents and cap rates.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, I don't have the occupancies or any of that stuff on the acquisitions here with me. They're generally somewhere between 70% and 85% occupied. In terms of price per foot, the we're about $110, $120 a foot. It varies by market.
componenttext: Jason, I don't have the occupancies or any of that stuff on the acquisitions here with me. They're generally somewhere between 70% and 85% occupied. In terms of price per foot, the we're about $110, $120 a foot. It varies by market.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just on the preferred you issued in January, I think it was a 5.4% coupon. Wondering where you think you might issue that now.

componenttext: Lower.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at Europe, how are the barriers to entry in that market from a development side? Is it difficult to permit, finance relative to say, a core West Coast market such as San Francisco and Los Angeles?
componenttext: Looking at Europe, how are the barriers to entry in that market from a development side? Is it difficult to permit, finance relative to say, a core West Coast market such as San Francisco and Los Angeles?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, London and Paris. First of all, those are big markets. I assume you're talking about the major metro centers, London, Paris, Berlin?
componenttext: Well, London and Paris. First of all, those are big markets. I assume you're talking about the major metro centers, London, Paris, Berlin?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they're just like Los Angeles or San Francisco or Manhattan. I mean, you've got core -- the core markets, the inner ring in Paris downtown near Buckingham Palace is central part of London. First of all, you can't get zoning. Second of all, if you [in
componenttext: Yes, they're just like Los Angeles or San Francisco or Manhattan. I mean, you've got core -- the core markets, the inner ring in Paris downtown near Buckingham Palace is central part of London. First of all, you can't get zoning. Second of all, if you [indiscernible] land for sale, it's incredibly expensive probably doesn't make sense. So it's equally as tough. And the sites we've done in London are -- they've not been easy in terms of getting the zoning. And same challenges that you face here where the markets where you really, really want to be in and there's no competition, it's really hard or there's no zoning.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when you go over to markets such as Europe, is your platform -- we always talk about your platform in the U.S. as being much better than some of the small mom-and-pops. Do you have that same advantage when you go over to Europe? And can you
componenttext: Okay. And then when you go over to markets such as Europe, is your platform -- we always talk about your platform in the U.S. as being much better than some of the small mom-and-pops. Do you have that same advantage when you go over to Europe? And can you consolidate anything over there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, you got to keep in mind, in all of Western Europe and again, this is best guess statistics, somewhere between 1,500 and 1,800 facilities in all of Western Europe including Great Britain, over half of which are in Great Britain. So the product t
componenttext: Yes. Well, you got to keep in mind, in all of Western Europe and again, this is best guess statistics, somewhere between 1,500 and 1,800 facilities in all of Western Europe including Great Britain, over half of which are in Great Britain. So the product that's available across the continent is pretty thin. There's not a lot of -- I think in Berlin, there's 10, 12 facilities in all of Berlin. So there's not a lot to buy. And the product is, on average, I'd say much lower quality than U.S. because a lot of it was not purpose-built. A lot of it was converted office, converted garages, converted industrial buildings. And it takes a variety of shapes and sizes. So not a lot of purpose-built product in Europe, not a lot of product to even buy. And most the product is over in Great Britain and a lot of it outside London.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: There appear to be no further questions at this time. I'd like to turn the floor back over to Clem Teng for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Jackie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Clem Teng to begin.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes. Before we begin, I want to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of historical facts include
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes. 
Before we begin, I want to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, April 27, 2016, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A reconciliation to GAAP with the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC report and an audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com. And I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem, and welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter here in Q1. So I'd like to open it up for questions.
componenttext: Thank you, Clem, and welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter here in Q1. So I'd like to open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Gwen Clark with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Gwen Clark with Evercore ISI.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I realize this information will be available in the 10-Q. But since that data won't be up for a few days, can you give us some color on the operating performance within your largest metros?
componenttext: So I realize this information will be available in the 10-Q. But since that data won't be up for a few days, can you give us some color on the operating performance within your largest metros?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gwen, this is John. I can kind of run through some of those. So Los Angeles, which is, by far, our largest market, revenues were up about 8.2%. San Francisco -- just a second, I'll just give you our top 10. San Francisco is up 7.8%; New York, 4.6%; C
componenttext: Yes, Gwen, this is John. I can kind of run through some of those. So Los Angeles, which is, by far, our largest market, revenues were up about 8.2%. San Francisco -- just a second, I'll just give you our top 10. San Francisco is up 7.8%; New York, 4.6%; Chicago, 2.4%; Seattle, 8.4%; Washington, D.C., 2.6%; Miami, 6%; Dallas-Fort Worth, 8.9%; Houston, 5.2%; and Atlanta, 7.8%.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess on that note, it seems like Chicago and D.C. were the definite underperformers. Can you just talk about what you think was driving that?
componenttext: And I guess on that note, it seems like Chicago and D.C. were the definite underperformers. Can you just talk about what you think was driving that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, D.C. has been an underperformer for us. For several years actually, we've struggled with D.C. I think that's mostly competition. With respect to Chicago, that's more of a recent phenomenon. I don't really know exactly what's going on in Chicago. It'
componenttext: Well, D.C. has been an underperformer for us. For several years actually, we've struggled with D.C. I think that's mostly competition. With respect to Chicago, that's more of a recent phenomenon. I don't really know exactly what's going on in Chicago. It's been a struggle for us throughout the market, so it's not just any particular part of the market. So I really can't tell. I think we're keeping our occupancy there, but we're lacking pricing power. So I guess we'll just keep working on that and see if we can improve it soon.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gwen, when you do get the Q, 10-Q, you will see that actually Chicago's NOI was up almost 11%. And that's not due to operating fundamentals, that's due to less snow than last year.
componenttext: Gwen, when you do get the Q, 10-Q, you will see that actually Chicago's NOI was up almost 11%. And that's not due to operating fundamentals, that's due to less snow than last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose with Citigroup.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about your acquisition activity, which looks like it's picked up year-to-date and I think is now in excess of what you did for an entire year in '15. And I just was curious, are you seeing more products come to market? Or are you chang
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about your acquisition activity, which looks like it's picked up year-to-date and I think is now in excess of what you did for an entire year in '15. And I just was curious, are you seeing more products come to market? Or are you changing what you're looking for in some of the acquisitions you're making? Or is there any -- some of it that's driving that increased volume there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Smedes, this is Ron. We've not changed our criteria at all. But I would summarize the market for acquisitions has more product, lower quality, higher prices.
componenttext: Smedes, this is Ron. We've not changed our criteria at all. But I would summarize the market for acquisitions has more product, lower quality, higher prices.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. More products, higher prices and lower quality.
componenttext: Okay. More products, higher prices and lower quality.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So within all of that, you're still able to find stuff that you like?
componenttext: Okay. So within all of that, you're still able to find stuff that you like?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] the broad market as a whole. Inside that are some good products, some reasonably priced, so we're able to do some transactions here and there. But historically, we tend to do what makes sense for the franchise, what makes sense for the pla
componenttext: [indiscernible] the broad market as a whole. Inside that are some good products, some reasonably priced, so we're able to do some transactions here and there. But historically, we tend to do what makes sense for the franchise, what makes sense for the platform, what makes sense on a price per foot. It varies by market. And that strategy has not changed, it's consistent. We continue to build out the platform in the markets where we are, both submarkets as well as markets in general. So nothing has changed in terms of strategy. But we are seeing, given the robust pricing, more product coming to market and I would say overall, lower quality. David Doll is here. So David, would you have anything to add to that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think the only reason that we're seeing a little more activity is we've got a team out looking for some of those one-off and off-marketed properties that can fill in some of our -- as Ron suggested, markets where we're trying to build out scale.
componenttext: No, I think the only reason that we're seeing a little more activity is we've got a team out looking for some of those one-off and off-marketed properties that can fill in some of our -- as Ron suggested, markets where we're trying to build out scale.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. I mean, so just, Ron, when you say higher prices, I mean, can you maybe just generally just quantify like how much cap rates have declined in the last, say, year or quarter or however you kind of measure it, just to get a sense of the pace
componenttext: That's helpful. I mean, so just, Ron, when you say higher prices, I mean, can you maybe just generally just quantify like how much cap rates have declined in the last, say, year or quarter or however you kind of measure it, just to get a sense of the pace of price increases of what folks are asking?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, my guess would be -- and everyone measures cap rates different, Smedes, right? They include tenant insurance or retail or don't include certain operating expenses. So it's a little hard to say. In terms of the way we underwrite and what we're seeing
componenttext: Well, my guess would be -- and everyone measures cap rates different, Smedes, right? They include tenant insurance or retail or don't include certain operating expenses. So it's a little hard to say. In terms of the way we underwrite and what we're seeing out there, I'd say 50 to 75 basis points at least, David?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Or 1.5 to 2x replacement cost.
componenttext: Or 1.5 to 2x replacement cost.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jana Galan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jana Galan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk to the decision to grow the development pipeline and maybe comment on land prices and construction costs.
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk to the decision to grow the development pipeline and maybe comment on land prices and construction costs.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the decision to grow the development pipeline or grow into development started about 3 -- in earnest, about 3 years ago. And we started doing that in part because we couldn't find product in markets or submarkets where we wanted to build out our fra
componenttext: Well, the decision to grow the development pipeline or grow into development started about 3 -- in earnest, about 3 years ago. And we started doing that in part because we couldn't find product in markets or submarkets where we wanted to build out our franchise, build out our platform. And two, we saw the continued escalation of prices of acquisitions, which previous question I just answered just kind of come to bear and has been for the last 12 to 18 months. So the pricing on acquisitions was making sense, and then getting new product in markets where we didn't have existing product is the rationale for the development platform. And to the team's credit, this quarter, we ended with $600 million in the pipeline, which is a new record for us. And most of that, about 2/3 of that, $300 million, $350 million, will be delivered this year, which is also fantastic. In terms of construction costs, land costs, David?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So construction costs, across the country, there's different markets where we're seeing acceleration of costs, mostly due to labor shortage or subcontractor coverage, markets like the Bay Area, Miami and smaller markets like Phoenix and Denver, we're star
componenttext: So construction costs, across the country, there's different markets where we're seeing acceleration of costs, mostly due to labor shortage or subcontractor coverage, markets like the Bay Area, Miami and smaller markets like Phoenix and Denver, we're starting to see some pressure on construction cost. Land prices generally, it's a factor of availability. And so in those key markets where availability is becoming more and more difficult, then we begin to focus our efforts on redevelopment. And in most of those markets, we've got a great portfolio of assets that can be redeveloped on our existing real estate. So the team has to be nimble in terms of where those opportunities exist and how they could execute it.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I believe last quarter, you identified overall supply, maybe about 1,200 self-storage facilities in some stage of development. I was curious if you had an update on that number.
componenttext: And I believe last quarter, you identified overall supply, maybe about 1,200 self-storage facilities in some stage of development. I was curious if you had an update on that number.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I've been pretty close to -- between 800 and 1,000. And that -- nothing's really changed. My guess though is it's accelerating. So as we go through the year that probably -- number will accelerate. The number of people entertaining developmen
componenttext: Yes, I think I've been pretty close to -- between 800 and 1,000. And that -- nothing's really changed. My guess though is it's accelerating. So as we go through the year that probably -- number will accelerate. The number of people entertaining development, trying to get their arms around it or undertaking it continues to grow.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeremy Metz on with Ross. John, I was just wondering if you could talk about what you're seeing on the rent front, given the maturity of the portfolio and close to max-out occupancy. It does seem like you guys are still able to get some good traction push
componenttext: Jeremy Metz on with Ross. John, I was just wondering if you could talk about what you're seeing on the rent front, given the maturity of the portfolio and close to max-out occupancy. It does seem like you guys are still able to get some good traction pushing rents and the market continues to bear it. So any color on street rates, where they trended during the quarter and maybe that spread between move-in and move-outs?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that the street rates during the quarter were up about 5%. The take rate on our move-ins, which our move-ins were about up 1% during the quarter, and they were moving in at rates that were about 4% higher than last year. The move-out rate
componenttext: Yes, I would say that the street rates during the quarter were up about 5%. The take rate on our move-ins, which our move-ins were about up 1% during the quarter, and they were moving in at rates that were about 4% higher than last year. The move-out rates, that were up 5.6% year-over-year. And just to give you a flavor of the take rate, the move-in rate was, average on a per unit basis, about $124 versus the move-out rate of about $135. So it was about probably about $11 difference there. And that compares to last year at about $119 move-in versus $128 move-out.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so pretty similar. And then just one on -- you had a pretty good bump on the late charges and admin fees this quarter. I was just wondering, is that more late fee-driven? And assuming you'd even be willing to provide it, are you able to say what kin
componenttext: Okay, so pretty similar. And then just one on -- you had a pretty good bump on the late charges and admin fees this quarter. I was just wondering, is that more late fee-driven? And assuming you'd even be willing to provide it, are you able to say what kind of percentage of the portfolio is in arrears at this point? And has that increased at all lately?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, with respect to delinquencies, we're close to or at record low delinquencies. So the uptick, it's late fees and admin fees. The late fees haven't changed, it's all in admin fees. We bumped those a little bit last year. And so on a year-over-year bas
componenttext: Well, with respect to delinquencies, we're close to or at record low delinquencies. So the uptick, it's late fees and admin fees. The late fees haven't changed, it's all in admin fees. We bumped those a little bit last year. And so on a year-over-year basis, they're higher. Plus as John noted, you've got about 1%, 1.5% increase in move-ins.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I think Ross has one quick one.
componenttext: Okay. And I think Ross has one quick one.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Your occupancy at the end of March was flat year-over-year. Do you have an update on where you are here at the end of April?
componenttext: Yes. Your occupancy at the end of March was flat year-over-year. Do you have an update on where you are here at the end of April?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have an update. Yes, as of yesterday, we were up about 11 basis points.
componenttext: I have an update. Yes, as of yesterday, we were up about 11 basis points.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Ron, given your comments on where the transaction market is with lower quality and higher pricing, have you thought about putting some of your "lower-quality, noncore, smaller market assets" up for sale and using that as a source of develop
componenttext: Okay. And then Ron, given your comments on where the transaction market is with lower quality and higher pricing, have you thought about putting some of your "lower-quality, noncore, smaller market assets" up for sale and using that as a source of development funding?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have thought about that, Ross, and we continue to think about that. In terms of needing that as capital for development, we have plenty of firepower here on the balance sheet to undertake our development program. Keep in mind, $300 million to $40
componenttext: Well, we have thought about that, Ross, and we continue to think about that. In terms of needing that as capital for development, we have plenty of firepower here on the balance sheet to undertake our development program. Keep in mind, $300 million to $400 million, call it, $350 million a year, of retained cash flow goes a long ways towards funding the development program. That's about what our spend will be this year. So it's basically -- at this level of development, we're basically taking our retained cash flow and underwriting the development program. To your first question, yes, we are -- we continue to look at maybe peeling off some markets where we don't want to grow in and we don't have much of a presence.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, just following up on new supply, curious to get your read over whether there are any markets where you think that there's some real overbuilding taking place that you're watching carefully or where you may be a little cautious over the next year or s
componenttext: Ron, just following up on new supply, curious to get your read over whether there are any markets where you think that there's some real overbuilding taking place that you're watching carefully or where you may be a little cautious over the next year or so.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2 markets that come to mind, Todd. One is the boroughs of New York. We have -- we don't have anything in the boroughs per se. Well, we've got one on Long Island and we've got one over in Jersey City, but that's it. But just looking at the C/O deals of the
componenttext: 2 markets that come to mind, Todd. One is the boroughs of New York. We have -- we don't have anything in the boroughs per se. Well, we've got one on Long Island and we've got one over in Jersey City, but that's it. But just looking at the C/O deals of the other public competitors as well as what we know is going on, the boroughs seem to have materially above-average level of development and high proportion of existing supply coming in. The other is Denver, where we've been told there's 40 to 50 properties on the board or about to be developed in that market, which is a big number for that size of market. We're developing quite a bit in Dallas. Where we are developing in North Dallas, we're not seeing a lot of new competitors. We're down in Houston. We've seen some uptick in Houston but nothing relative to the size -- in terms of size of market, nothing, from our perspective, to be concerned about at this juncture.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the lease-up cycles for new developments, they were taking place at as much, much faster pace for quite some time. Has that changed at all with some of the new deliveries? Or is absorption taking place at pretty much the same pace?
componenttext: And then the lease-up cycles for new developments, they were taking place at as much, much faster pace for quite some time. Has that changed at all with some of the new deliveries? Or is absorption taking place at pretty much the same pace?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're pretty much ahead across the board in terms of our filling up faster ahead of pro forma. So that process continues. The fundamentals of the business are great. Our customer acquisition costs were down again this quarter. We brought in more custo
componenttext: No, we're pretty much ahead across the board in terms of our filling up faster ahead of pro forma. So that process continues. The fundamentals of the business are great. Our customer acquisition costs were down again this quarter. We brought in more customers at lower cost at higher rates. So the fundamentals of the business continue to be just excellent. And that's playing into fortunately our development platform as well.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could talk about overall operating expenses. In 1Q, you guys benefited from lower snow removal costs. But as far as trends going into the rest of the year, are there any areas where we could see some savings that would keep cos
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could talk about overall operating expenses. In 1Q, you guys benefited from lower snow removal costs. But as far as trends going into the rest of the year, are there any areas where we could see some savings that would keep cost lower? I mean, I would assume you guys won't be expecting a negative -- another negative quarter of year-over-year costs. But what else could -- where could we see some savings in?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, I don't recall what Q2 snow removal costs were last year. I'm sure we had some. It was a pretty tough winter last year, so there may be some minor positive expense, for instance, on snow or R&M next year. But most of the other expenses, as I alway
componenttext: George, I don't recall what Q2 snow removal costs were last year. I'm sure we had some. It was a pretty tough winter last year, so there may be some minor positive expense, for instance, on snow or R&M next year. But most of the other expenses, as I always say, I would count on 2% to 3% property taxes. We've got them running at 4.5%. That's -- we don't see that changing much. So if I were modeling, I'd model 2% to 3%.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to follow up on a previous question, you guys gave April occupancy stats. And I was wondering if you could provide contract rate, what that looks like in April or move-in rates, whichever you think is more useful.
componenttext: So just to follow up on a previous question, you guys gave April occupancy stats. And I was wondering if you could provide contract rate, what that looks like in April or move-in rates, whichever you think is more useful.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ki, we don't usually provide that. I think -- but I don't think there's any trend different in April than what John mentioned in the first quarter in terms of move-in rates and move-out rates and street rates versus take rates.
componenttext: Ki, we don't usually provide that. I think -- but I don't think there's any trend different in April than what John mentioned in the first quarter in terms of move-in rates and move-out rates and street rates versus take rates.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess just broader, is this spring leasing season generally behaving the same way the previous couple of years spring leasing seasons have behaved in terms of you guys being able to push the take-in rate or contract rate year-over-year much harder in
componenttext: So I guess just broader, is this spring leasing season generally behaving the same way the previous couple of years spring leasing seasons have behaved in terms of you guys being able to push the take-in rate or contract rate year-over-year much harder in the springtime versus like the winter times?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ki, this is John. Yes, it is -- you've seen that sequential push. I think that the difficulty for us in Q2 is a comp compared to last year, where we had an exceptional Q2 last year that was surprising to us about how much demand came in and our ability to
componenttext: Ki, this is John. Yes, it is -- you've seen that sequential push. I think that the difficulty for us in Q2 is a comp compared to last year, where we had an exceptional Q2 last year that was surprising to us about how much demand came in and our ability to continue to push rates. So we're comping against that. But the trend lines are still the same. But it is a tougher comp for Q2 this year than we experienced historically.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, any color on Europe? Can you just give us a quick rundown of what you're seeing over there?
componenttext: I was wondering, any color on Europe? Can you just give us a quick rundown of what you're seeing over there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. Europe, let's see. Occupancies for the quarter were 89.8% versus 88.1%, so up 1.9%. Realized rents were up 3.1%, so overall REVPAF growth was 5.2% for the quarter. Expenses were only up 2.9%, so we had 6.7% NOI growth across Europe. So the tea
componenttext: Sure, Mike. Europe, let's see. Occupancies for the quarter were 89.8% versus 88.1%, so up 1.9%. Realized rents were up 3.1%, so overall REVPAF growth was 5.2% for the quarter. Expenses were only up 2.9%, so we had 6.7% NOI growth across Europe. So the team is doing a great job over there. Every market was up in terms of NOI, being led by Sweden at 16.2%. The laggard was Germany at 0.8%.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just in terms of investment activity over there, what's going on in terms of development or anything on the acquisition side?
componenttext: Got it. And just in terms of investment activity over there, what's going on in terms of development or anything on the acquisition side?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We opened up 3 new properties in London in the back half of last year. We've got a couple more that we're undertaking this year. We're trying to get things started in Berlin. So that's on the development side. Nothing at this juncture in terms of acquisit
componenttext: We opened up 3 new properties in London in the back half of last year. We've got a couple more that we're undertaking this year. We're trying to get things started in Berlin. So that's on the development side. Nothing at this juncture in terms of acquisitions.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Belcher with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Belcher with Wells Fargo.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you could give us some of the operating metrics for the assets that you acquired in the quarter as well as those already acquired so far in Q2, be particularly interested in any color you can share on the occupancy rates in place versus marke
componenttext: Wondering if you could give us some of the operating metrics for the assets that you acquired in the quarter as well as those already acquired so far in Q2, be particularly interested in any color you can share on the occupancy rates in place versus market rents and cap rates.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, I don't have the occupancies or any of that stuff on the acquisitions here with me. They're generally somewhere between 70% and 85% occupied. In terms of price per foot, the stuff we acquired were about $110, $120 a foot. It varies by market.
componenttext: Jason, I don't have the occupancies or any of that stuff on the acquisitions here with me. They're generally somewhere between 70% and 85% occupied. In terms of price per foot, the stuff we acquired were about $110, $120 a foot. It varies by market.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just on the preferred you issued in January, I think it was a 5.4% coupon, wondering where you think you might issue that now.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lower.
componenttext: Lower.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at Europe, how are the barriers to entry in that market from a development side? Is it difficult to permit, to finance relative to, say, a core West Coast market such as San Francisco and Los Angeles?
componenttext: Looking at Europe, how are the barriers to entry in that market from a development side? Is it difficult to permit, to finance relative to, say, a core West Coast market such as San Francisco and Los Angeles?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, London and Paris, first of all, those are big markets. I assume you're talking about the major metro centers, London, Paris, Berlin?
componenttext: Well, London and Paris, first of all, those are big markets. I assume you're talking about the major metro centers, London, Paris, Berlin?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they're just like Los Angeles or San Francisco or Manhattan. I mean, you've got core -- the core markets, the inner ring in Paris, downtown near Buckingham Palace, the central part of London. First of all, you can't get zoning. And second of all, if
componenttext: Yes, they're just like Los Angeles or San Francisco or Manhattan. I mean, you've got core -- the core markets, the inner ring in Paris, downtown near Buckingham Palace, the central part of London. First of all, you can't get zoning. And second of all, if you -- the deeds of lands for sale is incredibly expensive, it probably doesn't make sense. So it's equally as tough. And the sites we've done in London are -- they've not been easy in terms of getting the zoning. Same challenges that you face here, where the markets where you really, really want to be in and there's no competition, it's really hard or there's no zoning.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when you go over to markets such as Europe, is your platform -- and we always talk about your platform in the U.S. as being much better than some of the small mom-and-pops. Do you have that same advantage when you go over to Europe? And can
componenttext: Okay. And then when you go over to markets such as Europe, is your platform -- and we always talk about your platform in the U.S. as being much better than some of the small mom-and-pops. Do you have that same advantage when you go over to Europe? And can you consolidate anything over there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, you've got to keep in mind in all of Western Europe, and again this is best guess statistics, somewhere between 1,500 and 1,800 facilities in all of Western Europe, including Great Britain, over half of which are in Great Britain. So the produc
componenttext: Yes. Well, you've got to keep in mind in all of Western Europe, and again this is best guess statistics, somewhere between 1,500 and 1,800 facilities in all of Western Europe, including Great Britain, over half of which are in Great Britain. So the product that's available across the continent is pretty thin. There's not a lot of -- I think in Berlin, there's 10, 12 facilities in all of Berlin. So there's not a lot to buy. And the product is, on average, I'd say much lower quality than the U.S. because a lot of it was not purpose-built. A lot of it was converted office, converted garages, converted industrial buildings. And it takes a variety of shapes and sizes. So not a lot of purpose-built product in Europe, not a lot of product to even buy. And most of the product there is over in Great Britain and a lot of it is outside London.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And there appear to be no further questions at this time. I'd like to turn the floor back over to Clem Teng for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: And there appear to be no further questions at this time. I'd like to turn the floor back over to Clem Teng for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
