componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Jackie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Clem Teng to begin.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes. Before we begin, I want to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of historical facts include
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes. 
Before we begin, I want to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, April 27, 2016, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A reconciliation to GAAP with the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC report and an audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com. And I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem, and welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter here in Q1. So I'd like to open it up for questions.
componenttext: Thank you, Clem, and welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter here in Q1. So I'd like to open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Gwen Clark with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Gwen Clark with Evercore ISI.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I realize this information will be available in the 10-Q. But since that data won't be out for a few days, can you give us some color on the operating performance within your largest metros?
componenttext: So I realize this information will be available in the 10-Q. But since that data won't be out for a few days, can you give us some color on the operating performance within your largest metros?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gwen, this is John. I can kind of run through some of those. So Los Angeles, which is, by far, our largest market, revenues were up about 8.2%. San Francisco -- just a second, I'll just give you our top 10. San Francisco is up 7.8%; New York, 4.6%; C
componenttext: Yes, Gwen, this is John. I can kind of run through some of those. So Los Angeles, which is, by far, our largest market, revenues were up about 8.2%. San Francisco -- just a second, I'll just give you our top 10. San Francisco is up 7.8%; New York, 4.6%; Chicago, 2.4%; Seattle, 8.4%; Washington, D.C., 2.6%; Miami, 6%; Dallas-Fort Worth, 8.9%; Houston, 5.2%; and Atlanta, 7.8%.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess on that note, it seems like Chicago and D.C. were the definite underperformers. Can you just talk about what you think was driving that?
componenttext: And I guess on that note, it seems like Chicago and D.C. were the definite underperformers. Can you just talk about what you think was driving that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, D.C. has been an underperformer for us for several years actually, we've struggled with D.C. I think that's mostly competition. With respect to Chicago, that's more of a recent phenomenon. I don't really know exactly what's going on in Chicago. It's
componenttext: Well, D.C. has been an underperformer for us for several years actually, we've struggled with D.C. I think that's mostly competition. With respect to Chicago, that's more of a recent phenomenon. I don't really know exactly what's going on in Chicago. It's been a struggle for us throughout the market, so it's not just any particular part of the market. So I really can't tell. I think we're keeping our occupancy there, but we're lacking pricing power. So I guess we'll just keep working on that and see if we can improve it soon.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gwen, when you do get the Q, 10-Q, you will see that actually Chicago's NOI was up almost 11%. And that's not due to operating fundamentals, that's due to less snow than last year.
componenttext: Gwen, when you do get the Q, 10-Q, you will see that actually Chicago's NOI was up almost 11%. And that's not due to operating fundamentals, that's due to less snow than last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose with Citigroup.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about your acquisition activity, which looks like it's picked up year-to-date and I think is now in excess of what you did for in the entire year in '15. And I just was curious, are you seeing more product come to market? Or are you ch
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about your acquisition activity, which looks like it's picked up year-to-date and I think is now in excess of what you did for in the entire year in '15. And I just was curious, are you seeing more product come to market? Or are you changing what you're looking for in some of the acquisitions you're making? Or is there any -- something that's driving that increased volume there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Smedes, this is Ron. We've not changed our criteria at all. But I would summarize the market for acquisitions has more product, lower quality, higher prices.
componenttext: Smedes, this is Ron. We've not changed our criteria at all. But I would summarize the market for acquisitions has more product, lower quality, higher prices.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. More products, higher prices and lower quality.
componenttext: Okay. More products, higher prices and lower quality.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So within all of that, you're still able to find stuff that you like?
componenttext: Okay. So within all of that, you're still able to find stuff that you like?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's the broad market as a whole. Inside of that are some good products, some reasonably priced, so we're able to do some transactions here and there. But historically, we tend to do what makes sense for the franchise, what makes sense for the platf
componenttext: And that's the broad market as a whole. Inside of that are some good products, some reasonably priced, so we're able to do some transactions here and there. But historically, we tend to do what makes sense for the franchise, what makes sense for the platform, what makes sense on a price per foot. It varies by market. And that strategy has not changed, it's consistent. We continue to build out the platform in the markets where we are, both submarkets as well as markets in general. So nothing has changed in terms of strategy. But we are seeing, given the robust pricing, more product coming to market and I would say overall, lower quality. David Doll is here. So David, would you have anything to add to that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think the only reason that we're seeing a little more activity is we've got a team out looking for some of those one-off and off-marketed properties that can fill in some of our -- as Ron suggested, markets where we're trying to build out scale.
componenttext: No, I think the only reason that we're seeing a little more activity is we've got a team out looking for some of those one-off and off-marketed properties that can fill in some of our -- as Ron suggested, markets where we're trying to build out scale.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. I mean, so just, Ron, when you say higher prices, I mean, can you maybe just generally just quantify like how much cap rates have declined in the last, say, year or quarter or however you kind of measure it, just to get a sense of the pace
componenttext: That's helpful. I mean, so just, Ron, when you say higher prices, I mean, can you maybe just generally just quantify like how much cap rates have declined in the last, say, year or quarter or however you kind of measure it, just to get a sense of the pace of price increases of what folks are asking?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, my guess would be -- and everyone measures cap rates different, Smedes, right? They include tenant insurance or retail or don't include certain operating expenses. So it's a little hard to say. In terms of the way we underwrite and what we're seeing
componenttext: Well, my guess would be -- and everyone measures cap rates different, Smedes, right? They include tenant insurance or retail or don't include certain operating expenses. So it's a little hard to say. In terms of the way we underwrite and what we're seeing out there, I'd say 50 to 75 basis points at least, David?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Or 1.5 to 2x replacement cost.
componenttext: Or 1.5 to 2x replacement cost.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jana Galan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jana Galan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk to the decision to grow the development pipeline and maybe comment on land prices and construction costs.
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk to the decision to grow the development pipeline and maybe comment on land prices and construction costs.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the decision to grow the development pipeline or grow -- enter development started about 3 -- in earnest, about 3 years ago. And we started doing that in part because we couldn't find product in markets or submarkets where we wanted to build out our
componenttext: Well, the decision to grow the development pipeline or grow -- enter development started about 3 -- in earnest, about 3 years ago. And we started doing that in part because we couldn't find product in markets or submarkets where we wanted to build out our franchise, build out our platform. And two, we saw the continued escalation of prices of acquisitions, which previous question I just answered just kind of come to bear and has been for the last 12 to 18 months. So the pricing on acquisitions wasn't making sense, and then getting new product in markets where we didn't have existing product is the rationale for the development platform. And to the team's credit, this quarter, we ended with $600 million in the pipeline, which is a new record for us. And most of that, about 2/3 of that, $300 million, $350 million, will be delivered this year, which is also fantastic. In terms of construction costs, land costs, David?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So construction costs, across the country, there's different markets where we're seeing acceleration of costs, mostly due to labor shortage or subcontractor coverage, markets like the Bay Area, Miami and smaller markets like Phoenix and Denver, we're star
componenttext: So construction costs, across the country, there's different markets where we're seeing acceleration of costs, mostly due to labor shortage or subcontractor coverage, markets like the Bay Area, Miami and smaller markets like Phoenix and Denver, we're starting to see some pressure on construction cost. Land prices generally, it's a factor of availability. And so in those key markets where availability is becoming more and more difficult, then we begin to focus our efforts on redevelopment. And in most of those markets, we've got a great portfolio of assets that can be redeveloped on our existing real estate. So the team has to be nimble in terms of where those opportunities exist and how they could execute it.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I believe last quarter, you identified overall supply, maybe about 1,200 self-storage facilities in some stage of development. I was curious if you had an update on that number.
componenttext: And I believe last quarter, you identified overall supply, maybe about 1,200 self-storage facilities in some stage of development. I was curious if you had an update on that number.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I've been pretty close to -- between 800 and 1,000. And that -- nothing's really changed. My guess though is it's accelerating. So as we go through the year that probably -- number will accelerate. The number of people entertaining developmen
componenttext: Yes, I think I've been pretty close to -- between 800 and 1,000. And that -- nothing's really changed. My guess though is it's accelerating. So as we go through the year that probably -- number will accelerate. The number of people entertaining development, trying to get their arms around it or undertaking it continues to grow.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum with UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeremy Metz on with Ross. John, I was just wondering if you could talk about what you're seeing on the rent front, given the maturity of the portfolio and close to maxed-out occupancy. It does seem like you guys are still able to get some good traction pu
componenttext: Jeremy Metz on with Ross. John, I was just wondering if you could talk about what you're seeing on the rent front, given the maturity of the portfolio and close to maxed-out occupancy. It does seem like you guys are still able to get some good traction pushing rents and the market continues to bear it. So any color on street rates, where they trended during the quarter and maybe that spread between move-in and move-outs?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that the street rates during the quarter were up about 5%. The take rate on our move-ins, which our move-ins were about up 1% during the quarter, and they were moving in at rates that were about 4% higher than last year. The move-out rate
componenttext: Yes, I would say that the street rates during the quarter were up about 5%. The take rate on our move-ins, which our move-ins were about up 1% during the quarter, and they were moving in at rates that were about 4% higher than last year. The move-out rates, that were up 5.6% year-over-year. And just to give you a flavor of the take rate, the move-in rate was, about -- average on a per unit basis, about $124 versus the move-out rate of about $135. So it was about probably about $11 difference there. And that compares to last year at about $119 move-in versus $128 move-out.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so pretty similar. And then just one on -- you had a pretty good bump on the late charges and admin fees this quarter. I was just wondering, is that more late fee-driven? And assuming you'd even be willing to provide it, are you able to say what kin
componenttext: Okay, so pretty similar. And then just one on -- you had a pretty good bump on the late charges and admin fees this quarter. I was just wondering, is that more late fee-driven? And assuming you'd even be willing to provide it, are you able to say what kind of percentage of the portfolio is in arrears at this point? And has that increased at all lately?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, with respect to delinquencies, we're close to or at record low delinquencies. So the uptick, it's late fees and admin fees. The late fees haven't changed, it's all in admin fees. We bumped those a little bit last year. And so on a year-over-year bas
componenttext: Well, with respect to delinquencies, we're close to or at record low delinquencies. So the uptick, it's late fees and admin fees. The late fees haven't changed, it's all in admin fees. We bumped those a little bit last year. And so on a year-over-year basis, they're higher. Plus as John noted, you've got about 1%, 1.5% increase in move-ins.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I think Ross has one quick one.
componenttext: Okay. And I think Ross has one quick one.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Your occupancy at the end of March was flat year-over-year. Do you have an update on where you are here at the end of April?
componenttext: Yes. Your occupancy at the end of March was flat year-over-year. Do you have an update on where you are here at the end of April?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have an update. Yes, as of yesterday, we were up about 11 basis points.
componenttext: I have an update. Yes, as of yesterday, we were up about 11 basis points.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Ron, given your comments on where the transaction market is with lower quality and higher pricing, have you thought about putting some of your "lower-quality, noncore, smaller market assets" up for sale and using that as a source of develop
componenttext: Okay. And then Ron, given your comments on where the transaction market is with lower quality and higher pricing, have you thought about putting some of your "lower-quality, noncore, smaller market assets" up for sale and using that as a source of development funding?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have thought about that, Ross, and we continue to think about that. In terms of needing that as capital for development, we have plenty of firepower here on the balance sheet to undertake our development program. Keep in mind, $300 million to $40
componenttext: Well, we have thought about that, Ross, and we continue to think about that. In terms of needing that as capital for development, we have plenty of firepower here on the balance sheet to undertake our development program. Keep in mind, $300 million to $400 million, call it, $350 million a year, of retained cash flow goes a long ways towards funding the development program. That's about what our spend will be this year. So it's basically -- at this level of development, we're basically taking our retained cash flow and underwriting the development program. To your first question, yes, we are -- we continue to look at maybe peeling off some markets where we don't want to grow in and we don't have much of a presence.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, just following up on new supply, curious to get your read over whether there are any markets where you think that there's some real overbuilding taking place that you're watching carefully or where you may be a little cautious over the next year or s
componenttext: Ron, just following up on new supply, curious to get your read over whether there are any markets where you think that there's some real overbuilding taking place that you're watching carefully or where you may be a little cautious over the next year or so.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2 markets that come to mind, Todd. One is the boroughs of New York. We have -- we don't have anything in the boroughs per se. Well, we've got one on Long Island and we've got one over in Jersey City, but that's it. But just looking at the C/O deals of the
componenttext: 2 markets that come to mind, Todd. One is the boroughs of New York. We have -- we don't have anything in the boroughs per se. Well, we've got one on Long Island and we've got one over in Jersey City, but that's it. But just looking at the C/O deals of the other public -- our public competitors as well as what we know is going on, the boroughs seem to have a materially above-average level of development and high proportion of existing supply coming in. The other is Denver, where we've been told there's 40 to 50 properties on the board or about to be developed in that market, which is a big number for that size of market. We're developing quite a bit in Dallas. Where we are developing, North Dallas, we're not seeing a lot of new competitors. We're down in Houston. We've seen some uptick in Houston but nothing relative to the size -- in terms of size of market, nothing, from our perspective, to be concerned about at this juncture.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the lease-up cycles for new developments, they were taking place at a much, much faster pace for quite some time. Has that changed at all with some of the new deliveries? Or is absorption taking place at pretty much the same pace?
componenttext: And then the lease-up cycles for new developments, they were taking place at a much, much faster pace for quite some time. Has that changed at all with some of the new deliveries? Or is absorption taking place at pretty much the same pace?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're pretty much ahead across the board in terms of our filling up faster ahead of pro forma. So that process continues. The fundamentals of the business are great. Our customer acquisition costs were down again this quarter. We brought in more custo
componenttext: No, we're pretty much ahead across the board in terms of our filling up faster ahead of pro forma. So that process continues. The fundamentals of the business are great. Our customer acquisition costs were down again this quarter. We brought in more customers at lower cost at higher rates. So the fundamentals of the business continue to be just excellent. And that's playing into fortunately our development platform as well.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could talk about overall operating expenses. In 1Q, you guys benefited from lower snow removal costs. But just as far as trends going into the rest of the year, are there any areas where we could see some savings that would kee
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could talk about overall operating expenses. In 1Q, you guys benefited from lower snow removal costs. But just as far as trends going into the rest of the year, are there any areas where we could see some savings that would keep cost lower? I mean, I would assume you guys wouldn't be expecting a negative -- another negative quarter of year-over-year costs. But what else could -- where could we see some savings in?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, I don't recall what Q2 snow removal costs were last year. I'm sure we had some. It was a pretty tough winter last year, so there may be some minor positive expense, for instance, on snow or R&M next year. But most of the other expenses, as I alway
componenttext: George, I don't recall what Q2 snow removal costs were last year. I'm sure we had some. It was a pretty tough winter last year, so there may be some minor positive expense, for instance, on snow or R&M next year. But most of the other expenses, as I always say, I would count on 2% to 3% property taxes. We've got them running at 4.5%. That's -- we don't see that changing much. So if I were modeling, I'd model 2% to 3%.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to follow up on a previous question, you guys gave April occupancy stats. And I was wondering if you could provide contract rate, what that looks like in April or move-in rates, whichever you think is more useful.
componenttext: So just to follow up on a previous question, you guys gave April occupancy stats. And I was wondering if you could provide contract rate, what that looks like in April or move-in rates, whichever you think is more useful.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ki, we don't usually provide that. I think -- but I don't think there's any trends different in April than what John mentioned in the first quarter in terms of move-in rates and move-out rates and street rates versus take rates.
componenttext: Ki, we don't usually provide that. I think -- but I don't think there's any trends different in April than what John mentioned in the first quarter in terms of move-in rates and move-out rates and street rates versus take rates.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess just broader, is this spring leasing season generally behaving the same way the previous couple of years' spring leasing seasons have behaved in terms of you guys being able to push the take-in rate or contract rate year-over-year much harder i
componenttext: So I guess just broader, is this spring leasing season generally behaving the same way the previous couple of years' spring leasing seasons have behaved in terms of you guys being able to push the take-in rate or contract rate year-over-year much harder in the springtime versus like the winter times?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ki, this is John. Yes, it is -- you've seen that sequential push. I think that the difficulty for us in Q2 is a comp compared to last year, where we had an exceptional Q2 last year that was surprising to us about how much demand came in and our ability to
componenttext: Ki, this is John. Yes, it is -- you've seen that sequential push. I think that the difficulty for us in Q2 is a comp compared to last year, where we had an exceptional Q2 last year that was surprising to us about how much demand came in and our ability to continue to push rates. So we're comping against that. But the trend lines are still the same. But it is a tougher comp for Q2 this year than we experienced historically.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, any color on Europe? Can you just give us a quick rundown of what you're seeing over there?
componenttext: I was wondering, any color on Europe? Can you just give us a quick rundown of what you're seeing over there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. Europe, let's see. Occupancies for the quarter were 89.8% versus 88.1%, so up 1.9%. Realized rents were up 3.1%, so overall REVPAF growth was 5.2% for the quarter. Expenses were only up 2.9%, so we had 6.7% NOI growth across Europe. So the tea
componenttext: Sure, Mike. Europe, let's see. Occupancies for the quarter were 89.8% versus 88.1%, so up 1.9%. Realized rents were up 3.1%, so overall REVPAF growth was 5.2% for the quarter. Expenses were only up 2.9%, so we had 6.7% NOI growth across Europe. So the team is doing a great job over there. Every market was up in terms of NOI, being led by Sweden at 16.2%. The laggard was Germany at 0.8%.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just in terms of investment activity over there, what's going on in terms of development or anything on the acquisition side?
componenttext: Got it. And just in terms of investment activity over there, what's going on in terms of development or anything on the acquisition side?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We opened up 3 new properties in London in the back half of last year. We've got a couple more that we're undertaking this year. We're trying to get things started in Berlin. So that's on the development side. Nothing at this juncture in terms of acquisit
componenttext: We opened up 3 new properties in London in the back half of last year. We've got a couple more that we're undertaking this year. We're trying to get things started in Berlin. So that's on the development side. Nothing at this juncture in terms of acquisitions.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Wondering if you could give us some of the operating metrics for the assets that you acquired in the quarter as well as those already acquired so far in Q2, be particularly interested in any color you can share on the occupancy rates in place versus market rents and cap rates.

componenttext: Jason, I don't have the occupancies or any of that stuff on the acquisitions here with me. They're generally somewhere between 70% and 85% occupied. In terms of price per foot, the stuff we acquired were about $110, $120 a foot. It varies by market.

componenttext: Okay. And then just on the preferred you issued in January, I think it was a 5.4% coupon, wondering where you think you might issue that now.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at Europe, how are the barriers to entry in that market from a development side? Is it difficult to permit, to finance relative to, say, a core West Coast market such as San Francisco and Los Angeles?
componenttext: Looking at Europe, how are the barriers to entry in that market from a development side? Is it difficult to permit, to finance relative to, say, a core West Coast market such as San Francisco and Los Angeles?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, London and Paris, first of all, those are big markets. I assume you're talking about the major metro centers, London, Paris, Berlin?
componenttext: Well, London and Paris, first of all, those are big markets. I assume you're talking about the major metro centers, London, Paris, Berlin?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they're just like Los Angeles or San Francisco or Manhattan. I mean, you've got core -- the core markets, the inner ring in Paris, downtown near Buckingham Palace, the central part of London. First of all, you can't get zoning. And second of all, if
componenttext: Yes, they're just like Los Angeles or San Francisco or Manhattan. I mean, you've got core -- the core markets, the inner ring in Paris, downtown near Buckingham Palace, the central part of London. First of all, you can't get zoning. And second of all, if you -- decent lands for sale is incredibly expensive, it probably doesn't make sense. So it's equally as tough. And the sites we've done in London are -- they've not been easy in terms of getting the zoning. Same challenges that you face here, where the markets where you really, really want to be in and there's no competition, it's really hard or there's no zoning.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when you go over to markets such as Europe, is your platform -- and we always talk about your platform in the U.S. as being much better than some of the small mom-and-pops. Do you have that same advantage when you go over to Europe? And can
componenttext: Okay. And then when you go over to markets such as Europe, is your platform -- and we always talk about your platform in the U.S. as being much better than some of the small mom-and-pops. Do you have that same advantage when you go over to Europe? And can you consolidate anything over there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, you've got to keep in mind in all of Western Europe, and again this is best guess statistics, somewhere between 1,500 and 1,800 facilities in all of Western Europe, including Great Britain, over half of which are in Great Britain. So the produc
componenttext: Yes. Well, you've got to keep in mind in all of Western Europe, and again this is best guess statistics, somewhere between 1,500 and 1,800 facilities in all of Western Europe, including Great Britain, over half of which are in Great Britain. So the product that's available across the continent is pretty thin. There's not a lot of -- I think in Berlin, there's 10, 12 facilities in all of Berlin. So there's not a lot to buy. And the product is, on average, I'd say much lower quality than the U.S. because a lot of it was not purpose-built. A lot of it was converted office, converted garages, converted industrial buildings. And it takes a variety of shapes and sizes. So not a lot of purpose-built product in Europe, not a lot of product to even buy. And most of the product there is over in Great Britain and a lot of it is outside London.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Jackie, and I will your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Thank you. I would now like to turn the conference over to Clem Teng. Please go ahead.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes. Before we begin, I want to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of histor
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes. 
Before we begin, I want to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. 
All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, July 28, 2016, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
A reconciliation to GAAP to the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC report and an audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. Welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter here in Q2. So let's open it up for questions.
componenttext: Thank you, Clem. Welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter here in Q2. So let's open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.
componenttext:
[Operator Instructions] 
Our first question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, could you comment a little bit about same-store deals, same-store revenue deceleration? I know it's not that much. It's only 50 basis points off a good number. But I'm curious if you could provide some more details on what caused it. And tied to that
componenttext: Ron, could you comment a little bit about same-store deals, same-store revenue deceleration? I know it's not that much. It's only 50 basis points off a good number. But I'm curious if you could provide some more details on what caused it. And tied to that, in the years I've covered you, I've always known you guys to be a little bit more biased towards occupancy part of the equation. So maybe you can comment on the decline you saw towards the quarter-end.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a lot of questions, Ki, but I'll try to answer it. And I'll have John chime in with the details. If you look at the same-store portfolio and growth year-over-year between -- in our top 20 markets, you see 2 markets that really stand out: Denver and
componenttext: That's a lot of questions, Ki, but I'll try to answer it. And I'll have John chime in with the details. If you look at the same-store portfolio and growth year-over-year between -- in our top 20 markets, you see 2 markets that really stand out: Denver and Houston. Denver's revenue growth year-over-year declined by 8.3% and Houston year-over-year by 6.6%. So those markets declining from nearly double-digit growth last year to about 2% this year. And then you've got Washington, D.C. chugging along down there, about 2% growth as well. The big declines were in Houston and Denver. And those are also markets where occupancy degradation was probably 150, 200 basis points. So challenging markets. We have a fair amount -- there's a fair amount of new supply in the markets. We have a number of properties that fill up. So there is some cannibalization of the product, but I think Houston itself has some general economic slowdown there. The other markets, our West Coast markets are doing phenomenal, from San Francisco to L.A. to Seattle, Sacramento. And they're full. So they're not able to grow enough in terms of occupancy to offset the declining markets like Denver and Houston. So that's kind of the big picture in terms of revenue growth.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Does that mean -- and I can see those 2 markets, the supply -- told by supply markets.
componenttext: Okay. Does that mean -- and I can see those 2 markets, the supply -- told by supply markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Supply in Houston, you've also got, I think, there's some impact there from the slowdown in the oil industry, probably some out migration of people in that marketplace right now.
componenttext: Supply in Houston, you've also got, I think, there's some impact there from the slowdown in the oil industry, probably some out migration of people in that marketplace right now.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So whenever you're stretching too far, if I assumed, for the auto markets where you've talked about more supply coming on, not just this year, but maybe next year as well, is this -- can this be kind of [indiscernible] there's other markets that might be
componenttext: So whenever you're stretching too far, if I assumed, for the auto markets where you've talked about more supply coming on, not just this year, but maybe next year as well, is this -- can this be kind of [indiscernible] there's other markets that might be seeing this weakness further down the road that might impact your overall results?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's certainly new supply, and I've been saying for a year, 2 years that new supply will definitely impact revenue growth. And certainly in markets, I think, like Denver, New York, it is impacting, to some degree, revenue growth. But if you kind
componenttext: Well, there's certainly new supply, and I've been saying for a year, 2 years that new supply will definitely impact revenue growth. And certainly in markets, I think, like Denver, New York, it is impacting, to some degree, revenue growth. But if you kind of look across the markets, you got Denver down 8%; Houston, down 6%. Chicago and West Palm Beach were down 2%, but everything else was plus or minus 1%. Kind of the standout on the upside were Seattle, 2% change in the growth rate year-over-year; and Sacramento, up 3% year-over-year. Sacramento had a phenomenal quarter, up 11.8% in terms of total revenue growth. So everything else is kind of bouncing around plus 1, minus 1, but then you've got these big anchors there in terms of Chicago, Houston, Denver.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Juan with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Juan with Bank of America.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm here with James Specter [ph]. Just a question on rates. Any sense of what you're being able to push on a portfolio basis to start that third quarter. And if you can help us maybe get a picture of how that trended throughout the second quarter each mon
componenttext: I'm here with James Specter [ph]. Just a question on rates. Any sense of what you're being able to push on a portfolio basis to start that third quarter. And if you can help us maybe get a picture of how that trended throughout the second quarter each month, maybe throughout the second quarter versus July and maybe what we're seeing in August to date.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Juan [ph], this is John. Our rates, I would say, as we continue through the second quarter and into July, we've continued to overall -- overall portfolio continued to ratchet rates downward. So that now that our rates are below last year, we've also turne
componenttext: Juan [ph], this is John. Our rates, I would say, as we continue through the second quarter and into July, we've continued to overall -- overall portfolio continued to ratchet rates downward. So that now that our rates are below last year, we've also turned on more discounting, the dollar special discounting as well as discounting on our website. And as Ron mentioned, much of that is coming from some of these weaker markets. So overall, that's down. But there's markets that are up. Like the West Coast that run mentioned. I would expect, until we see this weakness, and if the weakness is coming in on the demand side, we are -- existing tenant base is not turning over any faster than it had previously. The move-ins that do come in are sticking around just as long as they've always had. I think the difficulty that we are seeing in these markets is just the lack of demand into our system, and therefore, we're having to reduce pricing and increase promotions.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give us a sense of what the year-over-year delta is in maybe July? Just to see how that [indiscernible] .
componenttext: Could you give us a sense of what the year-over-year delta is in maybe July? Just to see how that [indiscernible] .

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have that, but I could tell you, in the quarter, the year-over-year delta in the move-in rate -- last year, the delta was, say, the year-over-year move-in rate delta is about -- we were up 3.9% on the move-in rate. But our move-in volume was about
componenttext: I don't have that, but I could tell you, in the quarter, the year-over-year delta in the move-in rate -- last year, the delta was, say, the year-over-year move-in rate delta is about -- we were up 3.9% on the move-in rate. But our move-in volume was about -- down about 3%. So overall, in terms of, I would say, contract of projected rent, we were up slightly by about 0.5 percentage point.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just on the supply picture, could you give us a sense of what you're forecasting or thinking supply could be across your markets [indiscernible]
componenttext: Great. And then just on the supply picture, could you give us a sense of what you're forecasting or thinking supply could be across your markets [indiscernible]

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think it continues to expand. I don't have the second quarter numbers from the all the public companies yet, but last year, at the Self-storage Association, I gave kind of a projection of 30 million square feet to be delivered this year. And using
componenttext: Sure. I think it continues to expand. I don't have the second quarter numbers from the all the public companies yet, but last year, at the Self-storage Association, I gave kind of a projection of 30 million square feet to be delivered this year. And using the same methodology, it's up to about 38 million square feet. The way that my methodology is correct or not, if you extrapolate that, there's been about a 20% uptick in the volume of new supply in the last 12 months. Again, it varies, as I've continued to say, it varies by market. Certainly, the low barrier entry markets such as Dallas, Houston, parts of Florida. People don't think of New York as a low barrier entry market, but there's a lot of supply coming in New York. Those are markets that are gaining, I would say, above-average growth in supply, while markets like San Francisco, Seattle, and even most of L.A. have an absence of new supply. We're very [indiscernible].

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, second, who is striking this quarter that your expenses were up a little over 4%. I realized first half of the year, you're still low at 0.6%. I know you sort of talked about expenses maybe finally picking up to a more normal rate, and
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, second, who is striking this quarter that your expenses were up a little over 4%. I realized first half of the year, you're still low at 0.6%. I know you sort of talked about expenses maybe finally picking up to a more normal rate, and maybe people have kind of doubted that. But maybe it's starting to come. I guess, can you just talk a little bit about some of the line items that are up? In particular the on-site payroll was up 6.5%. So I'm just wondering if you're seeing, on a sustained basis, kind of wage inflation and other things that may be putting you in a more normalized expense environment.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You said it correctly at the front, Steve. I've continued to say expenses, 3% to 4%. And so we're kind of finally there. First quarter, Q1, we've got a big benefit of snow we moved, and obviously, that's going to occur. Property tax, it's continue to driv
componenttext: You said it correctly at the front, Steve. I've continued to say expenses, 3% to 4%. And so we're kind of finally there. First quarter, Q1, we've got a big benefit of snow we moved, and obviously, that's going to occur. Property tax, it's continue to drive our expense growth yet by far the largest item and they're up to a  5% run rate. On-site payroll, wage growth was about 1%, 1.5%. The change in payroll is really, we had a workers' comp credit last year, I think, of $1 million, $1.5 million. And then have an uptick in medical insurance. So that's really what's driving that line. Going forward, though, obviously, over the next couple of years, here in the West Coast, we're going to see an uptick in base wages due to changes in minimum wage law. Does that address kind of what you're thinking  about?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess it sounds like maybe this sort of, call it, 3-plus percent expense growth, which you've  been able to keep it at kind of a 1% range, plus or minus, maybe ending and we should be thinking about a more normalized expense environment sort of fro
componenttext: Yes. I guess it sounds like maybe this sort of, call it, 3-plus percent expense growth, which you've  been able to keep it at kind of a 1% range, plus or minus, maybe ending and we should be thinking about a more normalized expense environment sort of from here forward.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's a fair statement. .
componenttext: I think that's a fair statement. .

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you should -- Steve, this is Shawn. I'd also add that advertising expense is going to uptick. And what we will be doing in some of these weaker performing markets is we will be increasing our advertising spend on the web as well as we may increase
componenttext: I think you should -- Steve, this is Shawn. I'd also add that advertising expense is going to uptick. And what we will be doing in some of these weaker performing markets is we will be increasing our advertising spend on the web as well as we may increase our spend on television advertising sometime in the third quarter and into the fourth quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just staying on the development topic. I mean, your development pipeline is not about $630 million. Do you see that number as continuing to grow? And are you seeing any cannibalization from your new development on your existing portfolio?
componenttext: Just staying on the development topic. I mean, your development pipeline is not about $630 million. Do you see that number as continuing to grow? And are you seeing any cannibalization from your new development on your existing portfolio?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, last year, I said the development pipeline was hitting about $500 million. I thought that was peak. And Dave Doll and the team down there have moved it up to $600 million. Certainly, some of those properties will fall out, but I'm very pleased with
componenttext: Well, last year, I said the development pipeline was hitting about $500 million. I thought that was peak. And Dave Doll and the team down there have moved it up to $600 million. Certainly, some of those properties will fall out, but I'm very pleased with what we do have in the pipeline. We're going to have about $180 million of that delivered in the back in the second half of this year, so it will come down. We'll see if the team can replace that $180 million. So we continue to develop. We see attractive yields. In some markets, just there is some cannibalization, although we're trying very focused in terms of developing where we don't have existing product right near our current product. That's not always the case. There is some cannibalization. And certainly, smaller markets like Austin, Texas, where we put up a lot of product over the previous 2 years and we've seen a lot of other new product, there has been greater-than-average cannibalization in, say, in a market like Dallas where we're building mainly in North Dallas where we don't have much product.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of [indiscernible] with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of [indiscernible] with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Speak So just looking forward into the back half and 1Q, things are naturally a little slower and maybe put it back on rate of it. Just how are you strategically and tactically thinking, given what you've experienced this past quarter? Obviously, there's
componenttext: Speak So just looking forward into the back half and 1Q, things are naturally a little slower and maybe put it back on rate of it. Just how are you strategically and tactically thinking, given what you've experienced this past quarter? Obviously, there's also pretty strong, but I'm sort of looking forward and at that time when things are weaker, what are you expecting in terms of just free trade ability to push overall rate?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Shawn. We're still pushing rates, the renewal rates for existing tenants. We're still marching down the same path we have. We're obviously watching that to see it. It's triggering any ramp-up and move-out activities. So far, it hasn't as I m
componenttext: Well, this is Shawn. We're still pushing rates, the renewal rates for existing tenants. We're still marching down the same path we have. We're obviously watching that to see it. It's triggering any ramp-up and move-out activities. So far, it hasn't as I mentioned, the real struggle on some of these markets is on the front end and getting more demand into our system. But if it continues, the weakness will continue -- we'll just continue to cut rates and will continue to discount until we finally can get to a point where we're comfortable that we've found an equilibrium that we're happy with. So we're not afraid to cut rates. And we'll go right after market share.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so just to clarify. The existing -- can you just give us an update like how much is the existing rates -- the rate to existing customers, is that in line with recent trends and free trade is still in that 6% range?
componenttext: And so just to clarify. The existing -- can you just give us an update like how much is the existing rates -- the rate to existing customers, is that in line with recent trends and free trade is still in that 6% range?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're still sitting at increases to the existing tenant to base just like we did, very consistent with what we've done over the past 1 or 2 years. And the range is somewhere between 8% and 10% increases. And again, we're not seeing that our existing
componenttext: Yes. We're still sitting at increases to the existing tenant to base just like we did, very consistent with what we've done over the past 1 or 2 years. And the range is somewhere between 8% and 10% increases. And again, we're not seeing that our existing tenant base is any less stickier than it had been in the past. In fact, [indiscernible], and I'll let him throw that out, but the problem again in those peak markets are just trying to get the move-in volume coming in, in the door.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The percentage of customers greater than a year for the second quarter was up to 56.5%, which is an improvement from last year's 55.9%. And 2 years ago, it was down at 54%. So we've moved that 2.5% over the last couple of years.
componenttext: The percentage of customers greater than a year for the second quarter was up to 56.5%, which is an improvement from last year's 55.9%. And 2 years ago, it was down at 54%. So we've moved that 2.5% over the last couple of years.

componenttext: Just, first, a follow-up. Shawn, I just was wondering if you could provide a little clarification. I think I think I heard you say that rates were lower year-over-year in July. Was that asking rates that you're referencing?

componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes.
componenttext: Yes. Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Can you just provide a little more detail there or quantify what the year-over-year delta looks like?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The year-over-year delta, I think, the move-in -- I'm going to refer to the move-in versus The Street rates because Street rates, they're not as humane. They're not as important as actual move-in rate that's coming in the door. Move-in rates were down abo
componenttext: The year-over-year delta, I think, the move-in -- I'm going to refer to the move-in versus The Street rates because Street rates, they're not as humane. They're not as important as actual move-in rate that's coming in the door. Move-in rates were down about about 2.5%, month-to-date compared to the same time frame in July last year. I would say, again, just keep in mind. That's the average for our entire system, that Seattle's probably up 6% to 8%, and Houston's probably down 5%. So this is, I'm just drawing out averages here.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And over the last few years, is this the first time system-wide that you've had a reduction in asking rents year-over-year during the month?
componenttext: Okay. And over the last few years, is this the first time system-wide that you've had a reduction in asking rents year-over-year during the month?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have the data in front of me, but I don't think so. But I don't know.
componenttext: I don't have the data in front of me, but I don't think so. But I don't know.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I'm just curious. You just -- Ron, you just mentioned that you're increasing rents to existing customers. The percentage of customers was higher year-over-year in the quarter. If you do start, if you continue to reduce asking rents, system-
componenttext: Okay. And then I'm just curious. You just -- Ron, you just mentioned that you're increasing rents to existing customers. The percentage of customers was higher year-over-year in the quarter. If you do start, if you continue to reduce asking rents, system-wide, what does that do to the percent of the portfolio that gets a rent increase or is eligible for a rent increase?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Generally, as you reduce rates, customer duration gets longer. And so that, by definition and -- or axiomatically would say, "Okay, if customer generation increases, percentage of customers is greater than your increases, therefore, the more customers eli
componenttext: Generally, as you reduce rates, customer duration gets longer. And so that, by definition and -- or axiomatically would say, "Okay, if customer generation increases, percentage of customers is greater than your increases, therefore, the more customers eligible for an annual rate increase." I don't know if that's going to happen, but I mean, that's -- in theory, that's what would happen.

componenttext: Sure. For the quarter, this is same-store, Shurgard had a 7% NOI growth. Occupancy was up to 90.6 -- average 90.6 versus 90.1 last year. And realized rents were up 3%. Overall revenue was up 3.5%. Expenses were down 1.3%. That's how you got to this 7% NOI growth. Do you want by country?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: No, I think that's good. But so, by and large, it looks like those metrics look good. How are you guys thinking about your strategy post-Brexit, if it has an impact at all?

componenttext: It has no impact. I mean, we'll deal with whatever kind of unfolds in Brexit. Keep in mind, over in Europe, over the next 12 to 18 months, you have a substantial number of elections, which could change the political environment quite dramatically over in Europe, combined with Brexit. So we'll see how it plays out.

componenttext: Well, the decision was we had a great candidate percent in Maria Hawthorne, who's capable of sending to the CEO position at PS Business Parks, 31-year employee and which then made Joe available. Joe has a phenomenal track record at PSB. We have not had a COO at Public Storage for about 1.5 years. And so he's a great addition to the management team.

componenttext: Okay. So no intention to step down in the not-too-distant future that I'm hearing?

componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of Oklahoma, your acquisitions there this quarter more than double their footprint in the market. I'm guessing maybe this was up portfolio deal. So I guess, my question is, if you did this to protect your current position in the market? Or is this a market on your radar to further grow into?

componenttext: Okay. I guess you have them under contract, right?
