headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Jackie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to tu
componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Jackie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Thank you. I would now like to turn the conference over to Clem Teng. Please go ahead.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes. Before we begin, I want to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of histor
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes. 
Before we begin, I want to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. 
These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and our -- and in our reports filed with the SEC. 
All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, July 28, 2016, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC report and an audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. Welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter here in Q2. So let's open it up for questions.
componenttext: Thank you, Clem. Welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter here in Q2. So let's open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.
componenttext:
[Operator Instructions] 
Our first question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, could you comment a little bit about same-store revenue deceleration? I know it's not that much, and it's only 50 basis points off a good number. But I was curious if you could provide some details on what caused it. And tied to that, from the years
componenttext: Ron, could you comment a little bit about same-store revenue deceleration? I know it's not that much, and it's only 50 basis points off a good number. But I was curious if you could provide some details on what caused it. And tied to that, from the years I've covered you, I've always known you guys to be a little bit more biased towards occupancy part of the equation. So maybe you can comment on the decline you saw towards the quarter end.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a lot of questions, Ki, but I'll try to answer it. And then I'll have John chime in with some details. If you look at the same-store portfolio and growth year-over-year between -- in our top 20 markets, you see 2 markets that really stand out: Denv
componenttext: That's a lot of questions, Ki, but I'll try to answer it. And then I'll have John chime in with some details. If you look at the same-store portfolio and growth year-over-year between -- in our top 20 markets, you see 2 markets that really stand out: Denver and Houston. Denver's revenue growth year-over-year declined by 8.3% and Houston year-over-year by 6.6%. So those markets declining from nearly double-digit growth last year to about 2% this year. And then you've got Washington, D.C., chugging along down there at about 2% growth as well. But the big declines were in Houston and Denver. And those are also markets where occupancy degradation was probably 150, 200 basis points. So challenging markets. We have a fair amount -- there's a fair amount of new supply in the markets. We have a number of properties in fill-up. So there is some cannibalization of the product there, but I think Houston itself has some general economic slowdown there. The other markets, our West Coast markets are doing phenomenal, from San Francisco to L.A. to Seattle, Sacramento, and they're full. So they're not able to grow enough in terms of occupancy to offset the decline in markets like Denver and Houston. So that's kind of the big picture in terms of revenue growth.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Does that mean -- and I could see those 2 markets being the supply -- total [ph] by supply markets. Can I...
componenttext: Okay. Does that mean -- and I could see those 2 markets being the supply -- total [ph] by supply markets. Can I...

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the supply and in Houston, you've also got -- I think, there's some impact there from the slowdown in the oil industry, probably some out migration of people in that marketplace right now.
componenttext: In the supply and in Houston, you've also got -- I think, there's some impact there from the slowdown in the oil industry, probably some out migration of people in that marketplace right now.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So whenever [ph] you're stretching too far, if I assumed, for the other markets where as you've talked about more supply coming on, not just this year, but maybe next year as well, is this -- can this be -- can I draw a straight line and say, there's othe
componenttext: So whenever [ph] you're stretching too far, if I assumed, for the other markets where as you've talked about more supply coming on, not just this year, but maybe next year as well, is this -- can this be -- can I draw a straight line and say, there's other markets that might be seeing this weakness further down the road that might impact your overall results?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's certainly new supply, and I've been saying for a year that -- 2 years that new supply will definitely impact revenue growth. And certainly in markets, I think, like Denver, New York, it is impacting, to some degree, revenue growth. But if yo
componenttext: Well, there's certainly new supply, and I've been saying for a year that -- 2 years that new supply will definitely impact revenue growth. And certainly in markets, I think, like Denver, New York, it is impacting, to some degree, revenue growth. But if you kind of look across the markets, you got Denver, down 8%; Houston, down 6%; Chicago and West Palm Beach were down 2%. But everything else was plus or minus 1%. Kind of the standout on the upside were Seattle, 2% change in the growth rate year-over-year; and Sacramento, up 3% year-over-year. Sacramento had a phenomenal quarter, up 11.8% in terms of total revenue growth. So everything else is kind of bouncing around plus 1%, minus 1%, but then you've got these big anchors there in terms of Chicago, Houston and Denver.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Juan Sanabria with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Juan Sanabria with Bank of America.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm here with Jeff Spector. Just a question on rates. Any sense of what you're being able to push on a portfolio basis to start that third quarter? And if you could help us maybe get a picture of how that trended throughout the second quarter each month,
componenttext: I'm here with Jeff Spector. Just a question on rates. Any sense of what you're being able to push on a portfolio basis to start that third quarter? And if you could help us maybe get a picture of how that trended throughout the second quarter each month, maybe throughout the second quarter versus July and maybe what we're seeing in August to-date?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Juan, this is John. Our rates, I would say, through the -- as we continue through the second quarter and into July, we've continued to overall -- the overall portfolio continued to ratchet rates downward. So that now that our rates are below last year, we
componenttext: Juan, this is John. Our rates, I would say, through the -- as we continue through the second quarter and into July, we've continued to overall -- the overall portfolio continued to ratchet rates downward. So that now that our rates are below last year, we've also turned on more discounting, the dollar special discounting as well as discounting on our website. And as Ron mentioned, much of that is coming from some of these weaker markets. So overall, that's down. But there's markets that are up like the West Coast that Ron mentioned. So I would expect, until we see this weakness -- and the weakness is coming in on the demand side, we -- our existing tenant base is not turning over any faster than it had previously. The move-ins that do come in are sticking around just as long as they have always had. I think the difficulty that we are seeing in these markets is just the lack of demand into our system, and therefore, we're having to reduce pricing and increase promotions.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And could you give us a sense of what the year-over-year delta is in maybe July just to see how [indiscernible]?
componenttext: And could you give us a sense of what the year-over-year delta is in maybe July just to see how [indiscernible]?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have that, but I could tell you, in the quarter, the year-over-year delta in the move-in rate -- last year, the delta was -- say, the year-over-year move-in rate delta is about -- we were up 3.9% on the move-in rate. But our move-in volume was abo
componenttext: I don't have that, but I could tell you, in the quarter, the year-over-year delta in the move-in rate -- last year, the delta was -- say, the year-over-year move-in rate delta is about -- we were up 3.9% on the move-in rate. But our move-in volume was about -- down about 3%. So overall, in terms of, I would say, contract of projected rent, we were up slightly by about 0.5 percentage point.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just on the supply picture, could you give us a sense of what you're forecasting or thinking supply could be across your markets in the country [ph]?
componenttext: Great. And then just on the supply picture, could you give us a sense of what you're forecasting or thinking supply could be across your markets in the country [ph]?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, you had 2 questions. Do you mind getting back in the queue so other people can ask? Thanks.
componenttext: You know what, you had 2 questions. Do you mind getting back in the queue so other people can ask? Thanks.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, do you want to touch on supply?
componenttext: Ron, do you want to touch on supply?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think it continues to expand. I don't have the second quarter numbers from the -- all the public companies yet. But last year, at the Self Storage Association, I gave kind of a projection of 30 million square feet to be delivered this year. And us
componenttext: Sure. I think it continues to expand. I don't have the second quarter numbers from the -- all the public companies yet. But last year, at the Self Storage Association, I gave kind of a projection of 30 million square feet to be delivered this year. And using the same methodology, it's up to about 38 million square feet. So whether my methodology is correct or not, if you extrapolate that, there's been about a 20% uptick in the volume of new supply in the last 12 months. Again, it varies. As I've continued to say, it varies by market. Certainly, the lower barrier entry markets such as Dallas, Houston, parts of Florida. People don't think of New York as a low barrier entry market, but there's a lot of supply coming in New York. Those are markets that are getting, I would say, above-average growth in supply, while markets like San Francisco, Seattle, and even most of L.A. have an absence of new supply or very little.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, second, it was striking this quarter that your expenses were up a little over 4%. I realized first half of the year, you're still low at 0.6%. I know you sort of talked about expenses maybe finally picking up to a more normal rate and m
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, second, it was striking this quarter that your expenses were up a little over 4%. I realized first half of the year, you're still low at 0.6%. I know you sort of talked about expenses maybe finally picking up to a more normal rate and maybe people have kind of doubted that, but maybe it's starting to come. I guess, can you just talk a little bit about some of the line items that are up? In particular, the on-site payroll was up 6.5%. So I'm just wondering if you're seeing on a sustained basis kind of wage inflation and other things that may be putting you in a more normalized expense environment.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was -- you said it correctly at the front, Steve. I have continued to say expect expenses, 3% to 4%. And so we're kind of finally there. First quarter, Q1, we've got a big benefit of the snow removal, and obviously, that's not going to recur. Property
componenttext: It was -- you said it correctly at the front, Steve. I have continued to say expect expenses, 3% to 4%. And so we're kind of finally there. First quarter, Q1, we've got a big benefit of the snow removal, and obviously, that's not going to recur. Property taxes continue to drive our expense growth. They're by far the largest item and they're up to a 5% run rate. On-site payroll, wage growth was about 1%, 1.5%. The change in payroll is really, we had a workers' comp credit last year, I think, of $1 million, $1.5 million. And then we had an uptick in medical insurance. So that's really what's driving that line. Going forward, though, over the -- obviously, over the next couple of years, here in the West Coast, we're going to see an uptick in base wages due to changes in minimum wage law. Does that address kind of what you're thinking about?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I guess it sounds like maybe this sort of, call it, 3-plus percent expense growth, which you've been able to keep it in kind of a 1% range, plus or minus, maybe ending and we should be thinking about a more normalized expense environment sort o
componenttext: Yes. Well, I guess it sounds like maybe this sort of, call it, 3-plus percent expense growth, which you've been able to keep it in kind of a 1% range, plus or minus, maybe ending and we should be thinking about a more normalized expense environment sort of from here forward.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's a fair statement.
componenttext: I think that's a fair statement.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you should -- Steve, this is Shawn. And I'd also add that advertisement -- advertising expense is going to uptick. And what we will be doing in some of these weaker performing markets is we will be increasing our advertising spend on the web as we
componenttext: I think you should -- Steve, this is Shawn. And I'd also add that advertisement -- advertising expense is going to uptick. And what we will be doing in some of these weaker performing markets is we will be increasing our advertising spend on the web as well as we may increase our spend on television advertising sometime in the third quarter and into the fourth quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Hoglund with Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So staying on the development topic. I mean, your development pipeline is now about $630 million. Do you see that number as continuing to grow? And are you seeing any cannibalization from your new development on your existing portfolio?
componenttext: So staying on the development topic. I mean, your development pipeline is now about $630 million. Do you see that number as continuing to grow? And are you seeing any cannibalization from your new development on your existing portfolio?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, last year, I said the development pipeline was hitting about $500 million. I thought that was peak. And Dave Doll and the team down there have moved it up to $600 million. Some -- certainly, some of those properties will fall out, but I'm very pleas
componenttext: Well, last year, I said the development pipeline was hitting about $500 million. I thought that was peak. And Dave Doll and the team down there have moved it up to $600 million. Some -- certainly, some of those properties will fall out, but I'm very pleased with what we do have in the pipeline. We're going to have about $180 million of that deliver in the back -- in the second half of this year, so it'll come down. We'll see if the team can replace that $180 million. So I -- we continue to develop. We see attractive yields. In some markets, yes, there is some cannibalization, although, we're trying -- very focused in terms of developing where we don't have existing product right near our current product. That's not always the case. There is some cannibalization. And certainly, in smaller markets like Austin, Texas, where we put up a lot of product over the previous 2 years and we've seen a lot of other new product, there has been kind of greater-than-average cannibalization than, say, in a market like Dallas, where we're building mainly in North Dallas where we don't have much product.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vikram Malhotra with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just looking forward into the back half and 1Q, where things are naturally a little slower and maybe rate -- you pulled back on rate a bit. Just how are you strategically and tactically thinking, given what you've experienced this past quarter? Obvious
componenttext: So just looking forward into the back half and 1Q, where things are naturally a little slower and maybe rate -- you pulled back on rate a bit. Just how are you strategically and tactically thinking, given what you've experienced this past quarter? Obviously, the results are pretty strong, but I'm just sort of looking forward and saying at that time when things are weaker, what are you expecting in terms of just street rate and ability to push overall rate?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. We're still pushing rates -- the renewal rates for existing tenants. We're still marching down the same path we have. We're obviously watching that to see if it's triggering any ramp-up in move-out activity. So far it hasn't. As I ment
componenttext: Well, this is John. We're still pushing rates -- the renewal rates for existing tenants. We're still marching down the same path we have. We're obviously watching that to see if it's triggering any ramp-up in move-out activity. So far it hasn't. As I mentioned, the real struggle on some of these markets is on the front end and getting more demand into our system. But if it continues, the weakness will continue -- we'll just continue to cut rates and we'll continue to discount until we finally can get to a point where we're comfortable that we've found an equilibrium that we're happy with. So we're not afraid to cut rates, and we'll go right after market share.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so just to clarify. The existing -- can you just give us an update like how much is the existing rate -- the rate to existing customers, is that in line with recent trends and street rate is still in that 6% range?
componenttext: And so just to clarify. The existing -- can you just give us an update like how much is the existing rate -- the rate to existing customers, is that in line with recent trends and street rate is still in that 6% range?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're still sitting at increases to the existing tenant base just like we did, very consistent with what we've done over the past 1 or 2 years. And the range is somewhere between 8% and 10% increases. And again, we're not seeing that our existing ten
componenttext: Yes. We're still sitting at increases to the existing tenant base just like we did, very consistent with what we've done over the past 1 or 2 years. And the range is somewhere between 8% and 10% increases. And again, we're not seeing that our existing tenant base is any less stickier than they have been in the past, in fact, I think Ron's looking through the stats here [ph], and I'll let him throw that out. But the problem again in those weak markets are that just trying to get the move-in volume coming in, in the door.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The percentage of customers greater than a year for the second quarter was up to 56.5%, which is an improvement from last year's 55.9%. And 2 years ago, it was down at 54%. So we've moved that 2.5% over the last couple of years.
componenttext: The percentage of customers greater than a year for the second quarter was up to 56.5%, which is an improvement from last year's 55.9%. And 2 years ago, it was down at 54%. So we've moved that 2.5% over the last couple of years.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just first, a follow-up. John, I just was wondering if you could provide a little clarification. I think I heard you say that rates were lower year-over-year in July. Was that asking rates that you're referencing?
componenttext: Just first, a follow-up. John, I just was wondering if you could provide a little clarification. I think I heard you say that rates were lower year-over-year in July. Was that asking rates that you're referencing?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes.
componenttext: Yes. Yes.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you just provide a little more detail there or quantify what the year-over-year delta looks like?
componenttext: And can you just provide a little more detail there or quantify what the year-over-year delta looks like?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The year-over-year delta, I think, the move-in -- and I'm going to refer to what they're moving in at versus the street rates because street rates, they're not as -- to me, they're not as important as the actual move-in rate that's coming in the door. Mov
componenttext: The year-over-year delta, I think, the move-in -- and I'm going to refer to what they're moving in at versus the street rates because street rates, they're not as -- to me, they're not as important as the actual move-in rate that's coming in the door. Move-in rates were down about 2.5% month-to-date compared to the same time frame in July of last year. But that -- I would say, again, just keep in mind that's the average for our entire system, that Seattle's probably up 6% to 8%, and Houston's probably down 5%. So this is -- I'm just throwing out averages here.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And over the last few years, is this the first time system-wide that you've had a reduction in asking rents year-over-year during a month?
componenttext: Okay. And over the last few years, is this the first time system-wide that you've had a reduction in asking rents year-over-year during a month?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have that data in front of me, but I don't think so. But I don't know.
componenttext: I don't have that data in front of me, but I don't think so. But I don't know.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I'm just curious. You just -- Ron, you just mentioned that you're increasing rents to existing customers. The percentage of customers was higher year-over-year in the quarter. If you do start -- if you continue to reduce asking rents system
componenttext: Okay. And then I'm just curious. You just -- Ron, you just mentioned that you're increasing rents to existing customers. The percentage of customers was higher year-over-year in the quarter. If you do start -- if you continue to reduce asking rents system-wide, what does that do to the percent of the portfolio that gets a rent increase or is eligible for a rent increase?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Generally, as you reduce rates, customer duration gets longer. And so that, by definition and -- or axiomatically would say, "Okay, if customer duration increases, percentage of customers greater than a year increases, therefore, the more customers eligib
componenttext: Generally, as you reduce rates, customer duration gets longer. And so that, by definition and -- or axiomatically would say, "Okay, if customer duration increases, percentage of customers greater than a year increases, therefore, the more customers eligible for an annual rate increase." I don't know if that's going to happen, but I mean, that's -- in theory, that's what would happen.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Gwen Clark with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Gwen Clark with Evercore ISI.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just really quickly, can you give us an update on how Shurgard did during the quarter?
componenttext: Just really quickly, can you give us an update on how Shurgard did during the quarter?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. For the quarter, same -- this is same-store, Shurgard had a 7% NOI growth. Occupancy was up to 90.6% -- average 90.6% versus 90.1% last year. And realized rents were up 3%. Overall revenue was up 3.5%. Expenses were down 1.3%. That's how you got to
componenttext: Sure. For the quarter, same -- this is same-store, Shurgard had a 7% NOI growth. Occupancy was up to 90.6% -- average 90.6% versus 90.1% last year. And realized rents were up 3%. Overall revenue was up 3.5%. Expenses were down 1.3%. That's how you got to the 7% NOI growth. Do you want by country?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's good. But so, by and large, it looks like those metrics look good. How are you guys thinking about your strategy post-Brexit, if it has an impact at all?
componenttext: No, I think that's good. But so, by and large, it looks like those metrics look good. How are you guys thinking about your strategy post-Brexit, if it has an impact at all?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It has no impact. I mean, we'll deal with whatever kind of unfolds in Brexit. Keep in mind, over in Europe, over the next 12 to 18 months, you have a substantial number of elections, which could change the political environment quite dramatically over in
componenttext: It has no impact. I mean, we'll deal with whatever kind of unfolds in Brexit. Keep in mind, over in Europe, over the next 12 to 18 months, you have a substantial number of elections, which could change the political environment quite dramatically over in Europe combined with the Brexit. So we'll see how it plays out.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz with UBS.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, I just wanted to ask you one on succession planning. And if you could talk about the decision to bring Joe Russell over to Public Storage from PSB.
componenttext: Ron, I just wanted to ask you one on succession planning. And if you could talk about the decision to bring Joe Russell over to Public Storage from PSB.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the decision was we had a great candidate person in Maria Hawthorne, who was capable of ascending to the CEO position at PS Business Parks, a 31-year employee, and which then made Joe available. Joe has a phenomenal track record at PSB. We have not
componenttext: Well, the decision was we had a great candidate person in Maria Hawthorne, who was capable of ascending to the CEO position at PS Business Parks, a 31-year employee, and which then made Joe available. Joe has a phenomenal track record at PSB. We have not had a COO at Public Storage for about 1.5 years, and so he's a great addition to the management team.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So no intention to just step down in the not-too-distant future that I'm hearing?
componenttext: Okay. So no intention to just step down in the not-too-distant future that I'm hearing?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll be here next quarter.
componenttext: I'll be here next quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of Oklahoma, your acquisitions there this quarter more than doubled your footprint in the market. I'm guessing maybe this was up portfolio deal. So I guess, my question is, if you did this to protect your current position in the ma
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of Oklahoma, your acquisitions there this quarter more than doubled your footprint in the market. I'm guessing maybe this was up portfolio deal. So I guess, my question is, if you did this to protect your current position in the market? Or is this a market on your radar to further grow into?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't closed anything in Oklahoma.
componenttext: We haven't closed anything in Oklahoma.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess you have them under contract, right?
componenttext: Okay. And I guess you have them under contract, right?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if it's under contract and not closed, I'm not going to comment on it. So if we get it closed, that's a good question for next quarter.
componenttext: Yes. So if it's under contract and not closed, I'm not going to comment on it. So if we get it closed, that's a good question for next quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose with Citigroup.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back, you mentioned that move-in volumes are down and I'm just kind of trying to think about inasmuch as you can tell, do you think that's a factor of new supply overall? Or do you think there's sort of an affordability issue where the
componenttext: I just wanted to go back, you mentioned that move-in volumes are down and I'm just kind of trying to think about inasmuch as you can tell, do you think that's a factor of new supply overall? Or do you think there's sort of an affordability issue where the industry has pushed rates high and long against very high occupancies for so long that people are just sort of turning away and you need to make it more affordable again, which is kind of -- it sounds like what you're doing?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start and let John finish. Go back to my earlier comment of -- in a number of markets, whether it's Sacramento, Seattle, even L.A., Dallas, San Francisco. We -- during the second quarter here, we were full last year at 96%, 97%. We were full ag
componenttext: Well, I'll start and let John finish. Go back to my earlier comment of -- in a number of markets, whether it's Sacramento, Seattle, even L.A., Dallas, San Francisco. We -- during the second quarter here, we were full last year at 96%, 97%. We were full again this year at 96%, 97%. So in terms of net pickup and move-in volume, there was no more space to sell this year than there was last year. Where the markets are soft, whether it's Houston, Chicago, Denver, as John touched on, we're cutting rates and it seems to be a demand issue. And so that's where you probably had the more -- the greater fall-off in move-in volume. So think of it as part of your portfolio -- a good part of your portfolio is just sold out year-over-year. And so you're not going to have much of a change in move-in volume. And the stuff that is soft is where you're going to have degradation in move-in volumes precipitating the change in rates that John touched about. Do you have any?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, it's Michael Bilerman. Just going back to Joe Russell. Can you talk a little bit about the role and responsibility and, I think, when it was announced it was President and didn't have the COO in the press release. So talk a little bit about sort of r
componenttext: Ron, it's Michael Bilerman. Just going back to Joe Russell. Can you talk a little bit about the role and responsibility and, I think, when it was announced it was President and didn't have the COO in the press release. So talk a little bit about sort of role responsibilities that you want him to accomplish. And then talk about how it may be different. You have had a number of people through that role over the last 5 to 10 years and not much stuck. And so I'm curious how you expect Joe to make an impact and what his tasks are going to be to be successful in that seat.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, those are all good questions, but we're a little early in Joe's tenure up here at Public Storage to really answer all of that. As you know Joe and the REIT community knows Joe. He's an established leader and accomplished CEO. So he brings m
componenttext: Well, Michael, those are all good questions, but we're a little early in Joe's tenure up here at Public Storage to really answer all of that. As you know Joe and the REIT community knows Joe. He's an established leader and accomplished CEO. So he brings much more to the table than the COOs that I have had. And two, I've worked with Joe for 13 years at PS Business Parks. So I have a pretty good understanding of his capabilities. Right now, he's focused on learning our business and learning our markets. So right now, he has no direct operational responsibility. He's out learning the business and learning the markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: He had a pretty big move to make to come over, probably didn't need any storage.
componenttext: He had a pretty big move to make to come over, probably didn't need any storage.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you're looking at your developments that are in process right now, are you noticing any changes in the time to fill up? I guess going to that incoming demand question. Is it impacting the development pipeline as well, the lease-up?
componenttext: When you're looking at your developments that are in process right now, are you noticing any changes in the time to fill up? I guess going to that incoming demand question. Is it impacting the development pipeline as well, the lease-up?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Mike. So far, knock on wood, the developments are filling up ahead of plan. Now keep in mind, we've had somewhat of a strategy of being a little aggressive on pricing and promotion in some of them to accelerate that. So the real test will be, in a yea
componenttext: No, Mike. So far, knock on wood, the developments are filling up ahead of plan. Now keep in mind, we've had somewhat of a strategy of being a little aggressive on pricing and promotion in some of them to accelerate that. So the real test will be, in a year or 2, do we achieve the targeted revenue level as rates are stabilized. But for the most part, they're, on average, ahead of plan, ahead of plan in terms of NOI, well ahead in terms of occupancy. And we're very happy with the developments, deliveries and what's been happening. Our San Fernando Road property here in Glendale that we opened May -- end of May last year is already 92%, 93%, and is already at stabilized revenue level. So an absolute home run.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Stender with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Stender with Wells Fargo.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You traditionally haven't been a big seller of assets, but I know you had a few markets you were testing the prospects of selling, one is in the Midwest. Can you provide any updates there in your asset sales and maybe any other markets you're looking to t
componenttext: You traditionally haven't been a big seller of assets, but I know you had a few markets you were testing the prospects of selling, one is in the Midwest. Can you provide any updates there in your asset sales and maybe any other markets you're looking to test?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We pulled that package and have changed strategy in terms of what we're going to do in those markets. I can't comment on that now because we're in the middle of trying to do a couple of things. But I would just say we pulled that transaction. We don'
componenttext: Yes. We pulled that package and have changed strategy in terms of what we're going to do in those markets. I can't comment on that now because we're in the middle of trying to do a couple of things. But I would just say we pulled that transaction. We don't have any properties on the market for sale right now. And maybe next quarter or the quarter after, I'll be able to tell you -- kind of explain what happened.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Burke with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext:
[Operator Instructions] 
Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Burke with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, as we talk about the potential for moderating top line growth, does change in consumer behavior or the impact of new supply worry you more over the next 12 to 24 months?
componenttext: Ron, as we talk about the potential for moderating top line growth, does change in consumer behavior or the impact of new supply worry you more over the next 12 to 24 months?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I understand that question. Change in consumer behavior?
componenttext: I'm not sure I understand that question. Change in consumer behavior?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So demand from either -- or decision patterns of either your in-place customer or new customers, what rent increases they are able to digest? Where you're going to be able to push rents?
componenttext: Yes. So demand from either -- or decision patterns of either your in-place customer or new customers, what rent increases they are able to digest? Where you're going to be able to push rents?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've touched on kind of the differences in some of the markets where the demand issue is more of a problem. Maybe there's an uptick in supply there, certainly, in markets like Austin. So that's having an impact on demand and rental rates. A
componenttext: Well, I think we've touched on kind of the differences in some of the markets where the demand issue is more of a problem. Maybe there's an uptick in supply there, certainly, in markets like Austin. So that's having an impact on demand and rental rates. As I touched on earlier, we have not seen any degradation in the churn rate and actually have seen an improvement in length of stay this year versus last year, which would lead you to believe that customer stickiness and our ability to have pricing power with our existing tenant base is still quite good. Does that answer your question?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay and then -- that -- I think that gets me far enough. In terms of same-store pool, you only rolled about 15 of the 120 assets that you acquired in 2013 into the pool this year, which makes the definition of your same-store pool diverge from that of yo
componenttext: Okay and then -- that -- I think that gets me far enough. In terms of same-store pool, you only rolled about 15 of the 120 assets that you acquired in 2013 into the pool this year, which makes the definition of your same-store pool diverge from that of your peers even more so than it usually does. Occupancy on those assets is mid-90%, so I believe you could have rolled the rest of those in. Can you just talk to us about why you did not?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, this is John. The reason why we didn't is because stabilization isn't just about occupancy because I mean, I could fill up a property in a year by giving it away for free, right, and then throw it into the same-store the next year and revenues would
componenttext: Ryan, this is John. The reason why we didn't is because stabilization isn't just about occupancy because I mean, I could fill up a property in a year by giving it away for free, right, and then throw it into the same-store the next year and revenues would then just go skyrocketing. So we view stabilization not only as stabilized occupancy but also the stabilization of the rental rates that the existing customers are paying. So for those properties that we acquired in 2013 that we did not put in the same stores, even though the occupancies were mid-90s, the rental rates that were being charged the existing tenant base was still far below what we think stabilized numbers should be. So those properties we didn't put in, they're still growing at a much more rapid year-over-year change than the same-store properties that are operating and in those same markets. So clearly, they're not stabilized, and so we didn't put them in.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, to add some color to that, what John just said, on the 2013 acquisitions, our occupancies year-over-year were flat, 94.6%, but the contract rents were up 7.4%. And NOI growth on those was up for the quarter about 12%. So while -- as John said, it wo
componenttext: Ryan, to add some color to that, what John just said, on the 2013 acquisitions, our occupancies year-over-year were flat, 94.6%, but the contract rents were up 7.4%. And NOI growth on those was up for the quarter about 12%. So while -- as John said, it would look -- make the numbers look nicer or stronger if we put them in. From an objective reality in terms of are they really stabilized or not, they're not, so we've kept them out.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our final question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our final question comes from the line of Todd Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, realizing that the development machine takes some time to get ramped up here, as you look at growth perhaps moderating a bit at this point in the cycle, do you feel, as you look ahead over the next couple of years, that you need to make any changes t
componenttext: Ron, realizing that the development machine takes some time to get ramped up here, as you look at growth perhaps moderating a bit at this point in the cycle, do you feel, as you look ahead over the next couple of years, that you need to make any changes to how you're allocating capital as it pertains to development?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Todd, I'm not quite sure I understand. Are you implying or indicating that we should allocate more or less? I'm not quite following your question. I'm sorry.
componenttext: Todd, I'm not quite sure I understand. Are you implying or indicating that we should allocate more or less? I'm not quite following your question. I'm sorry.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just -- I know in certain markets like Houston, for example, you've talked about a commitment to that market long-term plans to develop, say, 100 facilities or so. You're also seeing softness in that market today. Does that change at all your commitment
componenttext: I just -- I know in certain markets like Houston, for example, you've talked about a commitment to that market long-term plans to develop, say, 100 facilities or so. You're also seeing softness in that market today. Does that change at all your commitment to that market? Or how you think about the pace of development?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, a couple of things. Houston is a great market. We think it's long term. I mean, I view it as the oil capital of the world. It's a great dynamic market. There's a lot of submarkets within Houston where we have little to no product and some marke
componenttext: Yes. Well, a couple of things. Houston is a great market. We think it's long term. I mean, I view it as the oil capital of the world. It's a great dynamic market. There's a lot of submarkets within Houston where we have little to no product and some markets where we do have some product, but we could penetrate those submarkets more. Same applies to Dallas. And there's a number of markets around the country, but those 2 markets in particular are very vibrant. And this does not change our program going forward. Now what may impact our program is, as rates roll down, it may adjust our ability to develop because it may not make sense in terms of what we can get land for and construction cost and the returns that we want on development to build as much in Houston as I would otherwise like. But long term, I mean, we're committed to those markets. Our development pipeline itself, I think we've delivered through June about $320 million or so. And so there's a fair amount of embedded growth on that. We're targeting stabilized yields, 8% to 10% on the development. And I think in the second quarter, we generated about $2 million on that $320 million of investment. So you can -- going forward, as you kind of go out '17, '18, '19, those development deals will provide a substantial source of growth for us. Right now, they're a bit of a headwind. Our 2016 deliveries for the first 6 months lost about $0.5 million. So net-net, we think it's a great investment long term. As I touched on, they're filling up ahead of plan. But it's a bit of a headwind on earnings today, but a great source of future growth. Does that address your question?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's helpful.
componenttext: Yes, that's helpful.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do have a question from the line of Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We do have a question from the line of Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up. On the non-same-store pool, I guess, if I look at the numbers, John, the occupancy is about 500-or-so basis points below your same-store pool. And the -- I guess, the realized rent per foot's about $1.50 lower. I guess, one, would you ex
componenttext: Just a follow-up. On the non-same-store pool, I guess, if I look at the numbers, John, the occupancy is about 500-or-so basis points below your same-store pool. And the -- I guess, the realized rent per foot's about $1.50 lower. I guess, one, would you expect this pool to ultimately kind of catch up to the same-store pool? And if so, do you think that's a 12-month process or more like a 24- to 36-month process?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: From here on -- well, first off, Steve, it's a different market mix than the same-store pool. So it's hard to compare the 2. It's a little apples and oranges. But it's -- I would say that in terms of potential future growth in this, I think that we're pro
componenttext: From here on -- well, first off, Steve, it's a different market mix than the same-store pool. So it's hard to compare the 2. It's a little apples and oranges. But it's -- I would say that in terms of potential future growth in this, I think that we're probably 12 -- another 12 months to 18 months away for another kind of rate increase or -- to existing tenants before we start getting to that level of them reaching that stabilization point.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I guess, you wouldn't expect the operating metrics of this pool of property, assuming it stayed static, to maybe get to the same level of occupancy as the same-store or you would?
componenttext: Okay. So I guess, you wouldn't expect the operating metrics of this pool of property, assuming it stayed static, to maybe get to the same level of occupancy as the same-store or you would?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All other things being equal, if they're in the same markets, they should get there. But my point is, is that they're in different markets, a different market mix, and I'm not sure what they are. For example, if they're all in Houston, could they get to t
componenttext: All other things being equal, if they're in the same markets, they should get there. But my point is, is that they're in different markets, a different market mix, and I'm not sure what they are. For example, if they're all in Houston, could they get to the same market mix, I mean, the same rate as our same stores? Probably not. Because Los Angeles and San Francisco dominate our same-store pool, and they have much higher occupancies right now than Houston does.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And higher rental rates.
componenttext: And higher rental rates.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. So you're asking me to compare apples and oranges, all I'm telling you is, is that they're not stabilized and I expect that their growth will continue to outpace the existing same-store growth, not only the growth of the overall same-store portfo
componenttext: Correct. So you're asking me to compare apples and oranges, all I'm telling you is, is that they're not stabilized and I expect that their growth will continue to outpace the existing same-store growth, not only the growth of the overall same-store portfolio, but those properties that are in the same markets, they will continue to outpace them just because of still filling up or stabilizing on the rental rates.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was our final question. Now I'd like to turn the floor back over to Clem Teng for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: That was our final question. Now I'd like to turn the floor back over to Clem Teng for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Public Storage Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Clem Teng. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Public Storage Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Thank you. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Clem Teng. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our third quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes. Before we begin, I wanted to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of hist
componenttext:
Good morning, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our third quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes. 
Before we begin, I wanted to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, October 27, 2016, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A reconciliation to GAAP to non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com. 
I'll now turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem, and welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter. And so with that, I'll open it up for questions.
componenttext: Thank you, Clem, and welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter. And so with that, I'll open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jeff Spector of Bank of America.
componenttext:
[Operator Instructions] 
Your first question comes from Jeff Spector of Bank of America.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And definitely want to recognize great growth in the quarter. Just if, Ron, you could give us maybe 2 minutes overview on the state of the market. You guys did a great job telegraphing some of the issues we may see this year in storage. But if you could j
componenttext: And definitely want to recognize great growth in the quarter. Just if, Ron, you could give us maybe 2 minutes overview on the state of the market. You guys did a great job telegraphing some of the issues we may see this year in storage. But if you could just summarize, I guess, the latest that you're seeing, whether it's supply, concessions and how you're thinking of running the business through the end of the year, that would be appreciated.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeff. I think, big picture, a couple of items. Our revenue growth rate obviously slowed down to 5.1%, but it's an incredible number, 5%. It's down from 6% last year but still a great number. If you look across our top 20 markets, all had positive gr
componenttext: Sure, Jeff. I think, big picture, a couple of items. Our revenue growth rate obviously slowed down to 5.1%, but it's an incredible number, 5%. It's down from 6% last year but still a great number. If you look across our top 20 markets, all had positive growth year-over-year, except one, Houston. The interesting thing, though, or trend thing that, I think, you want to get after is that if you take 80% of our revenue base, the rate of change in our growth rate decelerated in the third quarter year-over-year. So you take a market like Houston, which their year-over-year growth rate was down 9.3% Q3 '15 to Q3 2016. Denver was down 8.8% Q3 '15 growth rate versus Q3 2016. So 80% of our revenue base had a decline in the rate of growth, and certainly, we were up against very tough comps from 2015. We had an incredible third quarter last year. But what did that tell me, that growth is slowing. It's not all due to new supply because not all of these markets are impacted by new supply to the same degree. But you have markets like Los Angeles and San Francisco, which are certainly supply-constraint, very hard to get new product in, I would say, relatively new low new supply, but their rate of growth slowed. The other big picture is expenses uptick this quarter. And for us, there's a couple of explanations, but overall, expenses were up. And the big change -- one of the key items, I think, you should focus on is property taxes, up 5.4%, which continues to ratchet up by year-over-year. Supply is up, and the rate of change in new supply continues to accelerate. It's different across various markets. And I think that will continue to be a headwind on pricing power going into 2017. For us, we're going to continue to build our development pipelines up to $600 million. David and the team have done an excellent job, and the product that we're building is just exceptional. It's filling up pretty much according to plan, and our acquisitions are also doing quite well. For the most part, the stuff we bought from 2013 through 2016, most of it is ahead of what we underwrote. So the fundamentals of the business are still great. It's just the rate of change in growth, especially the top line, has slowed a little bit. John, you want to add any color on pricing and what's in doing in terms of marketing?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say that what we're experiencing is mostly softness in demand. The existing tenant base that we have is pretty much staying put like they normally have. So they're not vacating any more rapidly than we've seen. So the struggle, I would say, t
componenttext: Yes. I would say that what we're experiencing is mostly softness in demand. The existing tenant base that we have is pretty much staying put like they normally have. So they're not vacating any more rapidly than we've seen. So the struggle, I would say, that we are experiencing is really on the front end, getting move-ins in. Demand appears to soft around the country, not in any one particular market. I would say, in general, every market is experiencing softness. And as a result, we're having to -- we're advertising more on television, we're advertising more on the Internet, we are lowering our Street rates and we are giving away a little bit more discounts, not much more than last year, but a little bit more of this year. So -- but again, I'd like to emphasize that the existing tenant base is not vacating out any more rapidly than they have. We're continuing to send rate increase letters, similar to how we did last year, with increases in the range of 8% to 10%.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's helpful. Can I ask one follow-up? On that softness in demand, can you discuss that a bit? And is there anything you attribute to that specifically related to the economy, whether it's jobs or lack of income growth?
componenttext: It's helpful. Can I ask one follow-up? On that softness in demand, can you discuss that a bit? And is there anything you attribute to that specifically related to the economy, whether it's jobs or lack of income growth?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jeff, I'll touch and that. It kind of goes to -- and this is my point in terms of 80% of our revenue base headed slower year-over-year rate of growth than Q3 of last year. We're up against very tough comps. It's broad-based, and a number of these ma
componenttext: Well, Jeff, I'll touch and that. It kind of goes to -- and this is my point in terms of 80% of our revenue base headed slower year-over-year rate of growth than Q3 of last year. We're up against very tough comps. It's broad-based, and a number of these markets, I mean, are -- have very dynamic economies, the Bay Area Los Angeles. Seattle, this quarter, had a positive year-over-year rate of growth change, Sacramento, Minneapolis. So there's a lot of markets that still have some growth in them, but it's broad-based in terms of slow down. And I think, in part, it's due to just an exceptional 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the slowdown in demand and revenues. I was wondering how that's impacting acquisition market and how you're underwriting assets today versus a couple of quarters ago.
componenttext: Just following up on the slowdown in demand and revenues. I was wondering how that's impacting acquisition market and how you're underwriting assets today versus a couple of quarters ago.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not materially impacting what we're doing. In underwriting our acquisitions, we use what we have in terms of kind of a spot price in terms of rental rates on a trailing basis. We don't necessarily try to anticipate what the forward rate per foot is g
componenttext: It's not materially impacting what we're doing. In underwriting our acquisitions, we use what we have in terms of kind of a spot price in terms of rental rates on a trailing basis. We don't necessarily try to anticipate what the forward rate per foot is going to be. And then, of course, for us, replacement cost has been and continues to be a key element in terms of our underwriting. So the market may be tough, take Houston. If we can get something that's 60% or 70% replacement cost, we'll do that, even though, in the short term, we may be impacted by overall market conditions.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And as a follow-up, have you seen any changes in cap rates for stabilized assets in any of your markets?
componenttext: Great. And as a follow-up, have you seen any changes in cap rates for stabilized assets in any of your markets?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really.
componenttext: Not really.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give some stats on the move-in rates for the quarter and how that trended into October, please?
componenttext: Could you give some stats on the move-in rates for the quarter and how that trended into October, please?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ki, this is John. Ki Bin, this is John. The average move-in rate during the third quarter was about $135 per month. That compared to last year at $137 for the month -- for the quarter, that was for the quarter on a monthly basis. Month-to-date, in October
componenttext: Ki, this is John. Ki Bin, this is John. The average move-in rate during the third quarter was about $135 per month. That compared to last year at $137 for the month -- for the quarter, that was for the quarter on a monthly basis. Month-to-date, in October, the average move-in rate's about $127 per month, and that's actually up a little bit from last year, which was about $126 per month. But I will tell you this, notwithstanding the fact that it is higher than last year, the volume of move-ins that we are getting in the month of -- at least month-to-date October, is down about 3%. So getting higher rates but lower volume.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, a question I asked like 0.5 hour ago to your competitor's call. But I know we've tended to focus a lot on the supply side, but overall, on the demand side, what do you think is causing it, the lower traffic or lower volume or price sensitivit
componenttext: And I guess, a question I asked like 0.5 hour ago to your competitor's call. But I know we've tended to focus a lot on the supply side, but overall, on the demand side, what do you think is causing it, the lower traffic or lower volume or price sensitivity? Because we just have seen it before in the sector recently. So what do you think is really causing this change?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ki, it's so broad-based, and it varies by market. Well, John said volume is down 3% in a number of markets right now. In some markets, I mean, we're chock-full. We have not much space to sell, so there's not much volume uptick that we get. And then you ha
componenttext: Ki, it's so broad-based, and it varies by market. Well, John said volume is down 3% in a number of markets right now. In some markets, I mean, we're chock-full. We have not much space to sell, so there's not much volume uptick that we get. And then you have markets like Houston, which are -- have probably both a supply issue as well as an overall local economy issue with the big changes in the oil industry. And the other markets, whether it's San Francisco or L.A., don't have enough net new space to sell to offset the decline in volume in markets like Houston or Denver.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how about New York?
componenttext: And how about New York?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: New York's doing okay.
componenttext: New York's doing okay.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Gwen Clark of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Gwen Clark of Evercore ISI.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I know the information will be given in the Q, but since that, that won't be out for a while, can you just give us a brief run-through of the market performance specifically?
componenttext: So I know the information will be given in the Q, but since that, that won't be out for a while, can you just give us a brief run-through of the market performance specifically?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of -- you want NOI?
componenttext: In terms of -- you want NOI?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Revenue and NOI would be great, if possible.
componenttext: Revenue and NOI would be great, if possible.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Why don't I give you kind of some of our top markets. So Los Angeles was up 7.1% for the quarter, and this is in order of our largest to smallest within our top, let's say, 10. So Los Angeles was up 7.1%; San Francisco, 6.2%; New York, 2.9%; Seattle, 9.1%
componenttext: Why don't I give you kind of some of our top markets. So Los Angeles was up 7.1% for the quarter, and this is in order of our largest to smallest within our top, let's say, 10. So Los Angeles was up 7.1%; San Francisco, 6.2%; New York, 2.9%; Seattle, 9.1%; Washington, D.C., 2.7%; Miami, 5.5%; Chicago, 1.6%; Dallas and the Fort Worth area, 6.4%; Atlanta, 7.6%; Houston was down 1%; Philadelphia was up 5.3%; and Denver was up about a percentage point. That might be 10. And in terms of NOI growth, Los Angeles was up 7.8%; San Francisco, 6.2$; New York, 2.1%; Seattle, 9.7%; Washington, D.C., 1.3%; Miami, 8.7%, Chicago was down a negative 3.4%; Dallas-Fort Worth was up 5.8%; Atlanta, 7%; Houston, down 5.4%; Philadelphia, up 6.2%; and Denver was down 1.2%.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gwen, the Chicago and Houston, in particular, while the revenue was modest or negative, they were also -- were impacted by property tax increases year-over-year.
componenttext: Gwen, the Chicago and Houston, in particular, while the revenue was modest or negative, they were also -- were impacted by property tax increases year-over-year.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so that's helpful. And of these 6 [indiscernible], Houston, Chicago, Denver, D.C. are clear kind of underperformers of the group. Can you talk about what you think is driving, I guess, the demand within these markets just from a high-level perspecti
componenttext: Okay, so that's helpful. And of these 6 [indiscernible], Houston, Chicago, Denver, D.C. are clear kind of underperformers of the group. Can you talk about what you think is driving, I guess, the demand within these markets just from a high-level perspective and what might be affecting the growth rate?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I touched on in Houston, you've got -- there's not a huge amount, but new supply in Houston, both from us and competitors as well as kind of a macroeconomic condition with the oil industry and a dramatic slowdown in job growth and probably outmigrati
componenttext: What I touched on in Houston, you've got -- there's not a huge amount, but new supply in Houston, both from us and competitors as well as kind of a macroeconomic condition with the oil industry and a dramatic slowdown in job growth and probably outmigration of people. Denver is -- the economy's good there, but there's a big uptick in new supply. And D.C., was your other one Washington, D.C.? That's been a languishing market for a while. It's been languishing for apartments, it's been languishing for office, and it's been a tough market for us. A couple of years ago, the government shut down, let a reduction in spending, and that created some outmigration of people and that really has not returned. We think the market is stabilized there, but it certainly hasn't been on an upswing.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Todd Thomas of KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Todd Thomas of KeyBanc.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, the discounting, the promotional activity, the move-in rates you touched on earlier, can you just talk about how all of that boils down to the net acquisition cost per customer that you've talked about in the past, so what that cost per customer was
componenttext: Ron, the discounting, the promotional activity, the move-in rates you touched on earlier, can you just talk about how all of that boils down to the net acquisition cost per customer that you've talked about in the past, so what that cost per customer was in the quarter and how that compares year-over-year?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Todd. Marketing costs in Q3 were up 9.5%, and that's about $670,000. And that was evenly split, 2, between incremental TV and incremental Internet advertising. Promotional discounts were flat. So our overall customer acquisition costs were up 2.2% f
componenttext: Sure, Todd. Marketing costs in Q3 were up 9.5%, and that's about $670,000. And that was evenly split, 2, between incremental TV and incremental Internet advertising. Promotional discounts were flat. So our overall customer acquisition costs were up 2.2% for the quarter. Move-ins were up 1.1% or about 2,800 incremental new customers Q3 this year versus last year. So that gives you an acquisition cost of $127 versus $126 last year. Move-in rates for the quarter were down 1.5%. Fees were up 9.1. So our net profit per customer move-in was $32 this quarter versus $33 last year. Year-to-date, Todd, net profit per customer move-in was $38 versus $33 last year. So we had a 15.2% improvement in profitability. Year-to-date, move-ins are about flat -- or I'm sorry, cost are about flat. Move-ins were down 3,200, but rates were up and fees were up. So net-net, we made 50% more per customer this year than last year.

componenttext: I wanted to ask, Ron, you mentioned a couple of things going on, on the expense line, and you kind of called out the property taxes. As we look at the quarterly expenses up [ph] 6.4%, is there anything in any of those line items that were maybe kind of more onetime in nature or for this quarter? Or do you feel like it's just kind of a higher run rate than you have been over the last couple of years?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Smede. So a couple of items. You see on-site payroll there up 6.7%, most of that is due to about $1.5 million increase in our medical insurance costs employee benefits. And that's been up year-over-year, but we had $1.5 million increase in Q3. We'll
componenttext: Yes, Smede. So a couple of items. You see on-site payroll there up 6.7%, most of that is due to about $1.5 million increase in our medical insurance costs employee benefits. And that's been up year-over-year, but we had $1.5 million increase in Q3. We'll probably have another $0.5 million or so increase in Q4, smaller amount, but still a meaningful percentage increase year-over-year. Advertising, I touched on, up about $600,000, split between TV and Internet. And then the other big swing item was allocated overhead, which was up about $2 million. About $1.6 million of that was costs attributable to our annual sales conference, which we held in Q3 this year versus Q4 last year. So just over $1 million of that will flip back around Q4 as we expensed it in Q4 last year, Q3 this year.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I'm just going to ask you, too, at least relative to our forecast for your equity and earnings, [indiscernible] was up significantly. It's up year-over-year. I mean, I assume that's Shurgard, and maybe you can just give a little color on how that performed in the quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: PS, right? Yes, I think it's both Shurgard and PS Business Parks. And business parks, I think I know there earnings were up about 20% quarter-to-quarter. That's a combination of 2 things: solid same-store results, development. And then Business Parks has
componenttext: PS, right? Yes, I think it's both Shurgard and PS Business Parks. And business parks, I think I know there earnings were up about 20% quarter-to-quarter. That's a combination of 2 things: solid same-store results, development. And then Business Parks has been sitting on $150 million or $200 million of cash. And so at the end of June, they paid off a $250 million mortgage. And so they had nominal interest expense Q3 versus having cash and the interest expense last year. So half of the improvement of Business Parks is due to reduced interest, and half of it was due to improved operations. Shurgard Europe had good operating results, both from the same-store and nonsame-store properties. But a big chunk of their difference was $1.5 million special tax provision we made in Q3 last year that we did not make in this quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
