headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Could you give some stats on the move-in rate for the quarter and how that trended into October, please?
componenttext:
:  
          Could you give some stats on the move-in rate for the quarter and how that trended into October, please?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Ki, this is John. Ki Bin, this is John. The average move-in rate during the third quarter was about $135 per month. That compared to last year at $137 for the month -- for the quarter. That was for the quarter on a monthly basis. Month-to-d
componenttext:
:  
          Ki, this is John. Ki Bin, this is John. The average move-in rate during the third quarter was about $135 per month. That compared to last year at $137 for the month -- for the quarter. That was for the quarter on a monthly basis. Month-to-date, in October, the average move-in rate's about $127 per month, and that's actually up a little bit from last year, which was about $126 per month. But I will tell you this, notwithstanding the fact that it is higher than last year, the volume of move-ins that we are getting in the month of -- at least month-to-date October, is down about 3%. So getting higher rates but lower volume.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            And I guess, it's a similar question I asked like 0.5 hour ago to your competitor's call, but I know we've tended to focus a lot on the supply side, but overall, on the demand side, what do you think is causing it the lower traffic or lower
componenttext:
:  
          And I guess, it's a similar question I asked like 0.5 hour ago to your competitor's call, but I know we've tended to focus a lot on the supply side, but overall, on the demand side, what do you think is causing it the lower traffic or lower volume or price sensitivity? Because we just haven't seen it before in the sector recently. So what do you think is really causing this change?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Ki, it's so broad based, and it varies by market. Well, John is saying volume is down 3% in a number of markets right now. In some markets, I mean, we're chock-full. We have not much space to sell, so there's not much of a volume uptick tha
componenttext:
:  
          Ki, it's so broad based, and it varies by market. Well, John is saying volume is down 3% in a number of markets right now. In some markets, I mean, we're chock-full. We have not much space to sell, so there's not much of a volume uptick that we can get. And then you have markets like Houston, which are-- have probably both a supply issue as well as an overall local economy issue with the big changes in the oil industry. And the other markets, whether it's San Francisco or L.A., don't have enough net new space to sell to offset the decline in volume in markets like Houston or Denver.

That might be 10. And then in terms of NOI growth, Los Angeles was up 7.8%; San Francisco, 6.2%; New York, 2.1%; Seattle, 9.7%; Washington, D.C., 1.3%; Miami, 8.7%, Chicago was down a negative 3.4%; Dallas-Fort Worth was up 5.8%; Atlanta, 7%; Houston, down 5.4%; Philadelphia, up 6.2%; and Denver was down 1.2%.

componenttext:

          Okay, so that's helpful. And of these 6 out, Houston, Chicago, Denver, D.C. are clear kind of underperformers of the group. Can you talk about what you think is driving, I guess, the demand within these markets just from a high-level perspective, and what might be affecting the growth rate?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :  What I touched on in Houston, you've got-- there's not a huge amount, but new supply in Houston, both from us and competitors, as well as kind of a macroeconomic condition with the oil industry and a dramatic slowdown in job growth and probably outmigr
componenttext: :  What I touched on in Houston, you've got-- there's not a huge amount, but new supply in Houston, both from us and competitors, as well as kind of a macroeconomic condition with the oil industry and a dramatic slowdown in job growth and probably outmigration of people. Denver is -- the economy's good there, but there's a big uptick in new supply. And D.C., was that your other one? Washington, D.C.? That's been a languishing market for a while. It's been languishing for apartments, it's been languishing for office, and it's been a tough market for us. A couple of years ago, the government shut down, lot of reduction in spending, and that created some outmigration of people and that really has not returned. I think the market stabilized there, but it certainly hasn't been on an upswing.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Ron, the discounting, the promotional activity, the move-in rates you touched on earlier, can you just talk about how all that boils down to the net acquisition cost per customer that you've talked about in the past? So what that cost per c
componenttext:
:  
          Ron, the discounting, the promotional activity, the move-in rates you touched on earlier, can you just talk about how all that boils down to the net acquisition cost per customer that you've talked about in the past? So what that cost per customer was in the quarter and how that compares year-over-year?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Sure, Todd. Marketing costs in Q3 were up 9.5%, and that's about $670,000, and that was evenly split to between incremental TV and incremental Internet advertising. Promotional discounts were flat. So our overall customer acquisition costs
componenttext:
:  
          Sure, Todd. Marketing costs in Q3 were up 9.5%, and that's about $670,000, and that was evenly split to between incremental TV and incremental Internet advertising. Promotional discounts were flat. So our overall customer acquisition costs were up 2.2% for the quarter. Move-ins were up 1.1% or about 2,800 incremental new customers Q3 this year versus last year. So that gives you an acquisition cost of $127 versus $126 last year. Move-in rates for the quarter were down 1.5%. Fees were up 9.1. So our net profit per customer move-in was $32 this quarter versus $33 last year. Year-to-date, Todd, net profit per customer move-in was $38 versus $33 last year. So we had a 15.2% improvement in profitability. Year-to-date, move-ins are about flat -- or I'm sorry, costs are about flat. Move-ins were down 3,200, but rates were up and fees were up. So net-net, we made 15% more per customer this year than last year.

componenttext:

Or do you feel like those -- we're just going be on a higher run rate than you have been over the last couple of years?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, Smede. So a couple of items. So you see on-site payroll there, up 6.7%. Most of that is due to about $1.5 million increase in our medical insurance costs, employee benefits. And that's been up year-over-year, but we had $1.5 million in
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, Smede. So a couple of items. So you see on-site payroll there, up 6.7%. Most of that is due to about $1.5 million increase in our medical insurance costs, employee benefits. And that's been up year-over-year, but we had $1.5 million increase in Q3. We'll probably have another $0.5 million or so increase in Q4, smaller amount, but still a meaningful percentage increase year-over-year. Advertising, I touched on, up about $600,000, split between TV and Internet. And then the other big swing item was allocated overhead, which was up about $2 million. About $1.6 million of that was cost attributable to our annual sales conference, which we held in Q3 this year versus Q4 last year. So just over $1 million of that will flip back around in Q4 as we expensed it in Q4 last year, Q3 this year.

componenttext:

It's up year-over-year. I mean, I assume that's Shurgard, and maybe you can just give a little color on how that performed in the quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            In PSB, right? Yes, well, I think it's both Shurgard and PS Business Parks. And Business Parks, I don't think I know. Their earnings were, up about 20% quarter-to-quarter. That's a combination of 2 things: solid same-store results, fill up
componenttext:
:  
          In PSB, right? Yes, well, I think it's both Shurgard and PS Business Parks. And Business Parks, I don't think I know. Their earnings were, up about 20% quarter-to-quarter. That's a combination of 2 things: solid same-store results, fill up with some developments, and then they -- Business Parks has been sitting on $150 million or $200 million in cash. And so at the end of June, they paid off a $250 million mortgage. And so they had nominal interest expense Q3 versus having cash and the interest expense last year. So half of the improvement of Business Parks was due to reduced interest, and half of it was due to improved operations. Shurgard Europe had good operating results, both from the same-store and nonsame-store properties. But a big chunk of their difference was $1.5 million special tax provision we made in Q3 last year that we did not make in this quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Can you maybe just elaborate on some of the expense items, in particular, advertising? If you --  As you sort of see potentially occupancy or growth moderate a bit? Given how much more -- how many more customers are coming via the Internet?
componenttext:
:  
          Can you maybe just elaborate on some of the expense items, in particular, advertising? If you --  As you sort of see potentially occupancy or growth moderate a bit? Given how much more -- how many more customers are coming via the Internet? Can you give us how you sort of view the marketing and advertising bucket over the next, call it, year or so?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, this is John. We -- over the past year or 2, we've enjoyed a reduction in advertising as demand was coming in without the need to really spend more. In fact, we cut back significantly on both television and on the Internet. As we go fo
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, this is John. We -- over the past year or 2, we've enjoyed a reduction in advertising as demand was coming in without the need to really spend more. In fact, we cut back significantly on both television and on the Internet. As we go forward, if the softness continues, and it will at least over the next quarter or 2 and perhaps beyond, I don't know, I anticipate that we will spend more on -- definitely more on the Internet, on keyword search terms, probably spend more there than we will on television advertising. We did do a little television in Q3 and into Q4. Wasn't real thrilled with the response that we were getting, but we have been getting some pretty good response on the web. More and more of our customers, as you know, are moving to the web, whether they're using their desktop or mobile device, we're there, we're in both channels. So I expect, at least in the near term, our web spend will continue to tick up. I don't think that our television will really tick up. It will probably be the same. But overall, marketing costs will definitely be up.

what does the spread need to be. It probably needs to be 75, at least 75 bps before, I think, we would really want to issue another preferred to take out some of these other preferreds. But I also wouldn't rule out us issuing debt. We've talked about debt before. So I mean, that's always a possibility that we could issue debt and take out some of these preferreds. But I want to make sure that you understand, we haven't made a decision on what we're going to do in the first quarter yet with respect to these preferreds.

componenttext:
:  
          I would say core San Francisco, no, I don't see a lot of pickup in core San Francisco. There may be some outliers like Sacramento and some other submarkets to San Francisco. Portland seems to have a fair bit of new supply coming into that market. San Diego has a fair bit being built for the size of the marketplace. But again, we don't see that much in Los Angeles, Orange County. We're not really focused on Riverside and San Bernardino where there may be some more building going on.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Okay, great. Maybe just a bigger picture question for you, Ron. We're now pretty well into, I guess, a development cycle nationally, if you want to call it that. But in terms of your overall strategy for revenue management, what are you guy
componenttext:
:  
          Okay, great. Maybe just a bigger picture question for you, Ron. We're now pretty well into, I guess, a development cycle nationally, if you want to call it that. But in terms of your overall strategy for revenue management, what are you guys planning on doing differently, if anything, kind of this time around from the last time we were entering a development cycle? Just in terms of what you're doing with rate, occupancy and strategy overall.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Well, David, I like to say, the big dog eats first. And so I think going into this cycle, we have better pricing, better pricing strategies, better marketing, both television and Internet. Our market position, in terms of our market share,
componenttext:
:  
          Well, David, I like to say, the big dog eats first. And so I think going into this cycle, we have better pricing, better pricing strategies, better marketing, both television and Internet. Our market position, in terms of our market share, the product where it's located is better headed into this cycle. We've really got great positioning. And we will have next year as the deliveries come on in terms of Dallas, Houston, Miami, Charlotte, L.A., San Francisco. So I'm really happy -- Seattle -- with our market position. Our people are fantastic out in the field. We've got better product that we have available to rent. And I think our processes are as good as they've ever been. So -- and I'm just skipping over the balance sheet, which has never been stronger in our history. So we're really ready for this cycle.

Or was it kind of higher in the beginning and kind of slowed as we got towards the end?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Steve, let me see if I can answer the question a little bit. If you take the time and go back and look at our first quarter press release where we described our same stores, we give some metrics at the end of the quarter, what our square fo
componenttext:
:  
          Steve, let me see if I can answer the question a little bit. If you take the time and go back and look at our first quarter press release where we described our same stores, we give some metrics at the end of the quarter, what our square foot operate occupancy is and what the annual contract rate for occupied square foot is. You look at the first quarter, we reported that it was a 5.9% delta year-over-year. That gives a good indicator of what second quarter might be, and second quarter turned out to be a 6.1% revenue growth. If you now go to the second quarter information that we reported, we reported that the square foot occupancy had a negative decline of about 0.5%, that the annual contract rate was up 5.4%, the net of those 2 is a 4.9%. And we, in fact, reported a 5.2% for the quarter. So there was a big drop from Q1 to the end of Q2. We went from 5.9% to 4.9%. If you now look -- fast forward to the end of the third quarter, those same numbers are now at 4.7% versus 4.9% at the end of the second quarter. So the big drop, as I've kind of touched on, happened in Q2. We're still experiencing a decline, but the big drop happened earlier this year.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

So that rate of change, right, we had exceptional quarters in Q2, 3 and 4 of last year.

componenttextpreview: :            It's -- volumes, I think, are down. Or at least, I should say, the quality of the product coming to the marketplace is less than what it had been in prior quarters over the last year or so. And so I think buyers are being a little more sele
componenttext:

          It's -- volumes, I think, are down. Or at least, I should say, the quality of the product coming to the marketplace is less than what it had been in prior quarters over the last year or so. And so I think buyers are being a little more selective. There's lots more that we pass on than what we're buying, primarily due to quality of the product. Pricing hasn't changed that much. Will it continue to change? I don't know. But I think there's been a slowdown of quality product coming to the marketplace.

So the -- for the quarter, as we mentioned about the move-in rates, it was about $135 per move-in, the monthly rate. The move-out over the same time frame was $144, so down about 9% -- $9. Last year, it was $137 on the move-in. The move-outs were going out at $140, so about $3.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Okay. And then just one more question. We -- there's all this talk about demand softening in terms of coming into your system. But how do you measure and quantify that? Is it simply Internet traffic plus walk-ins? And are you able to quanti
componenttext:
:  
          Okay. And then just one more question. We -- there's all this talk about demand softening in terms of coming into your system. But how do you measure and quantify that? Is it simply Internet traffic plus walk-ins? And are you able to quantify sort of the deceleration that you've seen in the third quarter and October?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, the way I look at it, Ryan, is to say -- I look at it, at the call volume into our call center, the hits to our website where they're actually seeking and looking at storage space, so it's not the hits that come to our website of exist
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, the way I look at it, Ryan, is to say -- I look at it, at the call volume into our call center, the hits to our website where they're actually seeking and looking at storage space, so it's not the hits that come to our website of existing tenants that are paying their rent, as well as looking at our walk-in traffic as you actually mentioned. During the third quarter, we were actually seeing an uptick in sales calls. Part of that's due to the increased, I think, marketing activities. The web channel was about flat, though. But the channel that, I think, gives me most concerned is that our walk-in traffic was down about 7%. So 2 of our channels were either flat or up, but the walk-in channel was down. And I can't tell you why that has happened, but in fact, it was down 7% during the quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Just one quick one, just sticking on the development front. I was just wondering if some of the correction in the market would be at lower rates, increasing discounting? Has that created any additional opportunities under the development fr
componenttext:
:  
          Just one quick one, just sticking on the development front. I was just wondering if some of the correction in the market would be at lower rates, increasing discounting? Has that created any additional opportunities under the development front for you guys, either an opportunity to go acquire some land to build or in markets where maybe you're holding off, but now mentioning like a better time to start construction?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Well, Dave can provide that. Jeremy, generally, if rates are trending down, all other things being equal, that's going to slow development for us because the deals won't underwrite the way in terms of what we're trying to achieve in terms o
componenttext:
:  
          Well, Dave can provide that. Jeremy, generally, if rates are trending down, all other things being equal, that's going to slow development for us because the deals won't underwrite the way in terms of what we're trying to achieve in terms of return on invested capital. So a declining rate environment won't do that in the near term. Also, in the near term, land prices tend to lag changes in market conditions, right? Just like on the way up, they tend to lag on moving up. When you see the market turn, you can usually get good land deals for a period of time. So they tend to lag on the way down. So, so far, at least I haven't seen any reduction, big reductions in land prices. David?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :  I think you're correct, the sellers and developers are -- use the trailing indicators, not the leading indicators. So it'll be some time before those deals come to fruition.
componenttext:
:  
I think you're correct, the sellers and developers are -- use the trailing indicators, not the leading indicators. So it'll be some time before those deals come to fruition.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            It's actually Michael Bilerman. Ron, I'm curious, you've always focused on cap flow and cash flow growth rather than any sort of NAV metric. But I'm curious, now that the stock's around $200, which is probably just about the where you proba
componenttext:
:  
          It's actually Michael Bilerman. Ron, I'm curious, you've always focused on cap flow and cash flow growth rather than any sort of NAV metric. But I'm curious, now that the stock's around $200, which is probably just about the where you probably take your NAV, but more importantly, from a cash flow perspective, free cash flow yield, north of 5%. Does that entice you at all to put your, what you described as the best balance sheet you've ever had into your stock at this point?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Well, Michael, I'll just say this. If you look back in time, over 20-plus years, it's very rare that we can issue preferred at coupons below kind of the earnings yield on our stock, and we're getting pretty close to that. Now the last time
componenttext:
:  
          Well, Michael, I'll just say this. If you look back in time, over 20-plus years, it's very rare that we can issue preferred at coupons below kind of the earnings yield on our stock, and we're getting pretty close to that. Now the last time that there was -- that it happened at any -- for any extended period of time was '99-2000 when everyone wanted dot-com stocks and real estate was a bad word, brick-and-mortar. I don't know if we're going into that now, but it's very unusual for us to be able to issue preferred and coupons lower than our earnings yield. So we're getting close. And as John touched on, we'll see what we can continue to issue preferred and/or debt at. But it's not out of the question as time goes forward in terms of what -- where to deploy capital. Having said that, if we can deploy capital in third-party acquisitions or development opportunities that provide a kind of better spread yield or better overall earnings yield to the company, then we will do that vis--vis our share repurchases. So kind of which part of the menu of acquisitions development or share repurchases makes the most in terms of capital in terms of both growth and accretion to shareholder value.

componenttextpreview: :            Not at this time. Europe is generating more cash flow than it can deploy. We'll -- and so there, while they're ramping up their development program over there, their free cash flow is $80 million to $90 million a year, which is more than th
componenttext:
:  
          Not at this time. Europe is generating more cash flow than it can deploy. We'll -- and so there, while they're ramping up their development program over there, their free cash flow is $80 million to $90 million a year, which is more than they currently have plans to deploy. So in terms of an IPO, it'd be tough to do it in terms of use of proceeds. That could change in 3 to 6 months if some big opportunity came up in Europe. But at this time, I don't see that.

Is there a change in your willingness to push that first rent increase around the 6-month mark? And what happens to the magnitude of the rent increases?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            This is John. Look, we'll just -- we'll continue to test it and push it and see what happens. We constantly have a test group kept out of the normal group that's getting the increase to see what the reaction differential is to the rate incr
componenttext:
:  
          This is John. Look, we'll just -- we'll continue to test it and push it and see what happens. We constantly have a test group kept out of the normal group that's getting the increase to see what the reaction differential is to the rate increases. And if we do see some upticks, then we'll adjust accordingly. I can't respond to how we've done it in the past because: one, I don't remember; and two, I don't think we were smart enough to really test it as well under such circumstances. So we'll -- but we'll do that this time around and then we'll adjust, as I mentioned, as we see fit.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :  Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Public Storage Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Clem Teng. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext:
:  
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Public Storage Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Clem Teng. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Good morning, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our third quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.Before we begin, I wanted to remind those on the call that all statements other than stat
componenttext:
:  
          Good morning, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our third quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.
Before we begin, I wanted to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements.
These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, October 27, 2016, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
Now I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Thank you, Clem, and welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter. And so with that, I'll open it up for questions.
componenttext:
:  
          Thank you, Clem, and welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter. And so with that, I'll open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jeff Spector of Bank of America.
componenttext:
:  
          [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jeff Spector of Bank of America.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            And definitely want to recognize great growth in the quarter. Just if, Ron, you could give us maybe 2 minutes overview on the state of the market. You guys did a great job telegraphing some of the issues we may see this year in storage. But
componenttext:
:  
          And definitely want to recognize great growth in the quarter. Just if, Ron, you could give us maybe 2 minutes overview on the state of the market. You guys did a great job telegraphing some of the issues we may see this year in storage. But if you could just summarize, I guess, the latest that you're seeing, whether it's supply, concessions and how you're thinking of running the business through the end of the year, that would be appreciated.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Sure, Jeff. I think, big picture, a couple of items. Our revenue growth rate obviously slowed down to 5.1%, but it's an incredible number, 5%. It's down from 6% last year but still a great number. If you look across our top 20 markets, all
componenttext:
:  
          Sure, Jeff. I think, big picture, a couple of items. Our revenue growth rate obviously slowed down to 5.1%, but it's an incredible number, 5%. It's down from 6% last year but still a great number. If you look across our top 20 markets, all had positive growth year-over-year except one, Houston. The interesting thing though or trend thing that, I think, you want to get after is that if you take 80% of our revenue base, the rate of change in our growth rate decelerated in the third quarter year-over-year. So you take a market like Houston, which -- their year-over-year growth rate was down 9.3% Q3 '15 to Q3 2016. Denver was down 8.8% Q3 '15 growth rate versus Q3 2016. So 80% of our revenue base had a decline in the rate of growth. And certainly, we were up against very tough comps from 2015. We had an incredible third quarter last year. But what does that tell me? That growth is slowing. It's not all due to new supply because not all of these markets are impacted by new supply to the same degree. But you have markets like Los Angeles and San Francisco, which are certainly supply constrained, very hard to get new product in, I'd say, relatively new -- low new supply, but their rate of growth slowed. The other big picture is expenses uptick this quarter. And for us, there's a couple of explanations. But overall, expenses were up. And the big change -- one of the key items, I think, you should focus on is property taxes, up 5.4%, which continues to ratchet up by year-over-year. Supply is up, and the rate of change in new supply continues to accelerate. It's different across various markets. And I think that will continue to be a headwind on pricing power going into 2017. For us, we're going to continue to build. Our development pipelines up to $600 million. David and the team have done an excellent job, and the product that we're building is just exceptional. It's filling up pretty much according to plan, and our acquisitions are also doing quite well. For the most part, the stuff we bought from 2013 through 2016, most of it is ahead of what we underwrote. So the fundamentals of the business are still great. It's just the rate of change in growth, especially the top line, has slowed a little bit. John, you want to add any color on pricing and what you've been doing in terms of marketing?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Yes. I would say that what we're experiencing is mostly a softness in demand. The existing tenant base that we have is pretty much staying put like they normally have. So they're not vacating any more rapidly than we've seen. So the struggl
componenttext:
:  
          Yes. I would say that what we're experiencing is mostly a softness in demand. The existing tenant base that we have is pretty much staying put like they normally have. So they're not vacating any more rapidly than we've seen. So the struggle, I would say, that we are experiencing is really on the front end, getting move-ins in. Demand appears to be soft around the country, not in any one particular market. I would say, in general, every market is experiencing softness. And as a result, we're having to -- we're advertising more on television, we're advertising more on the Internet, we are lowering our Street rates and we are giving away a little bit more discounts, not much more than last year, but a little bit more of this year. So -- but again, I'd like to emphasize that the existing tenant base is not vacating out any more rapidly than they have. We're continuing to send rate increase letters similar to how we did last year, with increases in the range of 8% to 10%.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext:
:  
          It's helpful. Can I ask one follow-up? On that softness in demand, can you discuss that a bit? And is there anything you attribute to that specifically related to the economy, whether it's jobs or lack of income growth?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Well, Jeff, I'll touch on that. It kind of goes to -- and this is my point in terms of 80% of our revenue base had a slower year-over-year rate of growth than Q3 of last year. We're up against very tough comps. It's broad based, and a numbe
componenttext:
:  
          Well, Jeff, I'll touch on that. It kind of goes to -- and this is my point in terms of 80% of our revenue base had a slower year-over-year rate of growth than Q3 of last year. We're up against very tough comps. It's broad based, and a number of these markets, I mean, are -- have very dynamic economies: the Bay Area; Los Angeles; Seattle, this quarter, had a positive year-over-year rate of growth change; Sacramento; Minneapolis. So there's a lot of markets that still have some growth in them, but it's broad based in terms of slowdown. And I think, in part, it's due to just an exceptional 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Your next question comes from Gaurav Mehta of Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext:
:  
          Your next question comes from Gaurav Mehta of Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Just following up on the slowdown in demand and revenues. I was wondering how that's impacting acquisition market, and how you're underwriting assets today versus a couple of quarters ago.
componenttext:
:  
          Just following up on the slowdown in demand and revenues. I was wondering how that's impacting acquisition market, and how you're underwriting assets today versus a couple of quarters ago.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            It's not materially impacting what we're doing. In underwriting our acquisitions, we use what we have in terms of kind of a spot price in terms of rental rates on a trailing basis. We don't necessarily try to anticipate what the forward rat
componenttext:
:  
          It's not materially impacting what we're doing. In underwriting our acquisitions, we use what we have in terms of kind of a spot price in terms of rental rates on a trailing basis. We don't necessarily try to anticipate what the forward rate per foot is going to be. And then, of course, for us, replacement cost has been and continues to be a key element in terms of our underwriting. So the market may be tough. Take Houston. If we can get something that's 60% or 70% replacement cost, we'll do that deal even though in the short term, we may be impacted by overall market conditions.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Could you give some stats on the move-in rate for the quarter and how that trended into October, please?
componenttext:
:  
          Could you give some stats on the move-in rate for the quarter and how that trended into October, please?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Ki, this is John. Ki Bin, this is John. The average move-in rate during the third quarter was about $135 per month. That compared to last year at $137 for the month -- for the quarter. That was for the quarter on a monthly basis. Month-to-d
componenttext:
:  
          Ki, this is John. Ki Bin, this is John. The average move-in rate during the third quarter was about $135 per month. That compared to last year at $137 for the month -- for the quarter. That was for the quarter on a monthly basis. Month-to-date, in October, the average move-in rate's about $127 per month, and that's actually up a little bit from last year, which was about $126 per month. But I will tell you this, notwithstanding the fact that it is higher than last year, the volume of move-ins that we are getting in the month of -- at least month-to-date October, is down about 3%. So getting higher rates but lower volume.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            And I guess, it's a similar question I asked like 0.5 hour ago to your competitor's call, but I know we've tended to focus a lot on the supply side, but overall, on the demand side, what do you think is causing it the lower traffic or lower
componenttext:
:  
          And I guess, it's a similar question I asked like 0.5 hour ago to your competitor's call, but I know we've tended to focus a lot on the supply side, but overall, on the demand side, what do you think is causing it the lower traffic or lower volume or price sensitivity? Because we just haven't seen it before in the sector recently. So what do you think is really causing this change?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Ki, it's so broad based, and it varies by market. Well, John is saying volume is down 3% in a number of markets right now. In some markets, I mean, we're chock-full. We have not much space to sell, so there's not much of a volume uptick tha
componenttext:
:  
          Ki, it's so broad based, and it varies by market. Well, John is saying volume is down 3% in a number of markets right now. In some markets, I mean, we're chock-full. We have not much space to sell, so there's not much of a volume uptick that we can get. And then you have markets like Houston, which are-- have probably both a supply issue as well as an overall local economy issue with the big changes in the oil industry. And the other markets, whether it's San Francisco or L.A., don't have enough net new space to sell to offset the decline in volume in markets like Houston or Denver.

componenttext:

So Los Angeles was up 7.1%; San Francisco, 6.2%; New York, 2.9%; Seattle, 9.1%; Washington, D.C., 2.7%; Miami, 5.5%; Chicago, 1.6%; Dallas and the Fort Worth area, 6.4%; Atlanta, 7.6%; Houston was down 1%; Philadelphia was up 5.3%; and Denver was up about 1 percentage point. That might be 10. And then in terms of NOI growth, Los Angeles was up 7.8%; San Francisco, 6.2%; New York, 2.1%; Seattle, 9.7%; Washington, D.C., 1.3%; Miami, 8.7%, Chicago was down a negative 3.4%; Dallas-Fort Worth was up 5.8%; Atlanta, 7%; Houston, down 5.4%; Philadelphia, up 6.2%; and Denver was down 1.2%.

componenttext:

          Okay, so that's helpful. And of these 6 out, Houston, Chicago, Denver, D.C. are clear kind of underperformers of the group. Can you talk about what you think is driving, I guess, the demand within these markets just from a high-level perspective, and what might be affecting the growth rate?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :  What I touched on in Houston, you've got-- there's not a huge amount, but new supply in Houston, both from us and competitors, as well as kind of a macroeconomic condition with the oil industry and a dramatic slowdown in job growth and probably outmigr
componenttext: :  What I touched on in Houston, you've got-- there's not a huge amount, but new supply in Houston, both from us and competitors, as well as kind of a macroeconomic condition with the oil industry and a dramatic slowdown in job growth and probably outmigration of people. Denver is -- the economy's good there, but there's a big uptick in new supply. And D.C., was that your other one? Washington, D.C.? That's been a languishing market for a while. It's been languishing for apartments, it's been languishing for office, and it's been a tough market for us. A couple of years ago, the government shut down, lot of reduction in spending, and that created some outmigration of people and that really has not returned. I think the market stabilized there, but it certainly hasn't been on an upswing.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Ron, the discounting, the promotional activity, the move-in rates you touched on earlier, can you just talk about how all that boils down to the net acquisition cost per customer that you've talked about in the past? So what that cost per c
componenttext:
:  
          Ron, the discounting, the promotional activity, the move-in rates you touched on earlier, can you just talk about how all that boils down to the net acquisition cost per customer that you've talked about in the past? So what that cost per customer was in the quarter and how that compares year-over-year?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Sure, Todd. Marketing costs in Q3 were up 9.5%, and that's about $670,000, and that was evenly split to between incremental TV and incremental Internet advertising. Promotional discounts were flat. So our overall customer acquisition costs
componenttext:
:  
          Sure, Todd. Marketing costs in Q3 were up 9.5%, and that's about $670,000, and that was evenly split to between incremental TV and incremental Internet advertising. Promotional discounts were flat. So our overall customer acquisition costs were up 2.2% for the quarter. Move-ins were up 1.1% or about 2,800 incremental new customers Q3 this year versus last year. So that gives you an acquisition cost of $127 versus $126 last year. Move-in rates for the quarter were down 1.5%. Fees were up 9.1. So our net profit per customer move-in was $32 this quarter versus $33 last year. Year-to-date, Todd, net profit per customer move-in was $38 versus $33 last year. So we had a 15.2% improvement in profitability. Year-to-date, move-ins are about flat -- or I'm sorry, costs are about flat. Move-ins were down 3,200, but rates were up and fees were up. So net-net, we made 15% more per customer this year than last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext:

componenttext:
:  
          Todd, they may be affecting us, and I'm sure they are. But to the extent that they are, we kind of don't see it in our numbers. I mean, they could be taking away, let's say, 10 customers a facility. We would -- it's hard for us to notice that.

          I wanted to ask -- Ron, you mentioned a couple of things going on, on the expense line, and you kind of called out the property taxes. As we look at the quarterly expenses up 6.4%, is there anything in any of those line items that were maybe kind of more onetime in nature or -- for this quarter? Or do you feel like those -- we're just going be on a higher run rate than you have been over the last couple of years?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, Smede. So a couple of items. So you see on-site payroll there, up 6.7%. Most of that is due to about $1.5 million increase in our medical insurance costs, employee benefits. And that's been up year-over-year, but we had $1.5 million in
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, Smede. So a couple of items. So you see on-site payroll there, up 6.7%. Most of that is due to about $1.5 million increase in our medical insurance costs, employee benefits. And that's been up year-over-year, but we had $1.5 million increase in Q3. We'll probably have another $0.5 million or so increase in Q4, smaller amount, but still a meaningful percentage increase year-over-year. Advertising, I touched on, up about $600,000, split between TV and Internet. And then the other big swing item was allocated overhead, which was up about $2 million. About $1.6 million of that was cost attributable to our annual sales conference, which we held in Q3 this year versus Q4 last year. So just over $1 million of that will flip back around in Q4 as we expensed it in Q4 last year, Q3 this year.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext:
:  
          Okay, that's helpful. And then I'm just want to ask you, too, at least relative to our forecast, the equity and earnings, unconsolidated entities was up significantly. It's up year-over-year. I mean, I assume that's Shurgard, and maybe you can just give a little color on how that performed in the quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            In PSB, right? Yes, well, I think it's both Shurgard and PS Business Parks. And Business Parks, I don't think I know. Their earnings were, up about 20% quarter-to-quarter. That's a combination of 2 things: solid same-store results, fill up
componenttext:
:  
          In PSB, right? Yes, well, I think it's both Shurgard and PS Business Parks. And Business Parks, I don't think I know. Their earnings were, up about 20% quarter-to-quarter. That's a combination of 2 things: solid same-store results, fill up with some developments, and then they -- Business Parks has been sitting on $150 million or $200 million in cash. And so at the end of June, they paid off a $250 million mortgage. And so they had nominal interest expense Q3 versus having cash and the interest expense last year. So half of the improvement of Business Parks was due to reduced interest, and half of it was due to improved operations. Shurgard Europe had good operating results, both from the same-store and nonsame-store properties. But a big chunk of their difference was $1.5 million special tax provision we made in Q3 last year that we did not make in this quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Can you maybe just elaborate on some of the expense items, in particular, advertising? If you --  As you sort of see potentially occupancy or growth moderate a bit? Given how much more -- how many more customers are coming via the Internet?
componenttext:
:  
          Can you maybe just elaborate on some of the expense items, in particular, advertising? If you --  As you sort of see potentially occupancy or growth moderate a bit? Given how much more -- how many more customers are coming via the Internet? Can you give us how you sort of view the marketing and advertising bucket over the next, call it, year or so?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, this is John. We -- over the past year or 2, we've enjoyed a reduction in advertising as demand was coming in without the need to really spend more. In fact, we cut back significantly on both television and on the Internet. As we go fo
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, this is John. We -- over the past year or 2, we've enjoyed a reduction in advertising as demand was coming in without the need to really spend more. In fact, we cut back significantly on both television and on the Internet. As we go forward, if the softness continues, and it will at least over the next quarter or 2 and perhaps beyond, I don't know, I anticipate that we will spend more on -- definitely more on the Internet, on keyword search terms, probably spend more there than we will on television advertising. We did do a little television in Q3 and into Q4. Wasn't real thrilled with the response that we were getting, but we have been getting some pretty good response on the web. More and more of our customers, as you know, are moving to the web, whether they're using their desktop or mobile device, we're there, we're in both channels. So I expect, at least in the near term, our web spend will continue to tick up. I don't think that our television will really tick up. It will probably be the same. But overall, marketing costs will definitely be up.

[Audio Gap]
what does the spread need to be. It probably needs to be 75, at least 75 bps before, I think, we would really want to issue another preferred to take out some of these other preferreds. But I also wouldn't rule out us issuing debt. We've talked about debt before. So I mean, that's always a possibility that we could issue debt and take out some of these preferreds. But I want to make sure that you understand, we haven't made a decision on what we're going to do in the first quarter yet with respect to these preferreds.

componenttextpreview: :            I would say core San Francisco, no, I don't see a lot of pickup in core San Francisco. There may be some outliers like Sacramento and some other submarkets to San Francisco. Portland seems to have a fair bit of new supply coming into that m
componenttext:
:  
          I would say core San Francisco, no, I don't see a lot of pickup in core San Francisco. There may be some outliers like Sacramento and some other submarkets to San Francisco. Portland seems to have a fair bit of new supply coming into that market. San Diego has a fair bit being built for the size of the marketplace. But again, we don't see that much in Los Angeles, Orange County. We're not really focused on Riverside and San Bernardino where there may be some more building going on.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Okay, great. Maybe just a bigger picture question for you, Ron. We're now pretty well into, I guess, a development cycle nationally, if you want to call it that. But in terms of your overall strategy for revenue management, what are you guy
componenttext:
:  
          Okay, great. Maybe just a bigger picture question for you, Ron. We're now pretty well into, I guess, a development cycle nationally, if you want to call it that. But in terms of your overall strategy for revenue management, what are you guys planning on doing differently, if anything, kind of this time around from the last time we were entering a development cycle? Just in terms of what you're doing with rate, occupancy and strategy overall.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Well, David, I like to say, the big dog eats first. And so I think going into this cycle, we have better pricing, better pricing strategies, better marketing, both television and Internet. Our market position, in terms of our market share,
componenttext:
:  
          Well, David, I like to say, the big dog eats first. And so I think going into this cycle, we have better pricing, better pricing strategies, better marketing, both television and Internet. Our market position, in terms of our market share, the product where it's located is better headed into this cycle. We've really got great positioning. And we will have next year as the deliveries come on in terms of Dallas, Houston, Miami, Charlotte, L.A., San Francisco. So I'm really happy -- Seattle -- with our market position. Our people are fantastic out in the field. We've got better product that we have available to rent. And I think our processes are as good as they've ever been. So -- and I'm just skipping over the balance sheet, which has never been stronger in our history. So we're really ready for this cycle.

componenttext:

          Steve, let me see if I can answer the question a little bit. If you take the time and go back and look at our first quarter press release where we described our same stores, we give some metrics at the end of the quarter, what our square foot operate occupancy is and what the annual contract rate for occupied square foot is. You look at the first quarter, we reported that it was a 5.9% delta year-over-year. That gives a good indicator of what second quarter might be, and second quarter turned out to be a 6.1% revenue growth. If you now go to the second quarter information that we reported, we reported that the square foot occupancy had a negative decline of about 0.5%, that the annual contract rate was up 5.4%, the net of those 2 is a 4.9%. And we, in fact, reported a 5.2% for the quarter. So there was a big drop from Q1 to the end of Q2. We went from 5.9% to 4.9%. If you now look -- fast forward to the end of the third quarter, those same numbers are now at 4.7% versus 4.9% at the end of the second quarter. So the big drop, as I've kind of touched on, happened in Q2. We're still experiencing a decline, but the big drop happened earlier this year.

So that rate of change, right, we had exceptional quarters in Q2, 3 and 4 of last year.

componenttext:

          It's -- volumes, I think, are down. Or at least, I should say, the quality of the product coming to the marketplace is less than what it had been in prior quarters over the last year or so. And so I think buyers are being a little more selective. There's lots more that we pass on than what we're buying, primarily due to quality of the product. Pricing hasn't changed that much. Will it continue to change? I don't know. But I think there's been a slowdown of quality product coming to the marketplace.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Okay. And then just one more question. We -- there's all this talk about demand softening in terms of coming into your system. But how do you measure and quantify that? Is it simply Internet traffic plus walk-ins? And are you able to quanti
componenttext:

          Okay. And then just one more question. We -- there's all this talk about demand softening in terms of coming into your system. But how do you measure and quantify that? Is it simply Internet traffic plus walk-ins? And are you able to quantify sort of the deceleration that you've seen in the third quarter and October?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, the way I look at it, Ryan, is to say -- I look at it, at the call volume into our call center, the hits to our website where they're actually seeking and looking at storage space, so it's not the hits that come to our website of exist
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, the way I look at it, Ryan, is to say -- I look at it, at the call volume into our call center, the hits to our website where they're actually seeking and looking at storage space, so it's not the hits that come to our website of existing tenants that are paying their rent, as well as looking at our walk-in traffic as you actually mentioned. During the third quarter, we were actually seeing an uptick in sales calls. Part of that's due to the increased, I think, marketing activities. The web channel was about flat, though. But the channel that, I think, gives me most concerned is that our walk-in traffic was down about 7%. So 2 of our channels were either flat or up, but the walk-in channel was down. And I can't tell you why that has happened, but in fact, it was down 7% during the quarter.

:  
          Just one quick one, just sticking on the development front. I was just wondering if some of the correction in the market would be at lower rates, increasing discounting? Has that created any additional opportunities under the development front for you guys, either an opportunity to go acquire some land to build or in markets where maybe you're holding off, but now mentioning like a better time to start construction?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Well, Dave can provide that. Jeremy, generally, if rates are trending down, all other things being equal, that's going to slow development for us because the deals won't underwrite the way in terms of what we're trying to achieve in terms o
componenttext:
:  
          Well, Dave can provide that. Jeremy, generally, if rates are trending down, all other things being equal, that's going to slow development for us because the deals won't underwrite the way in terms of what we're trying to achieve in terms of return on invested capital. So a declining rate environment won't do that in the near term. Also, in the near term, land prices tend to lag changes in market conditions, right? Just like on the way up, they tend to lag on moving up. When you see the market turn, you can usually get good land deals for a period of time. So they tend to lag on the way down. So, so far, at least I haven't seen any reduction, big reductions in land prices. David?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext:
:  
          It's actually Michael Bilerman. Ron, I'm curious, you've always focused on cap flow and cash flow growth rather than any sort of NAV metric. But I'm curious, now that the stock's around $200, which is probably just about the where you probably take your NAV, but more importantly, from a cash flow perspective, free cash flow yield, north of 5%. Does that entice you at all to put your, what you described as the best balance sheet you've ever had into your stock at this point?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: :            Well, Michael, I'll just say this. If you look back in time, over 20-plus years, it's very rare that we can issue preferred at coupons below kind of the earnings yield on our stock, and we're getting pretty close to that. Now the last time
componenttext:
:  
          Well, Michael, I'll just say this. If you look back in time, over 20-plus years, it's very rare that we can issue preferred at coupons below kind of the earnings yield on our stock, and we're getting pretty close to that. Now the last time that there was -- that it happened at any -- for any extended period of time was '99-2000 when everyone wanted dot-com stocks and real estate was a bad word, brick-and-mortar. I don't know if we're going into that now, but it's very unusual for us to be able to issue preferred and coupons lower than our earnings yield. So we're getting close. And as John touched on, we'll see what we can continue to issue preferred and/or debt at. But it's not out of the question as time goes forward in terms of what -- where to deploy capital. Having said that, if we can deploy capital in third-party acquisitions or development opportunities that provide a kind of better spread yield or better overall earnings yield to the company, then we will do that vis--vis our share repurchases. So kind of which part of the menu of acquisitions development or share repurchases makes the most in terms of capital in terms of both growth and accretion to shareholder value.

So in terms of an IPO, it'd be tough to do it in terms of use of proceeds. That could change in 3 to 6 months if some big opportunity came up in Europe. But at this time, I don't see that.

componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Public Storage Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Clem Teng. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Public Storage Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Clem Teng. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our third quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.Before we begin, I wanted to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of histo
componenttext:
Good morning, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our third quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner and John Reyes.
Before we begin, I wanted to remind those on the call that all statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements, subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements.
These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release and in our reports filed with the SEC. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, October 27, 2016, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com.
Now I'll turn the call over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem, and welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter. And so with that, I'll open it up for questions.
componenttext: Thank you, Clem, and welcome, everyone. We had another solid quarter. And so with that, I'll open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jeff Spector of Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jeff Spector of Bank of America.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And definitely want to recognize great growth in the quarter. Just if, Ron, you could give us maybe 2 minutes overview on the state of the market. You guys did a great job telegraphing some of the issues we may see this year in storage. But if you could j
componenttext: And definitely want to recognize great growth in the quarter. Just if, Ron, you could give us maybe 2 minutes overview on the state of the market. You guys did a great job telegraphing some of the issues we may see this year in storage. But if you could just summarize, I guess, the latest that you're seeing, whether it's supply, concessions and how you're thinking of running the business through the end of the year, that would be appreciated.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeff. I think, big picture, a couple of items. Our revenue growth rate obviously slowed down to 5.1%, but it's an incredible number, 5%. It's down from 6% last year but still a great number. If you look across our top 20 markets, all had positive gr
componenttext: Sure, Jeff. I think, big picture, a couple of items. Our revenue growth rate obviously slowed down to 5.1%, but it's an incredible number, 5%. It's down from 6% last year but still a great number. If you look across our top 20 markets, all had positive growth year-over-year except one, Houston. The interesting thing though or trend thing that, I think, you want to get after is that if you take 80% of our revenue base, the rate of change in our growth rate decelerated in the third quarter year-over-year. So you take a market like Houston, which -- their year-over-year growth rate was down 9.3% Q3 '15 to Q3 2016. Denver was down 8.8% Q3 '15 growth rate versus Q3 2016. So 80% of our revenue base had a decline in the rate of growth. And certainly, we were up against very tough comps from 2015. We had an incredible third quarter last year. But what does that tell me? That growth is slowing. It's not all due to new supply because not all of these markets are impacted by new supply to the same degree. But you have markets like Los Angeles and San Francisco, which are certainly supply constrained, very hard to get new product in, I'd say, relatively new -- low new supply, but their rate of growth slowed. The other big picture is expenses uptick this quarter. And for us, there's a couple of explanations. But overall, expenses were up. And the big change -- one of the key items, I think, you should focus on is property taxes, up 5.4%, which continues to ratchet up by year-over-year. Supply is up, and the rate of change in new supply continues to accelerate. It's different across various markets. And I think that will continue to be a headwind on pricing power going into 2017. For us, we're going to continue to build. Our development pipelines up to $600 million. David and the team have done an excellent job, and the product that we're building is just exceptional. It's filling up pretty much according to plan, and our acquisitions are also doing quite well. For the most part, the stuff we bought from 2013 through 2016, most of it is ahead of what we underwrote. So the fundamentals of the business are still great. It's just the rate of change in growth, especially the top line, has slowed a little bit. John, you want to add any color on pricing and what you've been doing in terms of marketing?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say that what we're experiencing is mostly a softness in demand. The existing tenant base that we have is pretty much staying put like they normally have. So they're not vacating any more rapidly than we've seen. So the struggle, I would say,
componenttext: Yes. I would say that what we're experiencing is mostly a softness in demand. The existing tenant base that we have is pretty much staying put like they normally have. So they're not vacating any more rapidly than we've seen. So the struggle, I would say, that we are experiencing is really on the front end, getting move-ins in. Demand appears to be soft around the country, not in any one particular market. I would say, in general, every market is experiencing softness. And as a result, we're having to -- we're advertising more on television, we're advertising more on the Internet, we are lowering our Street rates and we are giving away a little bit more discounts, not much more than last year, but a little bit more of this year. So -- but again, I'd like to emphasize that the existing tenant base is not vacating out any more rapidly than they have. We're continuing to send rate increase letters similar to how we did last year, with increases in the range of 8% to 10%.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's helpful. Can I ask one follow-up? On that softness in demand, can you discuss that a bit? And is there anything you attribute to that specifically related to the economy, whether it's jobs or lack of income growth?
componenttext: It's helpful. Can I ask one follow-up? On that softness in demand, can you discuss that a bit? And is there anything you attribute to that specifically related to the economy, whether it's jobs or lack of income growth?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jeff, I'll touch on that. It kind of goes to -- and this is my point in terms of 80% of our revenue base had a slower year-over-year rate of growth than Q3 of last year. We're up against very tough comps. It's broad based, and a number of these mark
componenttext: Well, Jeff, I'll touch on that. It kind of goes to -- and this is my point in terms of 80% of our revenue base had a slower year-over-year rate of growth than Q3 of last year. We're up against very tough comps. It's broad based, and a number of these markets, I mean, are -- have very dynamic economies: the Bay Area; Los Angeles; Seattle, this quarter, had a positive year-over-year rate of growth change; Sacramento; Minneapolis. So there's a lot of markets that still have some growth in them, but it's broad based in terms of slowdown. And I think, in part, it's due to just an exceptional 2015.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Gaurav Mehta of Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Gaurav Mehta of Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the slowdown in demand and revenues. I was wondering how that's impacting acquisition market, and how you're underwriting assets today versus a couple of quarters ago.
componenttext: Just following up on the slowdown in demand and revenues. I was wondering how that's impacting acquisition market, and how you're underwriting assets today versus a couple of quarters ago.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not materially impacting what we're doing. In underwriting our acquisitions, we use what we have in terms of kind of a spot price in terms of rental rates on a trailing basis. We don't necessarily try to anticipate what the forward rate per foot is g
componenttext: It's not materially impacting what we're doing. In underwriting our acquisitions, we use what we have in terms of kind of a spot price in terms of rental rates on a trailing basis. We don't necessarily try to anticipate what the forward rate per foot is going to be. And then, of course, for us, replacement cost has been and continues to be a key element in terms of our underwriting. So the market may be tough. Take Houston. If we can get something that's 60% or 70% replacement cost, we'll do that deal even though in the short term, we may be impacted by overall market conditions.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And as a follow-up, have you seen any changes in cap rates for stabilized assets in any of your markets?
componenttext: Great. And as a follow-up, have you seen any changes in cap rates for stabilized assets in any of your markets?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really.
componenttext: Not really.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give some stats on the move-in rate for the quarter and how that trended into October, please?
componenttext: Could you give some stats on the move-in rate for the quarter and how that trended into October, please?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ki, this is John. Ki Bin, this is John. The average move-in rate during the third quarter was about $135 per month. That compared to last year at $137 for the month -- for the quarter. That was for the quarter on a monthly basis. Month-to-date, in October
componenttext: Ki, this is John. Ki Bin, this is John. The average move-in rate during the third quarter was about $135 per month. That compared to last year at $137 for the month -- for the quarter. That was for the quarter on a monthly basis. Month-to-date, in October, the average move-in rate's about $127 per month, and that's actually up a little bit from last year, which was about $126 per month. But I will tell you this, notwithstanding the fact that it is higher than last year, the volume of move-ins that we are getting in the month of -- at least month-to-date October, is down about 3%. So getting higher rates but lower volume.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, it's a similar question I asked like 0.5 hour ago to your competitor's call, but I know we've tended to focus a lot on the supply side, but overall, on the demand side, what do you think is causing it the lower traffic or lower volume or pric
componenttext: And I guess, it's a similar question I asked like 0.5 hour ago to your competitor's call, but I know we've tended to focus a lot on the supply side, but overall, on the demand side, what do you think is causing it the lower traffic or lower volume or price sensitivity? Because we just haven't seen it before in the sector recently. So what do you think is really causing this change?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ki, it's so broad based, and it varies by market. Well, John is saying volume is down 3% in a number of markets right now. In some markets, I mean, we're chock-full. We have not much space to sell, so there's not much of a volume uptick that we can get. A
componenttext: Ki, it's so broad based, and it varies by market. Well, John is saying volume is down 3% in a number of markets right now. In some markets, I mean, we're chock-full. We have not much space to sell, so there's not much of a volume uptick that we can get. And then you have markets like Houston, which are-- have probably both a supply issue as well as an overall local economy issue with the big changes in the oil industry. And the other markets, whether it's San Francisco or L.A., don't have enough net new space to sell to offset the decline in volume in markets like Houston or Denver.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how about New York?
componenttext: And how about New York?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: New York's doing okay.
componenttext: New York's doing okay.
